    The mayor and councilmen in office at the date this charter is adopted shall continue in office until after the election of April, 1987, and within one (1) week thereafter, shall canvass the returns of said election, declare the results thereof, and induct into office the mayor and councilmen declared elected. Thereupon the newly elected mayor and councilmen shall forthwith become the official governing body of the city and shall conduct the first meeting of the newly elected council. 
Section 15.5. - Temporary Ordinances. 
    At its first meeting or at any meeting held within sixty (60) days thereafter, the council may adopt temporary ordinances to deal with cases in which there is an urgent need for prompt action in connection with the transition of government and in which the delay incident to the appropriate ordinance procedure would probably cause serious hardship or impairment of effective city government. Every temporary ordinance shall be plainly labeled as such but shall be introduced in the form and manner prescribed for ordinances generally. A temporary ordinance may be considered and may be adopted with or without amendment or rejected at the meeting at which it is introduced. A temporary ordinance shall become effective upon adoption or at such later time preceding automatic repeal under this subsection as it may specify, and the referendum power shall not extend to any such ordinance. Every temporary ordinance, including any amendments made thereto after adoption, shall automatically stand repealed as of the ninety-first (91st) day following the date on which it was adopted, and it shall not be readopted, renewed or otherwise continued except by adoption in the manner prescribed for ordinances of the kind concerned. 
Section 15.6. - Purpose of Schedule. 
    The purpose of the foregoing provisions is to provide a transition from the present government of the City of Fulton, Missouri, to the new government provided for in this charter and to inaugurate the new government under the provisions of this charter. They shall constitute a part of this charter only to the extent and for the time required to accomplish that aim. 
PART II - CODE 
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
  

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of the City of Fulton, Missouri" and may be so cited. Such ordinances may also be cited as "Fulton City Code." 
(Code 1980, § 1-1) 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
(a)  In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances of the city, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless it shall be otherwise expressly provided in any section or ordinance or unless inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council or unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    City. The term "the city" or "this city" shall mean the City of Fulton, Missouri. 
    City council. The term "city council" or "the council" shall mean the city council of Fulton, Missouri. 
    Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day, and if the last day is Sunday or a legal holiday, that shall be excluded. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 1.040. 
    Corporate limits, corporation limits, city limits. Whenever the term "corporate limits," "corporation limits" or "city limits" is used, it shall mean the legal boundary of the City of Fulton. 
    County. The term "the county" shall mean the County of Callaway. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision or section appears requiring the head of a department of the city to do some act or make certain inspections, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection, unless the terms of the provision or section designate otherwise. 
    Gender. When any subject matter, party or person is described or referred to by words importing the masculine, females, as well as males, and associations and bodies corporate, as well as individuals, shall be deemed to be included. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 1.030(2). 
    Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of any section of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provision imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
    Joint authority. Words importing joint authority to three or more persons shall be construed as authority to a majority of such persons. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 1.050. 
    Keeper and proprietor. The terms "keeper" and "proprietor" shall mean and include persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs and partnerships, whether acting by themselves or by a servant, agent or employee. 
    Month. The term "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 1.020(10). 
    Name of officer. Whenever the name of an officer is given, it shall be construed as though the term "of the City of Fulton" were added. 
    Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
    Number. When any subject matter, party or person is described or referred to by words importing the singular number, the plural and separate matters and persons and bodies corporate shall be deemed to be included. 
    Oath. The term "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the terms "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the terms "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Or, and. The term "or" may be read "and," and the term "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The term "person" shall include a corporation, firm, partnership, association, organization and any other group acting as a unit, as well as individuals. It shall also include an executor, administrator, trustee, receiver or other representative appointed according to law. Whenever the term "person" is used in any section of this Code prescribing a penalty or fine, as to partnerships or associations, the term shall include the partners or members thereof and as to corporations shall include the officers, agents or members thereof who are responsible for any violation of such section. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 1.020(11). 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" shall include every species of property, except real property, as defined in this section. 
    Preceding, following. The terms "preceding" and "following" shall mean next before and next after, respectively. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 1.020(12). 
    Property. The term "property" shall include real, tangible and intangible personal property. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 1.020(15). 
    Public place. The term "public place" shall mean any park, cemetery, schoolyard or open space adjacent thereto and all other property open to the public. 
    Public way. The term "public way" shall include any street, alley, boulevard, parkway, highway, sidewalk or other public thoroughfare. 
    Real property, premises, real estate or lands. The terms "real property," "premises," "real estate" or "lands" shall be deemed to be coextensive with lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Residence. The term "residence" shall be construed to mean the place adopted by a person as his place of habitation and to which, whenever he is absent, he has the intention of returning. When a person eats at one place and sleeps at another, the place where such person sleeps shall be deemed his residence. 
    Seal. Whenever the term "seal" is used, it shall mean the city or corporate seal. 
    Shall; may. The term "shall" is mandatory; the term "may" is permissive. 
    Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" shall mean the portion of the street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Signature. Where the written signature of any person is required, the proper handwriting of such person or his mark shall be intended. 
    State. The term "the state" or "this state" shall mean the State of Missouri. 
    Street. The term "street" shall mean and include any public way, highway, street, avenue, boulevard, parkway, alley or other public thoroughfare, and each of such words shall include all of them. 
    Tangible personal property. The term "tangible personal property" shall include goods, chattels and all personal property, except intangible personal property. 
    Tenant, occupant. The term "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    Writing. The terms "writing" and "written" shall include printing, lithographing or any other mode of representing words and letters, but in all cases where the signature of a person is required, the proper handwriting of the person or his mark is intended. 
    Year. The term "year" shall mean a calendar year, unless otherwise expressed, and the term "year" shall be equivalent to the term "year of our Lord." 
(b)  All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the city council may be fully carried out. 
(Code 1980, § 1-2) 
State Law reference- Definitions, rules of construction, RSMo 1.020 et seq. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections; provisions considered as continuation of existing ordinances. 
(a)  The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such section or as any part of the section nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(b)  The sections appearing in this and the following chapters, so far as they are the same as those ordinances existing at the time of the adoption of this Code, shall be considered as a continuation thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Code 1980, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional or invalid by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code, since the phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections would have been enacted by the city council without the incorporation in this Code of any such unconstitutional or invalid phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
(Code 1980, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-5. - Repeal of ordinance not to affect liabilities, etc. 
    Whenever any ordinance or part of an ordinance shall be repealed or modified, either expressly or by implication, by a subsequent ordinance, the ordinance or part of an ordinance thus repealed or modified shall continue in force until the ordinance repealing or modifying such ordinance shall go into effect unless therein otherwise expressly provided; but no suit, prosecution, proceeding, right, fine or penalty instituted, created, given, secured or accrued under any ordinance prior to its repeal shall in any way be affected, released or discharged, but may be prosecuted, enjoyed and recovered as fully as if such ordinance or provisions had continued in force, unless it shall be therein otherwise expressly provided. 
(Code 1980, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-6. - Repeal not to revive former ordinance. 
    When an ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision shall itself be repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive such former ordinance, clause or provision unless it be expressly so provided and such former ordinance, clause or provision is set forth at length. 
(Code 1980, § 1-6) 
Sec. 1-7. - Seal-Device; form and size. 
    The device of the seal of the city shall be a bare arm and hand holding a hammer, and the seal shall be so engraved as to represent by its impression on such device surrounded by a double circle in which shall be the words "City of Fulton," "seal." The seal shall be circular and two inches in diameter, and all as designed and in use by the city. 
(Code 1980, § 1-7) 
Sec. 1-8. - Same-Clerk's duties. 
    The city clerk shall keep the seal of the city in his office and shall affix the seal to all instruments of writing of whatsoever nature, whenever required by ordinance, resolution or order of the city council or at the request of the mayor. 
(Code 1980, § 1-8) 
Sec. 1-9. - Same-Affixing when required by person. 
    The city clerk is authorized to affix the seal of the city to copies of all records and documents whenever required by any person. 
(Code 1980, § 1-9) 
Sec. 1-10. - Enactment of ordinances. 
(a)  All ordinances passed and adopted by the city council shall be recorded by the clerk of the city council in the ordinance book and signed by the mayor and countersigned by the clerk of the city council, and all ordinances when so recorded, signed and countersigned shall be considered and taken to be the original roll of the ordinances of the city. 
(b)  Beginning with the ordinance following the last ordinance included in this Code, each proposed ordinance shall be assigned a bill number, beginning with number 1 and continuing in numerical order, and each ordinance finally adopted, beginning with the ordinance following the last ordinance included in this Code, shall be assigned an ordinance number, beginning with number 1 and continuing in numerical order. A separate file shall be kept of all bills not finally adopted. 
(c)  Any ordinance passed and adopted by the city council shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage, except as may be otherwise provided in such ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 1-10) 
Sec. 1-11. - Copies of Code. 
(a)  The city clerk shall keep two copies of this Code. These copies shall be so preserved by the city clerk that any and all amendments to or general ordinances affecting such codification shall be shown by appropriate notes. The purpose of this subsection is to ensure the maintenance in the office of the city clerk of two master copies of the codification in which shall be shown any and all changes which have taken place since the publication of this Code. 
(b)  In determining whether or not any ordinance passed or any part thereof shall be noted in the copies of the codification so preserved by the city clerk and in determining the form of any such note and its location, if any doubt arises, the city clerk shall be guided by the advice of the city counselor or his assistants. 
(Code 1980, § 1-11) 
Sec. 1-12. - Code as evidence. 
    Any printed copy of this Code containing a printed certificate of the mayor and the city clerk as to the correctness of such codification shall be received in evidence in any court for the purpose of proving the ordinances therein contained and for the same purpose as the original ordinances, minutes or journals would be received. 
(Code 1980, § 1-12) 
Sec. 1-13. - Amendments to Code-Effect. 
    Any and all additions and amendments to this Code, when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the city council to make the addition or amendment a part of this Code, shall be deemed to be incorporated in this Code so that reference to the "Code of the City of Fulton, Missouri," shall be understood and intended to include such additions and amendments. 
(Code 1980, § 1-13) 
Sec. 1-14. - Same-Procedures. 
    All ordinances passed subsequent to the adoption of this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion in this Code, or in the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby, and the subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new code of ordinances by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 1-14) 
Sec. 1-15. - Same-Language. 
    Amendments to any of the chapters, articles, divisions or sections of this Code should be made by amending such chapters, articles, divisions or sections by specific reference to the chapter, article, division or section of this Code in substantially the following language: "That chapter (or article, division or section) _____ of the Code of the City of Fulton, Missouri, is hereby amended to read as follows: _______ (set out new provisions in full) _______." 
(Code 1980, § 1-15) 
Sec. 1-16. - Same-New material. 
(a)  If a new section not existing in this Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Code of the City of Fulton, Missouri, is hereby amended by adding a chapter (or article, division, section or other designation, as the case may be), to be numbered _____, which reads as follows: _______(set out new provisions in full)_____." 
(b)  In lieu of subsection (a) of this section, when the city council desires to enact an ordinance of a general and permanent nature embracing a subject not previously existing in the Code, which the city council desires to incorporate into the Code, a provision in substantially the following language may be made part of such ordinance: "It is the intention of the city council, and it is hereby ordained, that the provisions of this ordinance shall become and be made part of the Code of the City of Fulton, Missouri, and the sections of this ordinance may be renumbered to accomplish such intention." 
(Code 1980, § 1-16) 
Sec. 1-17. - Same-Repeal. 
    All sections, divisions, articles, chapters or other provisions of this Code desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section number, division number, article number, chapter or other number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1980, § 1-17) 
Sec. 1-18. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
(Code 1980, § 1-18) 
Sec. 1-19. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof or to alter or tamper with this Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. 
(Code 1980, § 1-19) 
Sec. 1-20. - General penalty for Code violations; continuing violations. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or any other ordinance of the city any act or failure to act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided, the violation of any such provision shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00 or by imprisonment for a term not to exceed 90 days or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(b)  Each day any violation of this Code or any other ordinance of the city continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1980, § 1-20) 
Cross reference- Planning and code enforcement officer, § 2-251 et seq.; alcoholic beverages, ch. 10; civil emergencies, ch. 34; courts, ch. 38; law enforcement, ch. 70; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 78; administration and enforcement of traffic regulations, § 110-31 et seq. 
Sec. 1-21. - Ordinances saved from repeal generally. 
    Nothing contained in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the following: 
(1)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of the ordinance adopting this Code; 
(2)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(3)  Any ordinance fixing salaries or other compensation of officers, employees or special counsel of the city not inconsistent with such Code; 
(4)  Any appropriation ordinance; 
(5)  Any right or franchise granted by the city council to any person, firm or corporation; 
(6)  Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, closing, paving, widening, vacating, or in any way affecting any street or public way in the city; 
(7)  Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the city; 
(8)  Any ordinance providing for local improvements or assessing taxes therefor; 
(9)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city; 
(10)  Any ordinance establishing traffic regulations for specific streets or portions thereof, not inconsistent with this Code; 
(11)  Any ordinance annexing property to the city; 
(12)  Any zoning ordinance of the city; 
(13)  Any ordinance levying taxes, not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this Code; 
(14)  Any ordinance fixing utility rates and charges. 
Such repeal shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part of an ordinance which is repealed by this Code. 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Animal control commission, § 14-41 et seq.; local organization for civil emergencies, § 34-26 et seq.; elections, ch. 42; fire prevention and protection, ch. 50; administration and enforcement of flood control regulations, § 54-31 et seq.; historic preservation commission, § 62-26 et seq.; human rights and community relations commission, § 66-31 et seq.; disability grievance procedure, § 66-61 et seq.; police department, § 70-26 et seq.; superintendent of parks and recreation, § 82-26 et seq.; parks and recreation board, § 82-51 et seq.; planning and zoning commission, § 86-26 et seq.; signs, ch. 92; solid waste department, § 94-26 et seq.; administration and enforcement of traffic regulations, § 110-31 et seq.; zoning, app. A. 
State Law reference- Provisions relative to all cities, RSMo 71.010 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Chapter's status. 
    This chapter shall constitute the administrative code required by section 6.1 of the city Charter. 
(Code 1980, § 32-1) 
Sec. 2-2. - Contracts-Authorization. 
(a)  Whenever it is deemed necessary for the city to enter into any contract with any person, the city council may by ordinance or resolution instruct the mayor and city clerk to enter into any such contract on behalf of the city. 
(b)  Such ordinance shall state the names of parties to such contract to be made and entered into and the general terms and the consideration thereof. 
(Code 1980, § 2-1; Ord. No. 648-93, § 1, 8-24-93) 
State Law reference- Requirements for municipal contracts generally, RSMo 432.070; duplicate copies required, RSMo 432.080. 
Sec. 2-3. - Same-Form. 
    All contracts entered into pursuant to section 2-2 shall be in writing, shall be signed by the parties thereto and, on the part of the city, shall be signed by the mayor and countersigned by the city clerk with the seal of the city affixed thereto. 
(Code 1980, § 2-2; Ord. No. 648-93, § 1, 8-24-93) 
Sec. 2-4. - Same-Bids. 
    The city council may solicit sealed bids for any contract through the city clerk, and the council shall have the right to reject any bids. 
(Code 1980, § 2-3; Ord. No. 648-93, § 1, 8-24-93) 
Sec. 2-5. - Impersonation of city officers. 
    No person shall, in the city, falsely represent himself to be an officer of the city or shall, without being lawfully authorized, exercise any of the duties, functions or powers of an officer of the city. 
(Ord. No. 648-93, § 1, 8-24-93) 
Sec. 2-6. - Hindering, obstructing or resisting officer in discharge of duty. 
    No person shall hinder, obstruct, resist or otherwise interfere with an officer of the city in the discharge of his official duty or attempt to rescue any person from the custody of any such officer. 
(Code 1980, § 2-5; Ord. No. 648-93, § 1, 8-24-93) 
Sec. 2-7. - Statements of city officers in claims against the city. 
    Officers, agents and employees of the city shall not give, make or sign statements presented to them by attorneys, adjusters or others having or prosecuting claims against the city, except with the advice and consent of the city counselor. 
(Code 1980, § 2-6; Ord. No. 648-93, § 1, 8-24-93) 
Sec. 2-8. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal year of the city shall commence on the first day of January and terminate on the thirty-first day of December of each year, and the books, accounts and reports of all officers shall be made to conform thereto. 
(Ord. No. 648-93, § 1, 8-24-93; Ord. No. 718-96, § 1, 6-25-96) 
Sec. 2-9. - Fiscal or interest disclosure-Declaration of policy. 
    The proper operation of municipal government requires that public officials and employees be independent, impartial and responsible to the people; that government decisions and policy be made in the proper channels of the governmental structure; that public office not be used for personal gain; and that the public have confidence in the integrity of its government. In recognition of these goals, there is hereby established a procedure for disclosure by certain officials and employees of private financial or other interests in matters affecting the city. 
(Code 1980, § 2-8; Ord. No. 648-93, § 1, 8-24-93; Ord. No. 672-94, § 1, 8-23-94; Ord. No. 883-01, § 1, 8-14-01; Ord. No. 938-03, § 1, 8-26-03; Ord. No. 1105-05, § 1, 8-23-05; Ord. No. 1189-07, § 1, 8-28-07; Ord. No. 1350-13, § 1, 8-13-13; Ord. No. 1391-15, § 1, 7-14-15) 
Sec. 2-10. - Same-Conflicts of interest. 
    The mayor or any member of the city council who has a substantial personal or private interest, as defined by state law, in any bill shall disclose on the records of the city council the nature of his interest and shall disqualify himself from voting on any matters relating to this interest. 
(Code 1980, § 2-9; Ord. No. 648-93, § 1, 8-24-93; Ord. No. 672-94, § 1, 8-23-94; Ord. No. 883-01, § 1, 8-14-01; Ord. No. 938-03, § 1, 8-26-03; Ord. No. 1105-05, § 1, 8-23-05; Ord. No. 1189-07, § 1, 8-28-07; Ord. No. 1350-13, § 1, 8-13-13; Ord. No. 1391-15, § 1, 7-14-15) 
Sec. 2-11. - Same-Disclosure reports. 
    Each elected official, the director of administration, and chief financial officer shall disclose the following information by May 1 if any such transaction were engaged in during the previous calendar year. 
(a)  For such person, and all persons within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity of such person, the date and the identities of the parties to each transaction with a total value in excess of $500.00, if any, that such person had with the political subdivision, other than compensation received as an employee or payment of any tax, fee or penalty due to the political subdivision, and other than transfers for no consideration to the political subdivision; and 
(b)  The date and the identities of the parties to each transaction known to the person with a total value in excess of $500.00, if any, that any business entity in which such person had a substantial interest, had with the political subdivision, other than payment of any tax, fee or penalty due to the political subdivision or transactions involving payment for providing utility service to the political subdivision, and other than transfers for no consideration to the political subdivision. 
(c)  The director of administration and the chief financial officer also shall disclose by May 1 for the previous calendar year the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of each of the employers of such person or firm from whom income of $1,000.00 or more was received during the year covered by the statement; 
(2)  The name and address of each sole proprietorship that he owned; the name, address and the general nature of the business conducted of each general partnership and joint venture in which he was a partner or participant; the name and address of each partner or co participant for each partnership or joint venture unless such names and addresses are filed by the partnership or joint venture with the secretary of state; the name, address and general nature of the business conducted of any closely held corporation or limited partnership in which the person owned ten percent or more of any class of the outstanding stock or limited partnership units; and the name of any publicly traded corporation or limited partnership that is listed on a regulated stock exchange or automated quotation system in which the person owned two percent or more of any class of outstanding stock, limited partnership units or other equity interests; 
(3)  The name and address of each corporation for which such person served in the capacity of a director, officer or receiver. 
(Code 1980, § 2-10; Ord. No. 648-93, § 1, 8-24-93; Ord. No. 672-94, § 1, 8-23-94; Ord. No. 883-01, § 1, 8-14-01; Ord. No. 938-03, § 1, 8-26-03; Ord. No. 1105-05, § 1, 8-23-05; Ord. No. 1189-07, § 1, 8-28-07; Ord. No. 1350-13, § 1, 8-13-13; Ord. No. 1391-15, § 1, 7-14-15) 
Sec. 2-12. - Same-Filing of reports. 
    The reports, in the prescribed format, shall be filed with the city clerk and with the secretary of state prior to January 1, 1993, and thereafter with the Missouri Ethics Commission. The reports shall be available for public inspection and copying during normal business hours. 
(Code 1980, § 2-11; Ord. No. 648-93, § 1, 8-24-93; Ord. No. 672-94, § 1, 8-23-94; Ord. No. 883-01, § 1, 8-14-01; Ord. No. 938-03, § 1, 8-26-03; Ord. No. 1105-05, § 1, 8-23-05; Ord. No. 1189-07, § 1, 8-28-07; Ord. No. 1350-13, § 1, 8-13-13; Ord. No. 1391-15, § 1, 7-14-15) 
Sec. 2-13. - Same-When filed. 
    The financial interest statements shall be filed at the following times, but no person is required to file more than one financial interest statement in any calendar year: 
(a)  Each person appointed to office shall file the statement within 30 days of such appointment or employment; 
(b)  Every other person required to file a financial interest statement shall file the statement annually not later than May 1 and the statement shall cover the calendar year ending the immediately preceding December 31; providing that any member of the city council may supplement the financial interest statement to report additional interests acquired after December 31 of the covered year until the date of filing of the financial interest statement. 
(Code 1980, § 2-12; Ord. No. 648-93, § 1, 8-24-93; Ord. No. 672-94, § 1, 8-23-94; Ord. No. 883-01, § 1, 8-14-01; Ord. No. 938-03, § 1, 8-26-03; Ord. No. 1105-05, § 1, 8-23-05; Ord. No. 1189-07, § 1, 8-28-07; Ord. No. 1350-13, § 1, 8-13-13; Ord. No. 1391-15, § 1, 7-14-15) 
Secs. 2-14-2-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Division of city into wards, RSMo 82.110; election of officers, date, RSMo 82.040. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-31. - Election. 
    An election for one councilmember shall be held in each ward on the first Tuesday in April of each year. 
(Code 1980, § 2-30(c)) 
Sec. 2-32. - Qualifications; term of office. 
(a)  No person shall be eligible to the office of councilmember who is not 21 years of age, a citizen of the United States and a qualified voter of the city. Such person shall have been a resident of the city for at least one year immediately preceding his nomination and a resident of his ward immediately preceding his nomination. No person shall be a councilmember who is in arrears for any tax lien, forfeiture or defalcation in office. 
(b)  Members of the council shall hold office for two years ensuing their election, and until their successors are elected, qualified and commissioned, unless they have resigned, moved from the ward from which they were elected or for other reasons vacated the office. 
(Code 1980, § 2-31) 
Sec. 2-33. - Compensation of deputy mayor when acting as mayor. 
    If a vacancy occurs in the office of mayor as set forth in section 4.5 of the city Charter, the deputy mayor who assumes all the duties and responsibilities of the mayor shall receive the same salary as the mayor until the next regular municipal election. 
(Code 1980, § 2-32) 
Sec. 2-34. - Meeting times, places-Generally. 
    All meetings of the city council shall be held at such places and times as established by the council from time to time. 
(Code 1980, § 2-37) 
Sec. 2-35. - Same-Regular. 
(a)  The first regular meeting of the city council after each annual election shall be held on the second Tuesday in April, and thereafter regular meetings shall be held on the second Tuesday of each month at 7:30 p.m. or as may be provided by the council. 
(b)  Adjourned meetings shall be reconvened whenever the council shall deem necessary. 
(Code 1980, § 2-38) 
Charter reference- Council to set meeting time and place, § 3.10(a). 
Sec. 2-36. - Election of deputy mayor. 
(a)  At the first regular meeting after each annual city election, the council shall elect a deputy mayor from the council to serve for one year. The deputy mayor shall act as the mayor during the absence or disability of the mayor. 
(b)  If the election of a deputy mayor results in a tie vote of the council, the council shall proceed to determine the election by lot. 
(Code 1980, § 2-39) 
Charter reference- Deputy mayor, § 3.4. 
Sec. 2-37. - Special committees. 
    Special committees may be appointed by the mayor or by the council from time to time, and such committees shall consider and report on such matters as may be referred to them. 
(Code 1980, § 2-40) 
Secs. 2-38-2-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RULES AND ORDER OF BUSINESS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Council to determine its rules and order of business, § 3.10(a). 

Sec. 2-51. - Rules to govern deliberations of council. 
    Rules of order and council procedure shall be submitted by the mayor and approved by the council at the beginning of each new term of the council. Any procedural question not covered by the adopted rules or this division shall be determined by reference to Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised. 
(Code 1980, § 2-52) 
Sec. 2-52. - Deputy mayor performing duties of mayor; election of substitute deputy mayor. 
    When the hour designated for a council meeting arrives, if the mayor is not present the deputy mayor shall perform all the duties of the mayor and as presiding officer of the council. If both the mayor and deputy mayor are absent, a quorum of members being present, the member with the most seniority on the council shall call the council to order and shall perform all the duties of the president of the council to order and shall perform all the duties of the president of the council for that meeting or until the mayor or deputy mayor shall arrive. Any member serving in such capacity shall retain a right to vote. 
(Code 1980, § 2-54) 
Sec. 2-53. - Committee of the whole. 
    It shall be the standing order for the council to resolve themselves into committee of the whole council on the state of the city. On motion made and carried to go into committee of the whole, the mayor shall leave the chair and call the councilmember with the most seniority on the council present to preside. The rules of proceeding in the council shall be observed in the committee as far as they are applicable, except that no limit of speaking shall be observed. A motion for the rising of the committee shall always be in order, unless a member is speaking, and shall be decided without debate. 
(Code 1980, § 2-55) 
Sec. 2-54. - Voting. 
    Every member of the council who shall be present when the question is stated by the chair shall vote thereon, unless excused by the council or unless he is prohibited by section 13.1 of the Charter. 
(Code 1980, § 2-56) 
Sec. 2-55. - Reducing motions and resolutions to writing. 
    Every resolution of the council shall be reduced to writing, and every motion of the council, at the request of the president or of any member of the council, shall be reduced to writing. 
(Code 1980, § 2-57) 
Sec. 2-56. - Deciding priority of business; objection to reading paper. 
    All questions relating to the priority of business to be acted on by the council shall be decided without debate. When a reading of any paper is called for and the reading is objected to by any member, it shall be determined by a vote of the council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-58) 
Sec. 2-57. - Voting on nominations for office. 
    When a nomination for office shall be made by the mayor, the council shall proceed to vote thereon, but no nomination shall be ratified until it shall have been approved by a majority of the council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-59) 
Sec. 2-58. - Resignation of member. 
    Any member of the council may resign at any time by addressing the resignation in writing to the mayor, who shall lay the resignation before the council at the first meeting after he receives the resignation. The council shall accept the resignation by motion which shall be noted in the journal of the council proceedings. 
(Code 1980, § 2-60) 
Secs. 2-59-2-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ORDINANCES AND RESOLUTIONS 

Sec. 2-71. - Council to require city counselor to sign. 
    The city council may require the signature of the city counselor on any ordinance or resolution certifying they are correct as to form. Such requirement shall be made any time prior to the passage of any ordinance or resolution. 
(Code 1980, § 2-99(e); Ord. No. 1496-19, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-72. - Vote for passing resolution. 
    The vote required to pass a resolution shall be a majority of the members of the council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-101) 
Sec. 2-73. - Title of bill. 
    The title of every bill shall indicate the purpose and object sought to be accomplished thereby. 
(Code 1980, § 2-102) 
Secs. 2-74-2-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DEPARTMENTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-96. - Departmental organization. 
(a)  The administrative service of the city shall be divided under the director of administration. The city council may further create, reorganize, alter, abolish or discontinue any department so created not inconsistent with the Charter into the following departments and heads thereof: 
(1)  Legal department, city attorney, city counselor. 
(2)  Police department, police chief. 
(3)  Fire department, fire chief. 
(4)  Utility department, superintendent of utilities. 
(5)  Finance department, chief financial officer. 
(6)  Public works department, city engineer. 
(7)  Parks and recreation department, parks and recreation superintendent. 
(8)  Solid waste department, solid waste manager. 
(9)  Office of the city clerk, city clerk. 
(10)  Planning and code enforcement department, planning and code enforcement officer. 
(b)  The council shall annually, prior to the adoption of the city budget, review the organization chart and shall make any such revisions as may be required. 
(Code 1980, § 32-5) 
Sec. 2-97. - Administrative policy and procedures. 
(a)  Officials. Each official shall perform all duties required of his office by state law, the Charter, this chapter and other ordinances of the city and such other duties not in conflict therewith as may be required by the director of administration. 
(b)  Department heads. Each department head shall: 
(1)  Be responsible to director of administration. Be immediately responsible to the director of administration for the effective administration of his department and all activities assigned thereto. 
(2)  Inaugurate sound practices. Keep informed as to the latest practices in his particular field and shall inaugurate, with the approval of the director of administration, such new practices as appear to be of benefit to the service and to the public. 
(3)  Report to director of administration. Submit a monthly report of the activities of his department to the director of administration and such other reports as may be required by the director of administration. 
(4)  Maintain records. Establish and maintain a system of filing and indexing records and reports in sufficient detail to furnish all information necessary for proper control of departmental activities and to form a basis for the periodic reports to the director of administration. 
(5)  Have authority over employees. Have the power, when authorized by the director of administration, to appoint and remove, subject to personnel system regulations for personnel, all subordinates under him. 
(6)  Maintain equipment. Be responsible for the proper maintenance of all city property and equipment used in his department. 
(c)  Departments. Each department shall furnish, upon direction of the director of administration, any other department such service, labor and material as may be requisitioned by the head of such department and as its own facilities permit, through the same procedure and subject to the same audit and control as other expenditures are incurred. 
(d)  Operation of administrative service. The administrative service shall have the following duties: 
(1)  Office hours. Be open at such hours and on such days as shall be required by the director of administration. 
(2)  Deposits. Make such deposits of any monies received as directed by the director of administration. 
(3)  Payment of monies. Pay out monies belonging to the city only in the manner prescribed by the director of administration, city council or city ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 32-7) 
Sec. 2-98. - Requisitions and estimates. 
    Each city department or agency shall file with the director of administration detailed requisitions or estimates of the requirements in supplies and contractual services in such manner, at such times and for such future periods as the director of administration or designee shall prescribe. 
(Code 1980, § 2-240) 
Secs. 2-99-2-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FINANCE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Finance department created, § 6.1(d). 

Sec. 2-111. - Created. 
    As provided in the city Charter there is created a finance department. The finance department shall be responsible for the effective and efficient collection and disbursement of all city revenues. The department shall be supervised by a chief financial officer who shall be appointed by the director of administration with the consent of the mayor. 
(Code 1980, § 2-226) 
Sec. 2-112. - Duties of chief financial officer. 
    In all cases where the duty is not expressly charged to any other department or office, it shall be the duty of the chief financial officer to act to promote, secure and preserve the financial and property interests of the city. The chief financial officer shall have the following duties: 
(1)  Fiscal supervision. Exercise general supervision regarding the proper management of the fiscal concerns of the city. 
(2)  Report delinquent payments and financial reports. See that officers receiving money pay the money into the city treasury, when required, and that all necessary financial reports are made by officials and shall report all delinquents in such payments or reports to the director of administration and city council. 
(3)  Duty upon default of official. Report the default of any official of the city to the director of administration who shall direct the city counselor to take immediate legal measures for the recovery of the amount for which such official may be in default. 
(4)  Responsibility for proceeds of bonds. Deposit the proceeds of all sales of bonds in the city treasury immediately after he shall have received the proceeds, and, until such deposit, he shall be responsible for the amount thereof. 
(5)  Payments of money from special trust funds. Pay to the persons duly entitled thereto any money paid into the treasury pursuant to condemnation proceedings or for the redemption of property sold for taxes or arising from special assessments for public improvements, condemnation fund certificates and all special trust funds. 
(6)  Accounts of receipts and expenditures. Keep in proper books a full and accurate account of all the monies received and disbursed by him in behalf of the city, specifying the time of receipt and disbursement, from whom received and to whom disbursed and on what account received and disbursed and how paid. 
(7)  Receive and disburse monies. Receive and have custody of all monies paid to the city. 
(8)  Pay city employees. Pay city employees upon presentation of the properly certified payroll. 
(9)  Collect monies and fees due city. Demand and receive all monies and fees owing to the city whenever any person is indebted to the city in any manner and the means of collection of such debt is not otherwise provided for by law. When any claim shall not be collectable by other methods, he shall report such to the city counselor for prosecution. 
(10)  Audit accounts. Examine and audit the accounts of all officials and departments. 
(11)  Budget duties. Prepare an estimate of revenue and give such other assistance in the preparation of the budget as may be required of him by the director of administration. 
(12)  Financial statements. Transmit to the director of administration, when so directed, audited statements of cash on hand and of unencumbered appropriation balances for the city as a whole and such other financial statements as the director of administration may from time to time require. He shall keep all departments, boards, commissions or institutions currently informed of its unencumbered appropriation balances. 
(13)  Keep accounts. Keep all accounts of the city government and of the respective departments, offices, boards, commissions and institutions. 
(Code 1980, § 32-9) 
Secs. 2-113-2-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PUBLIC WORKS 

Sec. 2-126. - Established; purpose. 
    There is established for the city, in accordance with the city Charter, a public works department, the purpose of which is to provide for the control, construction and maintenance of the public works of the city, except those public works of the city classified as municipal utilities. 
(Code 1980, § 31-1) 
Sec. 2-127. - Composition. 
(a)  The public works department will consist of but not be limited to the following divisions: 
(1)  Engineering service; 
(2)  Street; 
(3)  Airport; and 
(4)  Cemetery. 
(b)  The director of administration, with the consent of the council, may from time to time include additional responsibilities or functions. 
(Code 1980, § 31-2) 
Sec. 2-128. - Compensation. 
    The salary of the personnel of the public works department shall be determined by the council. 
(Code 1980, § 31-3) 
Sec. 2-129. - Suspension, demotion or discharge of personnel. 
(a)  The city engineer may suspend, demote or discharge any personnel of the public works department for misbehavior, malfeasance or inefficiency. 
(b)  Any person so suspended, demoted or discharged for misbehavior, malfeasance or inefficiency may appeal such suspension, demotion or discharge through the grievance procedures established in the personnel manual. 
(Code 1980, § 31-4) 
Sec. 2-130. - City engineer. 
(a)  Generally. The director of administration, with the consent of the mayor, shall appoint a city engineer, who shall have supervisory responsibility for the operations of the public works department. 
(b)  Property. The city engineer shall have the power of control over the responsibility for all real estate and personal property placed under the jurisdiction of the street division, including, but not restricted to, the real estate and personal property used for and by the storage building, sheds and areas used for such purposes and the offices and rooms in the city hall now devoted to such uses. The council may, by resolution from time to time, include additional property or functions within the control and responsibility of the city engineer or remove any property or functions from him. Property shall only be sold or leased with the written approval of the council by resolution. All legal descriptions of real estate which are the subject of any transaction involving the city in any way shall be checked and approved by the city engineer in writing, addressed to the proper department head or city official. 
(Code 1980, § 31-5(a)) 
Sec. 2-131. - City engineer may use title of street commissioner. 
    The city engineer shall have the powers of and may use the title of street commissioner whenever called for by city or state law. 
(Code 1980, § 31-6) 
Sec. 2-132. - Duties and responsibilities of city engineer. 
(a)  The city engineer shall have supervisory responsibility for all personnel of the public works department. 
(b)  The city engineer shall make such rules and regulations as he deems necessary governing the relation of the various departments under his supervision with other departments and agencies of the city. 
(c)  Construction and maintenance work shall be conducted as necessary to the effective operation of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 31-7) 
Secs. 2-133-2-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-156. - Salaries. 
    The council shall fix by ordinance as far as practicable the compensation of all officers and regular employees of the city; provided, however, that the salary of an officer shall not be changed during the time for which he was elected, appointed or employed. 
(Code 1980, § 2-140) 
Sec. 2-157. - Qualifications. 
    All officers elected or appointed to offices under the city government shall be qualified voters under the law and constitution of the state and the ordinances of the city and, except the city sextons, must be residents of the city. No person shall be elected or appointed to any office and no person shall be employed or remain in the employment of the city who shall, at any time, be in arrears for any unpaid city taxes or forfeiture or defalcation in office. 
(Code 1980, § 2-141) 
Sec. 2-158. - Oath. 
    Every officer of the city and his assistants and every councilmember, before entering upon duties of his office, shall take and subscribe to an oath or affirmation before some court of record in the county or justice of the peace in the city, county or state or the city clerk or municipal judge that he possesses all the qualifications prescribed for his office by law; that he will support the Constitution of the United States and of the state, the provisions of all laws of the state affecting constitutional charter cities and the ordinances of the city and that he will faithfully demean himself in office, which official oath or affirmation shall be filed with the city clerk. If any person elected or appointed to any office shall fail to take and subscribe such oath or affirmation, his office shall be deemed vacant. 
(Code 1980, § 2-142) 
Sec. 2-159. - Certain officers authorized to administer oaths and affirmations. 
    The mayor or presiding officer, municipal judge and city clerk are authorized and empowered to administer oaths and affirmations in the following cases: 
(1)  The mayor or presiding officer of the city council to witnesses or other persons touching any subject under consideration by the council in which the interest of the city may be involved or in the conduct of the trial of any proceedings in which the city may be an interested party or any other elective or appointive officer to his official oath. 
(2)  The municipal judge to witnesses, jurors or other persons relating to any trial or other proceedings within the jurisdiction of his court or to any elective or appointive officer to his official oath. 
(3)  The city clerk to any person certifying to any demand or claim against the city, bearing on the correctness of the demand or claim, or to any witness or juror in any case wherein the city is or may be an interested party. 
(Code 1980, § 2-143) 
Sec. 2-160. - Official bonds. 
    Every officer of the city, when required by law or ordinance, shall, within 15 days after his election or appointment and before entering upon the discharge of his duties, give bond to the city in such sum and with such sureties as shall be designated by this Code or by city ordinance, conditioned on the faithful performance of his duty and that he will pay over all moneys belonging to the city, as provided by law, that may come into his hands. If any person elected or appointed to any office shall fail to give bond as required in this section, his office shall be deemed vacant. For any breach of condition of any such bond, suit may be instituted thereon by the city or by any person in the name of the city for use of such person. Should any officer of the city required to give bond be covered by a blanket bond to the same extent or more, an individual bond shall not be required. 
(Code 1980, § 2-144) 
Sec. 2-161. - Commission authorizing person to discharge duties of office. 
    After receiving certificates of election and upon the filing of the oath and bond provided for in sections 2-158 and 2-160, the city clerk shall deliver to the person elected or appointed a commission in due form, signed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk and under the seal of the city, authorizing and empowering such person to discharge the duties of the office therein named for the term for which he has been elected or appointed and until his successor shall have been duly elected or appointed. 
(Code 1980, § 2-145) 
Sec. 2-162. - Annual reports to council. 
    All officers of the city shall report annually to the council at the first regular monthly meeting thereof in August of each year. Such reports shall be made in writing and shall embrace a full and detailed statement of the receipts and shall embrace a full statement of the expenditures, if any, of their respective offices and all other matters and things necessary to a complete showing of all the public business done in their respective offices or under the supervision thereof. 
(Code 1980, § 2-147) 
Sec. 2-163. - Inspection of books, documents, vouchers by public. 
    All books, papers, records, documents and vouchers of a public character in the office of any city officer shall be open for the reasonable inspection of the public at all times during reasonable business hours. 
(Code 1980, § 2-148) 
Sec. 2-164. - Receipt for books, furniture and supplies; delivery of property to successor. 
    Upon taking his office, every city officer shall sign a receipt for all books, papers, records, furniture and fixtures and office supplies of all kinds coming to him with such office, such receipts being filed with the city clerk. Upon going out of office, the officer shall deliver the property, together with all of a similar character that shall accumulate during his term of office, to his successor or make good to the city any missing or damaged property. 
(Code 1980, § 2-149) 
Sec. 2-165. - Vacancy of office for certain changes in residence. 
    If any city officer shall leave the city with the intention of changing residence from the city, his office shall thereby be declared vacant. If any councilmember shall move from the ward from which he was elected, his office shall be declared vacant and his successor named according to the provisions made for the election of officers. 
(Code 1980, § 2-151) 
Sec. 2-166. - Appointive offices-Vacancy in office. 
    If a vacancy occurs in any nonelective office as to which the mayor has the power of appointment with the consent of the council, the mayor shall appoint a suitable person to discharge the duties of the office until the first regular meeting of the council thereafter, at which time such vacancy shall be permanently filled in the manner provided by ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 2-152) 
Sec. 2-167. - Same-Time of appointment; majority consent of council for certain appointments. 
    The several city offices not made elective by the state law shall be filled by proper appointment, according to law and ordinance, not later than 30 days after the organization of the council in April in each year. The consent of a majority of the members elected to the city council shall be necessary to a confirmation of any appointment wherein the approval of the council is required. 
(Code 1980, § 2-153) 
Sec. 2-168. - Resignations. 
    Any officer or person desiring to resign his office or employment under the city government shall do so in writing. The written resignation shall be directed to the department head or to the mayor and receipt received for its delivery. Upon receipt of any resignation, the department head or the mayor shall immediately take action thereon, and no office or position shall be deemed vacant until such resignation has been duly accepted by the department head or the mayor. 
(Code 1980, § 2-154) 
Sec. 2-169. - Workers' compensation-Start of benefits. 
    Workers' compensation benefits shall begin as provided by statute. 
(Code 1980, § 2-160) 
Sec. 2-170. - Same-Payment of sick leave prior to receiving benefits; pay while drawing compensation. 
(a)  Regular sick leave shall be paid until workers' compensation benefits shall begin, except that sick leave shall not be paid in excess of that to which the employee is entitled. 
(b)  While receiving workers' compensation the employee shall receive from the city an amount equal to the difference between the regular rate of pay being earned at the time of the accident and the amount of workers' compensation being paid to the employee. 
(Code 1980, § 2-161) 
Sec. 2-171. - Participation in retirement system. 
(a)  The city is a political subdivision as defined in RSMo 70.600-70.760 and elects to have covered by the state local government employees retirement system all of its eligible employees in the following classes: 
(1)  Present and future general employees. 
(2)  Present and future police officers. 
(3)  Present and future firefighters. 
(b)  The city elects that 100 percent of prior employment be considered for prior service credit in computing benefits and contributions to the system. 
(c)  The city clerk is authorized and directed to deduct from the wages and salaries of each employee member the member contributions required by RSMo 70.705 and to promptly remit the deductions to the retirement system together with the employer contributions required by RSMo 70.730. 
(Code 1980, § 2-162) 
Sec. 2-172. - Election of benefit program in state retirement system. 
    The city elects benefit program L-3 in accordance with RSMo 70.655. Such election shall be effective on July 1, 1978. 
(Code 1980, § 2-163) 
Sec. 2-173. - Matters not covered by article. 
    Matters relating to officers and employees not covered in this article or elsewhere in this Code shall be as provided in the personnel manual. 
(Code 1980, § 2-164) 
Sec. 2-174. - City engineer. 
(a)  Duties generally. The city engineer shall be responsible for all matters relating to community planning, zoning and development; and the construction, management, maintenance and operation of the city's physical properties. 
(b)  Duties for public works. The city engineer shall perform all engineering services for the department of public works and for such other departments of the city as may from time to time require such services. 
(c)  Duties for street division. For the street division the city engineer shall direct the repair, maintenance and uses of all city streets. 
(Code 1980, § 32-11) 
Sec. 2-175. - Conflicts in private business transactions. 
    No city officer or employee shall enter into any private business transaction with any person who or entity that has a matter pending upon which the officer or employee is or will be called upon to render a decision or pass judgment. If any officer or employee is already engaged in the business transaction, at the time that matter arises, he shall be disqualified from rendering any decision or passing any judgment upon the business. 
(Code 1980, § 2-241) 
Sec. 2-176. - Gifts and rebates. 
    Every city officer and employee is expressly prohibited from accepting, directly or indirectly, from any person from whom any purchase or contract is or might be awarded any rebate, gift, money or anything of value whatsoever, except where given for the use and benefit of the city. Violation of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-20. 
(Code 1980, § 2-242) 
Secs. 2-177-2-185. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MAYOR[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Charter reference- Mayor, §§ 4.1-4.6. 

Sec. 2-186. - Appointment of certain officers and employees. 
    The mayor, with the consent and approval of a majority of the council, shall have the power to appoint all officers of the city whose election or appointment is not otherwise provided for by the Charter. 
(Code 1980, § 2-179) 
Sec. 2-187. - Deputy mayor's duties in temporary absence or disability of mayor. 
    Should the mayor be absent or unable to perform the duties of his office for a period of 30 days or more, the deputy mayor shall have all the powers and perform all the duties of the office until the mayor shall return and shall receive the same compensation as the mayor. 
(Code 1980, § 2-180) 
Secs. 2-188-2-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DIRECTOR OF ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 2-201. - Functions. 
    The director of administration shall be the chief operating officer of the city government, shall enforce the laws of the city and require the faithful performance of all administrative duties. He may serve as the head of any department other than the legal department. 
(Code 1980, § 32-3(A)) 
Sec. 2-202. - Powers and duties. 
    The director of administration shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Appointments, dismissals, suspensions and disciplinary actions. With the advice and consent of the mayor, appoint all department heads, except the city counselor and city attorney. He shall appoint competent, qualified officers and employees to the administrative service and shall have the power to dismiss, suspend and discipline, in accordance with the personnel code, all officers and employees in the administrative service under his control. He shall also have the power to authorize a department head or officer responsible to him to appoint and remove subordinates serving under that department head or officer. 
(2)  Administration. Be responsible for the day-to-day administrative activities of the city. He shall also serve as the professional staff resource to the mayor and the city council in matters concerning the proposal and development of public policy and shall, as a matter of procedure, bring all such public policy proposals and suggestions first to the mayor for discussion and the mayor shall transmit to the city council. 
(3)  Appoint to acting capacity. Designate himself or some other officer or employee to perform the duties of any office or position in the administrative service under his control which is vacant or which lacks administration due to the absence or disability of the incumbent. 
(4)  Annual report. Prepare and present to the mayor for review, amendment and transmittal to the city council an annual report and such other reports as the mayor and council shall require. 
(5)  Budget report. Assemble estimates of the financial needs and resources for the city each ensuing year, prepare a program of activities within the financial power of the city and prepare and submit to the mayor a recommended annual budget and three-year capital program for mayoral review, amendment and transmittal to the city council. 
(6)  Assign according to classification. Have the power to assign any employee of the city to any department or branch thereof requiring services appropriate to the personnel code classification of the employee so assigned. 
(7)  Prescribe rules. Have the power to prescribe such rules and regulations as he shall deem necessary or expedient for the conduct of administrative agencies subject to his authority and have the power to revoke, suspend or amend any rule or regulation of the administrative service so prescribed by himself or subordinates. 
(8)  Investigations. Have the power, either by himself or by an officer or person designated for the purpose by him, to investigate and to examine or inquire into the affairs or operation of any department, division, bureau or office and, when so authorized by the city council, have the power to employ consultants and professional counsel to aid in such investigations, examinations or inquiries. 
(9)  Overrule officials. Have the power to set aside any action taken by a department head, except the city attorney and city counselor, and may supersede the department head in the functions of his office. 
(10)  Delegate duties. Have the power to direct any department, division or bureau to perform the work for any other department, division or bureau. 
(11)  Attendance at council meetings. Attend council meetings and have the right to take part in discussion, but may not vote. He shall receive notice of all meetings. 
(12)  Other duties. Perform such other duties as are specified in the Charter or may be required by the mayor from time to time. 
(Code 1980, § 32-3(B)) 
Secs. 2-203-2-215. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CITY ATTORNEY AND CITY COUNSELOR[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 653-93, § A, adopted Oct. 12, 1993, repealed §§ 2-213-2-221 of the city's 1980 Code, codified herein as §§ 2-216-2-223, and § B of the ordinance added similar new provisions to read as herein set out. 
Charter reference- City attorney, §§ 7.1-7.4; city counselor, § 7.5. 

Sec. 2-216. - City attorney-Selection. 
    At the first election following the adoption of the City Charter and biannually thereafter, the qualified voters of the city shall elect a city attorney, who shall hold office for two years and until his/her successor is elected and qualified. 
(Ord. No. 653-93, § B, 10-12-93) 
Sec. 2-217. - Same-Qualifications. 
(a)  The city attorney shall be a qualified voter of the city, licensed to practice law in this state, and a resident of the city at least six months and of the state one year next prior to his election. 
(b)  Should there be no qualified person filing for such office, the mayor, with the advice and consent of the council, is authorized to employ a city attorney on such terms as shall be established by ordinance. In such case, the city attorney shall not be required to be a resident of the city. 
(Ord. No. 653-93, § B, 10-12-93) 
Sec. 2-218. - Same-Duties. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the city attorney to prosecute all persons charged with violations of the ordinances of the city. 
(b)  When any complaint has been filed, it shall be the duty of the city attorney to prepare and file with the associate judge of the 13th judicial circuit a statement of information in proper form. 
(c)  When an affidavit is required on behalf of the city in any cause pending in the municipal court, it shall be made by the city attorney or, in case of the city attorney's inability, by some other person with knowledge of the facts. 
(d)  All cases filed shall be filed in the division of the associate judge of the 13th judicial circuit, as may be assigned by the presiding judge of the circuit. 
(e)  It shall be the duty of the city attorney to review, as to form, all ordinances passed by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 653-93, § B, 10-12-93) 
Sec. 2-219. - City counselor-Selection. 
    The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, may appoint a city counselor, whose tenure shall be determined on an as-needed basis. The city counselor may be an individual or law firm, licensed to practice in this state. Residency is not a requirement for the appointment of an individual or law firm as city counselor. 
(Ord. No. 653-93, § B, 10-12-93) 
Sec. 2-220. - Same-Term of office. 
    The city counselor shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 653-93, § B, 10-12-93) 
Sec. 2-221. - Same-Duties. 
    The city counselor shall give legal advice and handle all legal issues assigned by the mayor or, with the advice and consent of the mayor, by the director of administration. 
(Ord. No. 653-93, § B, 10-12-93) 
Sec. 2-222. - Compensation. 
(a)  City attorney. The compensation of the elected city attorney shall be a sum per month as established by the city council from time to time. 
(b)  City counselor. The compensation of the appointed city counselor (if any) shall be established by agreement between the appointing authority and the attorney or law firm involved at a specific rate per hour, which agreement shall be reported from time to time by the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 653-93, § B, 10-12-93; Ord. No. 663-94, § 1, 1-26-94) 
Sec. 2-223. - Filling temporary vacancy in office of city attorney. 
    In case of sickness, absence from the city or other temporary disability or inability of the city attorney to perform the duties of his office, then the mayor shall appoint some competent attorney to act as city attorney pending such temporary disability. The person so appointed shall possess the same power and receive the same compensation as the city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 653-93, § B, 10-12-93) 
Secs. 2-224-2-235. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CITY CLERK[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Charter reference- City clerk, § 6.2. 

Sec. 2-236. - Office created. 
    The office of city clerk is created. 
(Code 1980, § 2-193) 
Sec. 2-237. - Duties. 
    The city clerk shall: 
(1)  Serve as clerk of the city council and perform such other duties of a like nature as shall be specified by law. 
(2)  Be responsible for the recording, filing, indexing and safekeeping of all proceedings of the city council. 
(3)  Record in full, uniformly and permanently, all ordinances and authenticate the ordinances. 
(4)  Publish all adopted ordinances and resolutions of the city council, as required, and all legal notices required by law or ordinance. 
(5)  Notify the appointing authority of the impending expiration of the term of office of a member of any board or commission, such notice to be given at least 30 days before such expiration. 
(6)  Be the custodian of the official seal of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 32-4) 
Sec. 2-238. - Assistant. 
    The director of administration shall appoint an assistant city clerk, upon the recommendation of the city clerk and with the advice and consent of the mayor and the council. The assistant clerk shall perform the duties of the city clerk in the city clerk's absence, and the service rendered shall be in the name of and for the clerk. 
(Code 1980, § 2-197) 
Sec. 2-239. - Temporary clerk. 
    Whenever for any reason the city clerk is unable in person or by an assistant to perform the duties of the office, the director of administration may appoint a temporary clerk, who shall have all the powers and perform all the duties of the regular clerk. 
(Code 1980, § 2-198) 
Secs. 2-240-2-250. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - PLANNING AND CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- General penalty for Code violations, § 1-20. 

Sec. 2-251. - Position created, appointment, similar titles. 
(a)  The position of planning and code enforcement officer is created. 
(b)  The planning and code enforcement officer shall be appointed by the director of administration with the consent of the mayor and shall serve at the pleasure of the city engineer and the director of administration. 
(c)  Any reference to the titles of code official, building inspector or health officer or health authority within this Code or any other code adopted by the city shall be construed to mean the planning and code enforcement officer or his designee. 
(Code 1980, § 6-10) 
Sec. 2-252. - Duties. 
    The planning and code enforcement officer shall be responsible for the issuance of all permits and inspections involved in community planning, zoning and development and the construction of sewer and water services, sidewalks, curb cuts, street cuts and buildings. The planning and code enforcement officer shall review all building plans and construction thereof under the provisions of the electrical, plumbing and building codes of the city and inspect all premises, including structures and appurtenances thereon, for safety features. 
(Code 1980, § 32-12) 
Secs. 2-253-2-265. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - OFFENSES AND IMPEACHMENT 

Sec. 2-266. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Officer means any elected official or anyone appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-263) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-267. - Voting for illegal claim or demand. 
    Any member of the council or officer who shall knowingly or willfully or corruptly vote for or assent to or report in favor of or allow or certify for allowance any claim or demand against the city, which claim or demand shall be on account of a contract or agreement not authorized by law and the ordinances of the city, shall be subject and liable to removal from office for cause. 
(Code 1980, § 2-264) 
Sec. 2-268. - Interest in city contracts. 
    Any city officer or employee who has a substantial financial interest, direct or indirect, or because of ownership of stock in any corporation, in any contract with the city, or in the sale of any land, material, supplies or services to the city or to a contractor supplying the city shall make known that interest and shall refrain from voting upon or otherwise participating in his capacity as a city officer or employee in the making of such sale or in the making or performance of such contract. Any city officer or employee who willfully conceals such a substantial financial interest or willfully violates this section shall be guilty of malfeasance in office or position and shall forfeit his office or position. Violation of this section with the knowledge, express or implied, of the person or corporation contracting with or making a sale to the city shall render the contract or sale voidable by the mayor or the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-265) 
Sec. 2-269. - Receiving reward for improper services. 
    Every city officer who shall, directly or indirectly, accept or receive any fee, consideration, gratuity or reward or act on any promise to receive any such compensation in connection with any city activity under the control and influence of any officer in his official capacity, by either omission or neglect, or showing partiality or favor in any responsibility or act for which he has the obligation and ability to control, contrary to law or ordinance, shall be subject to removal for cause. 
(Code 1980, § 2-266) 
Sec. 2-270. - Receiving reward for procuring appointments. 
    Every city officer who shall, directly or indirectly, accept or receive of another any sum of money or other valuable consideration, gratuity or reward or any promise or security thereof: 
(1)  Upon any agreement to give or procure the officer's interest or influence or other means; any appointment, office or place of trust or any preferment or emolument; or to aid or assist in procuring such for any other person; or 
(2)  In consideration of any office or appointment, place or preferment or emolument of any act, interest or influence aid or assistance by any means in procuring or attempting to procure any such preferment or emolument, appointment, office or place of trust; 
shall be subject and liable to removal from office for cause. 
(Code 1980, § 2-267) 
Sec. 2-271. - Procuring office by improper means.
