    Every city officer who shall have taken, accepted, received or obtained, directly or indirectly, his office, appointment, place of trust, preferment or emolument by the act, influence, aid or assistance of another upon any agreement or consideration mentioned in sections 2-269 and 2-270 shall be subject and liable to removal from office for cause. 
(Code 1980, § 2-268) 
Sec. 2-272. - Willful misconduct, malicious conduct, abuse of authority. 
    Every city officer who shall be guilty of willful misconduct or abuse of authority or willful and malicious oppressive partiality in his official capacity or under color of his office shall be subject and liable to removal from office for cause. As used in this section, the term "willful misconduct" means either nonfeasance, misfeasance or malfeasance in office. 
(Code 1980, § 2-269) 
Sec. 2-273. - Removal of appointive officers. 
(a)  The mayor may, with the majority vote of all the members of the council, remove from office any appointive city officer at will, and any such appointive officer may be so removed by six votes of the council, independently of the mayor's approval or recommendation. 
(b)  No formalities whatever shall be necessary for the removal of any appointive city officer further than the necessary vote therefor by the city council, with or without the mayor's approval, as the case may demand under the law and this division. 
(Code 1980, § 2-270) 
Sec. 2-274. - Suspension of officer. 
    Whenever an impeachment proceeding shall be started or commenced against any city officer and as soon as the complaint has been filed with the city clerk or mayor, the mayor, with the consent of the majority of the council, may suspend such officer, if they think it to be for the best interest of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 2-271) 
Sec. 2-275. - Impeached officer filling vacancy. 
    Any city officer who shall be impeached and removed from office in accordance with this division shall not be eligible for election or appointment to fill the vacancy created by removal, but such vacancy shall be filled in other respects as other vacancies are filled. 
(Code 1980, § 2-272) 
Sec. 2-276. - Removal of officer by mayor. 
    The mayor may, with the majority vote of all the members of the city council, remove from office for cause shown any city officer. Such officer being first given opportunity, together with witnesses, shall be heard before the council sitting as a court of impeachment. 
(Code 1980, § 2-273) 
Sec. 2-277. - Removal of officer by council. 
    Any officer, including the mayor, may, in the manner prescribed in section 2-276, for cause shown, be removed from office by six votes of the city council, independently of the mayor's approval or recommendation. 
(Code 1980, § 2-274) 
Sec. 2-278. - Complaint-Procedures. 
    In the impeachment and removal of any officer of the city from office, it shall be necessary that the charges be set out in writing in sufficient fullness to correctly advise the officer of the nature and character of the complaint, sworn and subscribed to by the person making the complaint before some person authorized by the laws of the state to administer oaths. Such complaint shall be filed with the city clerk or with the mayor and shall be laid before the city council by such officer without delay. 
(Code 1980, § 2-275) 
Sec. 2-279. - Same-Bond may be required of person making complaint. 
    Before ordering the issuing of summons as provided in section 2-280, the city council may order the person making the complaint in the case to give a bond to the city with proper security in a sum sufficient to cover the costs and expenses of the investigation, and, unless such bond is given, the charges may be disregarded by the council or the council may proceed with the investigation without any security for costs. The expenses of the investigation may be paid by the city. 
(Code 1980, § 2-276) 
Sec. 2-280. - Same-Hearing. 
    If the council desires to proceed with an investigation after the filing of a complaint pursuant to section 2-278, or if the city officer against whom the charges are directed demands an investigation, the council shall, by order entered of record, fix a time and place for the hearing of the matter and shall direct the city clerk to issue a notice under the clerk's hand and seal of the city, directed to the defendant in the complaint and stating the time when and the place where the proceedings of the investigation will be held. Such notice, together with a true copy of the charges filed made out by the city clerk attached thereto, shall be served by the chief of police or any police officer upon the city officer named as the defendant in the complaint. The manner of service shall be the same as provided by the laws of the state for the service of summons in civil courts. 
(Code 1980, § 2-277) 
Sec. 2-281. - Same-Determination of date of investigation. 
    The date fixed by the council for an investigation of any complaint filed pursuant to section 2-278 shall be such as to give the city officer against whom the charges are made opportunity to secure attendance of witnesses and otherwise prepare for trial in a reasonable manner. 
(Code 1980, § 2-278) 
Sec. 2-282. - Fees of officers serving in investigation. 
    The several officers rendering services in any investigation pursuant to this division shall be entitled to and shall receive the same fees as are or may be given by state law of officers performing similar services in courts of record in the state. 
(Code 1980, § 2-279) 
Sec. 2-283. - Subpoenas for witnesses. 
    The city clerk shall issue proper subpoenas for witnesses upon the application of a complaint under this division or the defendant, and such subpoenas may be served by the chief of police or any police officer. 
(Code 1980, § 2-280) 
Sec. 2-284. - Council to sit as court of impeachment. 
    The trial and proceedings under this division shall be had and held before the city council, sitting as court of impeachment, and the proceeding shall be the same, as far as applicable, as prescribed by law for the trial of civil cases in courts of record in the state. 
(Code 1980, § 2-281) 
Sec. 2-285. - Presiding officer. 
    In all impeachment proceedings before the council pursuant to this division, the mayor or person exercising the office of mayor shall preside. If the mayor or any councilmember shall be the person against whom the complaint is filed, such mayor or councilmember shall not preside over or vote in the impeachment proceedings. 
(Code 1980, § 2-282) 
Sec. 2-286. - Oaths. 
    At the time and place appointed for a trial under this division and before proceeding therewith, the mayor or, if the mayor is accused, the deputy mayor of the council, shall administer to the members of the council present and the presiding judge shall at the time administer to the mayor or, if the mayor is accused, to the deputy mayor of the council, an oath or affirmation impartially to try to determine the charges and do justice according to law and the evidence. The officer presiding at the trial shall administer the usual oath to all witnesses. 
(Code 1980, § 2-283) 
Sec. 2-287. - Public trial; record of proceedings. 
    All trials under this division shall be public, and the council shall cause the city clerk to keep a full and accurate record of the proceedings in the journal of the council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-284) 
Sec. 2-288. - Accused entitled to counsel. 
    Upon any trial held pursuant to this division, the accused shall be entitled to be heard by himself and his counsel in his defense. 
(Code 1980, § 2-285) 
Sec. 2-289. - Duty of counselor; procedure when counselor accused. 
    Pursuant to this division, the city counselor shall conduct and prosecute all trials on behalf of the city for the removal of any city officer. If the city counselor is the accused, the city attorney shall act in the city counselor's stead during the trial proceedings. 
(Code 1980, § 2-286) 
Sec. 2-290. - Vote on question of guilt; roll call and votes to be recorded. 
    Upon the completion of any trial held pursuant to this division, the clerk shall call the roll upon the questions of the defendant's guilt or innocence under the complaint or under each separate qualification contained in the complaint if there are more than one such specifications, and the members of the council shall vote guilty or not guilty upon the complaint or upon each such specification. The roll call and votes shall be made a part of the record of the clerk. 
(Code 1980, § 2-287) 
Secs. 2-291-2-300. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - PERSONNEL RULES 

Sec. 2-301. - Employees at will. 
    All employees of the city are employees at will, serving at the pleasure of the mayor and city council of the city, but subject to certain administrative protections as hereinafter set forth. These administrative procedures do not change the character of employment by the city from that of employees at will. 
(Ord. No. 649-93, §§ I, II, 8-24-93) 
Sec. 2-302. - Rules to be promulgated. 
    The director of administration shall, from time to time, promulgate personnel rules and regulations which shall be published and distributed to city employees. It shall be the responsibility of each employee to be familiar with the rules and regulations and to obey the same. 
(Ord. No. 649-93, §§ I, II, 8-24-93) 
Sec. 2-303. - Discipline imposed. 
    Discipline under the published personnel rules may be imposed by an employee's department head. Discipline shall be, to the extent possible, progressive in nature and shall be intended to correct an employee's behavior if required, rather than to be punitive in nature. Such discipline will be imposed in accordance with the published personnel rules and regulations. Notwithstanding the desire that discipline be progressive in nature, and that employees' behavior be improved rather than having employees replaced, it may be necessary from time to time that employees be terminated from municipal service. Such personnel actions shall be based upon guidelines established by the director of administration. 
(Ord. No. 649-93, §§ I, II, 8-24-93) 
Secs. 2-304-2-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - REVIEW OF PERSONNEL ACTIONS 

Sec. 2-311. - Generally. 
(a)  Any employee who is aggrieved by any personnel action shall have the privilege, within seven days of such personnel action, to request a meeting with and discussion of that personnel action with the director of administration. Such meeting and discussion with the director of administration shall occur within seven days of the request. The director of administration shall have the discretion to suspend the personnel action, to leave it in place, or to modify that action as shall seem appropriate. 
(b)  Following the meeting with the director of administration, if the employee is still aggrieved by the personnel action, the employee shall have the privilege, within five days, of having a meeting and discussion with the city's personnel advisory board, as established herein. The meeting of the personnel advisory board shall not be considered a "hearing" as the term is used in the State Administrative Procedures Act but shall be a meeting and discussion separate from the State Administrative Procedures Act procedures. The purpose of this meeting and discussion is to provide guidance in the internal operations of the city, to ensure an even application of discipline, but shall not be construed to provide any rights of further redress in the court system of the state or federal government. 
(Ord. No. 649-93, §§ I, II, 8-24-93) 
Sec. 2-312. - Personnel advisory board-Membership. 
    The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, shall appoint a personnel advisory board consisting of seven persons who shall hold office for a term of three years. The members of the personnel advisory board shall have staggered terms, two or three members' terms ending on the last day of June of each year. Upon the establishment of the personnel advisory board, the existing six-member personnel board shall continue to hold office until the expiration of their terms, and a seventh member shall be appointed to have a three-year term. 
(Ord. No. 649-93, §§ I, II, 8-24-93) 
Sec. 2-313. - Same-Procedures. 
    Upon the timely receipt of any request for a meeting and discussion regarding any adverse personnel action, the personnel advisory board shall schedule a closed meeting in which this matter will be addressed. The meeting will be scheduled at the convenience of the parties but, whenever possible, within ten days of the request. At such meeting, the following procedures will be observed: 
(1)  The director of administration shall first present an explanation of the reasons for the personnel action. The city counselor shall represent the director of administration and may present whatever witnesses seem appropriate. 
(2)  The employee, or the employee's legal representative, shall be entitled to cross-examine these witnesses. 
(3)  At the conclusion of the presentation of all evidence for the director of administration, the employee shall be permitted to present whatever evidence the employee desires. The director of administration shall have the right to cross-examine such witnesses. 
(4)  The rules of evidence shall not apply to this procedure, and it is especially understood that hearsay evidence and documentary evidence may be received when offered by either party. 
(5)  When it appears necessary in order to be fair to the parties, the personnel advisory board may continue the meeting to permit inquiry and may permit the use of rebuttal evidence as seems appropriate. 
(6)  Proceedings at this meeting shall be transcribed, but such transcription shall remain a closed record of the city available only to the employee and his representative and to the city and its representatives except as otherwise provided by law. 
(7)  The personnel advisory board shall consider, at this meeting, the following question: 
"Does cause exist for the discipline of this employee?" 
and shall answer to that question either in the affirmative or the negative. 
(8)  The personnel advisory board may make recommendations as to the appropriate level of discipline that should be imposed if cause for such discipline is found, but that recommendation shall not be binding upon the director of administration. 
(9)  The decision of the personnel advisory board shall be prepared in writing regarding the answer to the questions as to whether cause for discipline exists, as well as any recommendation that the personnel advisory board may choose to provide. This written decision regarding the cause for discipline and the recommendation shall be publicly disclosed immediately after the employee has been notified of such decision or within 72 hours of the decision, whichever occurs first. 
(10)  The decision of the personnel advisory board, if it is not implemented by the director of administration, shall be reported to the city council together with the director of administration's reasons for refusing to impose the decision or recommendation. 
(Ord. No. 649-93, §§ I, II, 8-24-93) 
Sec. 2-314. - Claims regarding discriminatory treatment. 
    The personnel advisory board is specifically authorized to inquire into claims of alleged discriminatory treatment by the city and, for that purpose, may inquire into the treatment afforded to other employees of the city in the same or similar circumstance as the aggrieved employee who brings the matter before it. Any employee who has a claim of discriminatory or unequal treatment in violation of the laws of the United States or the state is expected to bring that complaint first to the personnel advisory board, although it is recognized that such employee is not legally required to do so. In addition, the personnel advisory board is entitled to consider claims of unfair or discriminatory treatment based upon categories, factors or characteristics that are not protected under state or federal law. 
(Ord. No. 649-93, §§ I, II, 8-24-93) 
Sec. 2-315. - Exception to personnel advisory board procedures. 
    Employees who test positive in the city's random drug testing program, and who thereafter fail to conform to the city's direction regarding rehabilitation and treatment by refusing or declining to participate in any rehabilitation program established by the director of administration, shall be immediately terminated, unless the director of administration shall order otherwise. Employees terminated for failing to participate in a drug rehabilitation program, or failing to successfully complete it in satisfactory manner, shall have no right to have that termination considered and discussed by the personnel advisory board. 
(Ord. No. 649-93, §§ I, II, 8-24-93) 
Secs. 2-316-2-320. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-321. - Creation. 
    The administrative service of the city shall include at a minimum the boards and commissions provided for in section 2-323, in compliance with the city Charter and the ordinances of the city. The boards and commissions shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 32-17(A)) 
Sec. 2-322. - Membership. 
    The boards and commissions created in section 2-323 shall be composed of the number of members and for the terms of office designated by ordinance creating such board or commission. 
(Code 1980, § 32-17(B)) 
Sec. 2-323. - Titles; other boards and commissions; ex officio members. 
(a)  The names of city boards and commissions are as follows: 
(1)  Planning and zoning commission. 
(2)  Commission on human rights and community relations. 
(3)  Personnel board. 
(4)  Board of public utilities. 
(5)  Parks and recreation board. 
(6)  Board of adjustment. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the authority of the mayor and city council to appoint such other committees, boards or commissions from time to time as may be necessary to the effective operation of the city, provided that such committees, boards and commissions are not inconsistent with the Charter. 
(c)  The mayor and the director of administration shall serve as ex officio members of all committees, commissions and boards, without a vote, unless otherwise prohibited by law. 
(Code 1980, § 32-17(C)) 
Secs. 2-324-2-335. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERSONNEL BOARD 

Sec. 2-336. - Established; purpose; appointment, composition and qualifications of members. 
(a)  There is established a personnel board to oversee the development of sound personnel practices which provide for impartial and nondiscriminatory standards for all employees of the city. 
(b)  The personnel board shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the council and shall consist of six members selected from the citizens of the city. Citizens appointed to the personnel board shall be qualified voters and shall have resided in the city at least one year. They shall hold no city office nor shall they be employees of the city government during their terms. 
(Code 1980, § 2-401) 
Sec. 2-337. - Terms of members; removal from office. 
(a)  The members of the personnel board shall hold office for three years from July 1 following their appointment. Annually, the mayor shall before July 1 of each year appoint two members who shall hold office for three years and until their successors are appointed. 
(b)  Upon the recommendation of the mayor, a member of the personnel board may be removed by a vote of five members of the city council. A member may also be removed by six votes of the city council independently of the mayor's approval or recommendation. 
(c)  Any member who fails to attend three consecutive regular meetings without being formally excused by the board shall forfeit his membership. 
(Code 1980, § 2-402) 
Sec. 2-338. - Officers. 
(a)  Annually, the personnel board shall elect one of its members as chairman and one as vice-chairman. 
(b)  The city clerk or a person designated by the director of administration shall be the recording secretary and keep a record of all actions taken at the meeting. A copy of the minutes of every meeting of the personnel board shall be delivered to the city council. All regular meetings shall become public record, except as otherwise provided by law. 
(Code 1980, § 2-403) 
Sec. 2-339. - Meetings. 
    The personnel board shall meet upon the call of the director of administration. 
(Code 1980, § 2-404) 
Sec. 2-340. - Duties and responsibilities. 
(a)  Members of the personnel board shall in their deliberations consider the best interests of effective and efficient services to the public, as well as consistent, equitable application of rules, policies, procedures and regulations. 
(b)  The board shall hear appeals from corrective or disciplinary actions against city employees which might result in disciplinary demotion, suspension or dismissal of an individual. 
(Code 1980, § 2-405) 
Secs. 2-341-2-360. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FINANCES, PURCHASING AND BID PROCEDURES 

Sec. 2-361. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal year of the city shall commence on the first day of January and terminate on the thirty-first day of December of each year, and the books, accounts and reports of all officers shall be made to conform thereto. 
(Code 1980, § 2-7; Ord. No. 718-96, § 2, 6-25-96) 
Charter reference- Council to establish fiscal year by ordinance, § 8.1. 
Sec. 2-362. - Competitive bidding. 
    When the city negotiates any purchase, sale or other contract, there shall be provided ample opportunity for competitive bidding in the following manner: 
(1)  If the consideration is $500.00 or less, these items shall be exempt from the bid procedure but purchased with due regard for competitive prices and quality. 
(2)  If the consideration is for more than $500.00 but not more than $2,000.00, at least three bids shall be solicited by mail or telephone request from at least three prospective vendors, from which the lowest bid, with proper qualifications, shall be accepted. A record of the quotations shall be maintained, as directed. 
(3)  If the consideration is for more than $2,000.00 but less than $5,000.00, three written bids shall be solicited from which the lowest bid, with proper qualifications, shall be accepted. 
(4)  All supplies and contractual services estimated to cost $5,000.00 or more shall be purchased by formal, written contract from the lowest responsible bidder, after due notice inviting proposals. Whenever possible, at least three bids should be obtained from prospective, qualified vendors. 
(5)  Individual contracts, purchases or sales, be they for goods, supplies, commodities or services, shall not be excluded from the requirement of competitive bidding described in this section. 
(6)  Individual contracts or purchases shall not be subdivided for the purpose of evading the requirement of competitive bidding. 
(7)  A list of items to be exempted from competitive bidding shall be made a part of the annual budget and reviewed at least annually. Reasons for exemption shall be set out in writing and made a part of the budget. Such reasons shall be limited to price volatility or limited supply or available source. 
(8)  Professional service shall be selected on the basis of a policy set out in detail in the administrative manual. 
(9)  Purchases up to $500.00 shall be approved by the department head. Purchases of more than $500.00 but less than $1,000.00 shall be approved by the department head and the chief financial officer. Purchases of $1,000.00 or more shall be approved by the director of administration or the mayor. 
(Code 1980, § 2-243; Ord. No. 621-92, § 1, 8-25-92) 
Sec. 2-363. - Bid notice procedure. 
    The notice required by section 2-362 shall consist of the following: 
(1)  Notice inviting bids shall be published in at least one newspaper of the city at least seven working days preceding the last day set for the receipt of the proposals. The newspaper notice shall include a general description of the articles to be purchased or sold, shall state where bid blanks and specifications may be secured and shall give the time and place for opening bids. 
(2)  The city clerk shall also solicit sealed bids from all responsible prospective suppliers who have requested their names be added to a bidders' list, which the city clerk or designee shall maintain, by sending them a copy of such newspaper notice or such other notice as will acquaint them with the proposed purchase or sale. In any case, invitations sent to the vendors on the bidder's list shall be limited to commodities that are similar in character and ordinarily handled by the trade group to which the invitations are sent. 
(Code 1980, § 2-244) 
Sec. 2-364. - Bid opening procedure. 
    Bids shall be submitted sealed to the city clerk and shall be identified as bids on the envelope. They shall be opened in public and read aloud at the time and place stated in the public notice with at least two persons present at the opening. The city clerk shall send each bidder a copy of the bid tabulation and shall also furnish the bid tabulation to any requesting party. 
(Code 1980, § 2-245) 
Sec. 2-365. - Rejection of bids; award to lowest and best responsible bidder. 
    The city reserves the right to reject any or all bids. Contracts shall be awarded to the lowest and best responsible bidder. Bids shall not be accepted from nor contracts awarded to a vendor who is in default on the payment of taxes, licenses or other monies due the city. In determining the lowest and best responsible bidder, in addition to price, the following shall be considered: 
(1)  The ability, capacity and skill of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service required. 
(2)  Whether the bidder can perform the contract or provide the service promptly or within the time specified, without delay or interference. 
(3)  The integrity, reputation, judgment, experience and efficiency of the bidder. 
(4)  The quality of performance of previous contracts or services. 
(5)  The compliance by the bidder with laws and ordinances relating to the contract or service. 
(6)  The sufficiency of the financial resources and ability of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service. 
(7)  The quality, availability and adaptability of the supplies or contractual services to the particular use required. 
(8)  The ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service for the use of the subject of the contract. 
(9)  The number and scope of conditions attached to the bid. 
(10)  Life cycle costs of products. 
(Code 1980, § 2-246) 
Sec. 2-366. - Tie bids. 
    If all bids received or the lowest bids received are for the same total amount or unit price, quality and service being equal, the contract shall be awarded to a local bidder. Where there is no city low bidder, the award shall be made on the basis of a drawing of lots, to be held in public. 
(Code 1980, § 2-247) 
Sec. 2-367. - Petty expenditures revolving fund. 
(a)  There is appropriated out of money in the city treasury, not otherwise appropriated, the sum of $300.00 which shall be known as the petty expenditures revolving fund. From this fund shall be paid all purchases not in excess of $25.00 each, made by the head of a using agency for incidentals with the approval of the chief financial officer. Amounts greater than $25.00 may be paid by obtaining prior approval from the chief financial officer. A written explanation shall accompany the purchases explaining in detail the reasons for the expenditure. 
(b)  The chief financial officer shall promulgate rules and regulations for use of the petty expenditures revolving fund. 
(Code 1980, § 2-248) 
Sec. 2-368. - Emergency purchases. 
    If an apparent emergency occurs which requires immediate purchase of supplies or contractual services, the department head may authorize the purchase, at the lowest obtainable price, of any supplies or contractual services not in excess of $1,000.00. A full explanation of the circumstances of an emergency purchase shall be reported to the director of administration in writing and a copy filed with the chief financial officer. 
(Code 1980, § 2-249) 
Sec. 2-369. - Cooperative procurement. 
    The director of administration or designee shall have the authority to join with other units of government in cooperative purchasing plans when the best interest of the city would be served and after approval of the council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-250) 
Sec. 2-370. - Sale of surplus material. 
(a)  Surplus material may be sold or disposed of without prior consideration and approval from the city council, but with signed approval from the mayor, director of administration, department head, and one member of the city council in accordance to the following: 
(1)  That said materials shall not consist of real property, but rather, tangible goods, materials, supplies, or equipment. 
(2)  That said materials shall have an estimated value of less than or equal to $10,000.00. 
(3)  That said materials shall be sold in accordance to the competitive bidding procedures set forth in this Code, including, but not limited to any verified open market competition to the highest bidder. 
(4)  That the purchasing agent or other designee as determined by the director of administration may set a minimum sale price and may reject any bid that, in said designee's judgment, is not a fair sale price. 
(b)  That all real property declared as surplus must be given city council approval by ordinance prior to sale. 
(Ord. No. 1427-16, § 1, 11-22-16) 
Secs. 2-371-2-400. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - OPEN MEETINGS AND RECORDS 

Sec. 2-401. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them as follows: 
    Closed meeting, closed record or closed vote means any meeting, record or vote closed to the public. 
    Copying, if requested by a member of the public, means photocopies provided in accord with the cost schedule established by this article, if duplication equipment is available. 
    Public business means all matters which relate in any way to the performance of the city's functions or the conduct of its business. 
    Public governmental body means any legislative, administrative governmental entity created by the constitution or statutes of this state, orders or ordinances of the city, judicial entities when operating in an administrative capacity, or by executive order, including: 
(1)  Any advisory committee or commission appointed by the mayor or city council. 
(2)  Any other legislative or administrative governmental deliberative body under the direction of three or more elected or appointed members having rule-making or quasi-judicial power. 
(3)  Any committee appointed by or at the direction of any of the entities and which is authorized to report to any of the above named entities. 
(4)  Any quasi-public governmental body. The term "quasi-public governmental body" means any corporation organized or authorized to do business in this state under the provisions of RSMo chapter 352, 353 or 355, or unincorporated association which either (a) has as its primary purpose to enter into contracts with public governmental bodies, or to engage primarily in activities carried out pursuant to an agreement or agreements with public governmental bodies; or (b) performs a public function, as evidenced by a statutorily or ordinance-based capacity to confer or otherwise advance, through approval, recommendation or other means, the allocation or issuance of tax credits, tax abatement, public debt, tax exempt debt, rights of eminent domain, or the contracting of lease-back agreements on structures whose annualized payments commit public tax revenues; or any association that directly accepts the appropriations of money from the city, but only to the extent that meetings, a record or vote relates to such appropriation. 
    Public meeting means any meeting of a public governmental body subject to this article at which any public business is discussed, decided or public policy formulated, whether corporeal or by means of communication equipment. The term "public meeting" shall not include an informal gathering of members of a public governmental body for ministerial or social purposes when there is no intent to avoid the purposes of this article. 
    Public record means any record, whether written or electronically stored, retained by or for any public governmental body including any report, survey, memorandum, or other document or study prepared and presented to the public governmental body by a consultant or other professional service paid for in whole or in part by public funds. 
    Public vote means any vote cast at any public meeting of any public governmental body. 
(Ord. No. 658-93, § 1, 11-9-93) 
Sec. 2-402. - Meetings, records and votes to be public; exceptions. 
    All meetings, records and votes are open to the public, except that any meeting, record or vote relating to one or more of the following matters, as well as other materials designated elsewhere in this article, shall be closed unless the public governmental body votes to make them public: 
(1)  Legal actions, causes of action or litigation involving a public governmental body and any confidential or privileged communications between a public governmental body or its representatives and its attorneys. However, any vote relating to litigation involving a public governmental body shall be made public upon final disposition of the matter voted upon; provided, however, in matters involving the exercise of the power of eminent domain, the vote shall be announced or become public immediately following the action on the motion to authorize institution of such a legal action. Legal work product shall be considered a closed record. 
(2)  Lease, purchase or sale of real estate by a public governmental body where public knowledge of the transaction might adversely affect the legal consideration therefor. However, any vote or public record approving a contract relating to the lease, purchase or sale of real estate by a public governmental body shall be made public upon execution of the lease, purchase or sale of the real estate. 
(3)  Hiring, firing, discipline or promotion of particular employees by a public governmental body when personal information about the employee is discussed or recorded. However, any vote on a final decision, when taken by a public governmental body, to hire, fire, promote or discipline an employee of a public governmental body must be made available to the public within 72 hours of the close of the meeting where such action occurs; provided, however, that any employee so affected shall be entitled to prompt notice before such decision is made available to the public. As used here, the term "personal information" means information relating to the performance or merit of individual employees. 
(4)  Nonjudicial mental or physical health proceedings involving an identifiable person, including medical, psychiatric, psychological or alcoholism or drug dependency diagnosis or treatment. 
(5)  Testing and examination materials, before the test or examination is given or, if it is to be given again, before so given again. 
(6)  Welfare cases of identifiable individuals. 
(7)  Preparation, including any discussions or work product, on behalf of a public governmental body or its representatives for negotiations with employee groups. 
(8)  Software codes for electronic data processing and documentation thereof. 
(9)  Specifications for competitive bidding, until either the specifications are officially approved by the public governmental body or the specifications are published for bid. 
(10)  Sealed bids and related documents, until the earlier of either when the bids are opened or all bids are accepted or all bids are rejected. 
(11)  Individually identifiable personnel records, performance ratings or records pertaining to employees or applicants for employment, except that this exemption shall not apply to the names, positions, salaries and lengths of service of officers and employees of public agencies once they are employed as such. 
(12)  Records which are protected from disclosure by law. 
(13)  Meetings and public records relating to scientific and technological innovations in which the owner has a proprietary interest. 
(Ord. No. 658-93, § 2, 11-9-93) 
Sec. 2-403. - Records pertaining to internal investigations and investigations of allegedly illegal conduct. 
(a)  In order to allow the fullest cooperation by employees and members of the public in investigation of matters wherein an employee of the city is alleged to have engaged in any form of misconduct, all files, records and documents relating to investigations of allegations of misconduct by city employees will be considered to be personnel records and shall be closed records under the custody of the respective department head. 
(b)  In order to protect the integrity and efficacy of investigations of criminal conduct and the safety and well being of witnesses, complainants, law enforcement officials and members of the public who cooperate with investigations, any information acquired by a law enforcement agency by way of a complaint or report of a crime made by telephone contact using the emergency number, "911," shall be inaccessible to the general public and shall only be available upon request by law enforcement agencies or as otherwise provided by law. For the same reasons, records of an administrative department or law enforcement agency relating to reports, associations or investigations of conduct alleged or believed to be illegal or otherwise contrary to law shall be closed records until: (a) the investigation is terminated; or (b) all suspected wrongdoers have been arrested or charged with an offense; or (c) the department head determines that public disclosure of the record would not unreasonably jeopardize such investigation. In addition, for the foregoing reasons and in order to recognize and protect rights of personal privacy, the efficient suppression and punishment of crime and protection of third parties, reports, records and materials containing information identifying witnesses, complainants, covert law enforcement personnel, confidential informants or others who may be compromised or subjected to the risk of retaliation or injury upon disclosure of their participation in any report or investigation of allegedly illegal activity, together with any information which could reasonably lead to identification of such persons, shall be deleted from any records prior to examination by or delivery to members of the public. In the event an objection to the deletion of such information is lodged by the requesting party, the custodian of the record may employ a supplemental request, notification and hearing process consistent with the provisions of section 2-405 below, and/or the question resolution procedures pursuant to section 2-412 below prior to allowing access to the information in question. 
(Ord. No. 658-93, § 3, 11-9-93) 
Sec. 2-404. - Records pertaining to medical condition or history. 
    All information obtained by the city regarding medical examinations, medical condition or medical history of city employees or job applicants, if retained by the city, shall be collected and maintained on separate forms and in separate medical files and shall be treated as closed and confidential records, except that: (a) supervisors and managers may be informed regarding necessary restrictions on the work duties of employees and necessary accommodations; (b) first aid and safety personnel may be informed, when appropriate, if the information reflects the existence of a disability which might require emergency treatment; or (c) government officials investigating compliance with state or federal law pertaining to treatment of persons with disabilities may be allowed access to such records. 
(Ord. No. 658-93, § 4, 11-9-93) 
Sec. 2-405. - Records containing confidential, proprietary or private information. 
(a)  In order to protect reasonable expectations of privacy on the part of persons having dealings with the city, city records containing information or entries of a personal, confidential, private or proprietary nature including, but not limited to, income, sales data, financial circumstances, household and family relationships, social security numbers, dates of birth, insurance information and other information which reasonable persons generally regard as private and not a customary subject for public discourse, which information or entries have been provided to the city by one complying with regulations requiring the disclosure of such information, shall be excised from copies of city records disclosed or provided to members of the public other than those persons to whom the information or entries pertain. Persons desiring access to information or entries excised from such records may file a supplementary written request with the city clerk for disclosure of material to be specified in the request, which request should state: (a) whether or not the requesting party has informed persons to whom the requested information pertains of the request; and (b) all reasons why the requesting party believes disclosure by the city of the specified information is in the public interest. 
(b)  The director of administration may afford all interested parties, including the persons to whom the information pertains, a reasonable time within which to comment on the requested disclosure prior to acting further on the request. If an interested person objects to the disclosure of the requested information, the director of administration may conduct a hearing at which all interested parties may be heard. At such hearing, the director of administration shall consider, among such other factors as may be reasonable and relevant: (a) the requirements and intent of state law, city ordinances and this policy; (b) the legitimate expectations of privacy on the part of interested parties; (c) the personal, confidential, private or proprietary nature of the information at issue; (d) whether the information was obtained by the city under compulsion of law or was freely and voluntarily provided by the persons objecting to the disclosure; and (e) the public purposes to be served by disclosure of the requested information. If the director of administration determines that disclosure is legally required or would otherwise serve the best interests of the public and that such requirements or purpose outweigh the legitimate concerns or interests of the persons to whom the information pertains, the director of administration shall provide the requested information to the requesting party. 
(c)  In addition to or in lieu of the hearing described above, the director of administration may afford all interested parties a reasonable opportunity to seek judicial review of or relief from the proposed disclosure. The director of administration may also utilize the procedures for judicial determination and/or opinion solicitation provided in section 2-412 below. 
(Ord. No. 658-93, § 5, 11-9-93) 
Sec. 2-406. - Notices of meetings. 
(a)  Each governmental body shall give notice of the time, date, place and tentative agenda of each meeting. The notice shall be placed on the appropriate bulletin board at the city hall at least 24 hours prior to the meeting, exclusive of weekends and holidays when the city hall is closed. If an emergency makes it impossible to give 24-hours notice, the reason must be reflected in the minutes. Notice shall also be given to any representative of the news media who requests notice of meetings of a particular public governmental body. 
(b)  Each governmental body shall give notice of the time, date, place of a closed meeting and the reason for holding it by reference to a specific exception. The notice shall be the same as described in the preceding paragraph. No other business may be discussed in a closed meeting which does not directly relate to the specific reason announced to close the meeting to the public. 
(c)  A formally constituted subunit of a parent governmental body may conduct a meeting without notice during a lawful meeting of the parent governmental body, a recess in that meeting, or immediately following that meeting, if the meeting of the subunit is publicly announced at the parent meeting and the subject of the meeting reasonably coincides with the subjects discussed or acted upon by the parent governmental body. 
(Ord. No. 658-93, § 6, 11-9-93) 
Sec. 2-407. - Closed meetings, how held; journals of meetings and records of voting. 
    Before closing a meeting to the public, a majority of a quorum of the governmental body must vote to do so in a public vote. The vote of each member of the governmental body on the question of closing the meeting or vote and the reason for closing the meeting by reference to a specific exception shall attribute each "yea" and "nay" vote, or abstinence if not voting, to the name of the individual member of the body. 
(Ord. No. 658-93, § 7, 11-9-93) 
Sec. 2-408. - Accessibility of meetings. 
    Each meeting shall be held at a place reasonably accessible to the public and at a time reasonably convenient to the public, unless for good cause such a place or time is impossible or impractical. When it is necessary to hold a meeting on less than 24-hours notice or at a place that is not reasonably accessible to the public or at a time that is not reasonably convenient to the public, the nature of the good cause justifying that departure from the normal requirements shall be stated in the minutes. 
(Ord. No. 658-93, § 8, 11-9-93) 
Sec. 2-409. - Separation of exempt material. 
    If a public record contains material which is not exempt from disclosure as well as material which is exempt from disclosure, the custodian shall separate the exempt and nonexempt material and make the nonexempt material available for public examination and copying in accord with the policies provided herein. When designing a public record, the custodian shall, to the extent practicable, facilitate a separation of exempt from nonexempt information. If the separation is readily apparent to a person requesting to inspect or receive copies of the form, the custodian shall generally describe the material exempted, unless that description would reveal the contents of the exempt information and thus defeat the purpose of the exemption. 
(Ord. No. 658-93, § 9, 11-9-93) 
Sec. 2-410. - Arrest record. 
    Records shall be maintained of all arrests made by city law enforcement personnel. Records of arrests shall be made available to the public. If any person is arrested and not charged with an offense against the law within 30 days of the arrest, official records of the arrest and of any detention or confinement incident thereto shall thereafter be closed records, except that the disposition portion of the record may be accessed for purposes of exculpation. If the person arrested is charged but the case is subsequently nolle prossed, dismissed, or the accused is found not guilty or imposition of sentence is suspended in the court in which the action is prosecuted, official records pertaining to the case shall thereafter be closed records when such case is finally terminated, except that the disposition portion of the record may be accessed for purposes of exculpation and except as provided by RSMo 610.120. 
(Ord. No. 658-93, § 10, 11-9-93) 
Sec. 2-411. - Custodian designated; response to request for access to records. 
(a)  The director of administration shall be the custodian of records and will be responsible for maintenance and control of all records. The custodian may designate deputy custodians in operating departments of the city and such other departments or offices as the custodian may determine. Deputy custodians shall conduct matters relating to public records and meetings in accord with the policies enumerated herein. 
(b)  The custodian shall provide public access to all public records as soon as possible but no later than the third business day following the date the request is received by the custodian. If additional delay is necessary, the custodian shall give an explanation for the delay and the date the record will be available for inspection. 
(c)  If a request for access is denied, the custodian shall provide, upon request, a written statement of the grounds for such denial. Such statement shall cite the specific provision of law under which access is denied and shall be furnished to the requester no later than the end of the third business day following the date that the request for the statement is received. 
(Ord. No. 658-93, § 11, 11-9-93) 
Sec. 2-412. - Procedures for resolving questions of public accessibility. 
    A public governmental body or record custodian in doubt about the legality of closing a particular meeting, record or vote may, subject to approval by the city council, bring suit in the circuit court for the county to ascertain the propriety of such action. In addition, subject to approval by the city council, the public governmental body or custodian may seek a formal opinion of the attorney general or an attorney for the city regarding the propriety of such action. In such events, the proposed closed meeting or public access to the record or vote shall be deferred for a reasonable time pending the outcome of the actions so taken. 
(Ord. No. 658-93, § 12, 11-9-93) 
Sec. 2-413. - Fees. 
    The custodian shall charge $0.25 per page for duplication costs and $10.00 per hour for document search. The custodian shall receive (or may require) payment prior to duplicating documents. 
(Ord. No. 658-93, § 13, 11-9-93) 
Chapter 6 - ADVERTISING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, ch. 10; businesses, ch. 22; cable communications, ch. 26; food service establishments, § 58-51 et seq.; secondhand goods, ch. 90; signs, ch. 92; taxicabs, § 118-26 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them by this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Aircraft means any contrivance invented, used or designated for navigation or for flight in the air. The term "aircraft" includes helicopters and lighter-than-air dirigibles and balloons. 
    Commercial handbill means any printed or written matter, any sample, device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature which: 
(1)  Advertises for sale any merchandise, produce, commodity or thing; 
(2)  Directs attention to any business or mercantile or commercial establishment or other activity for the purpose of, either directly or indirectly, promoting the interest thereof by sales; 
(3)  Directs attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition or event of any kind for which an admission fee is charged for the purpose of private gain or profit; provided, however, that this subsection of this definition shall not apply where an admission fee is charged or a collection is taken up for the purpose of defraying the expenses incident to such meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition or event of any kind, when either of such is held, given or takes place in connection with the dissemination of information which is not restricted under the ordinary rules of decency, good morals, public peace, safety and good order; provided further, however, that nothing contained in this subsection of this definition shall be deemed to authorize the holding, giving or taking place of any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition or event of any kind without a license, where such license is or may be required by any law of the state or under any ordinance of the city; or 
(4)  While containing reading matter other than advertising matter, is predominantly and essentially an advertisement and is distributed or circulated for advertising purposes or for the private benefit and gain of any person so engaged as advertiser or distributor. 
    Newspaper means any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law, any newspaper duly entered with the United States Postal Service in accordance with federal statute or regulation and any newspaper filed and recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law and, in addition thereto, means and includes any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four issues per year and sold to the public. 
    Noncommercial handbill means any printed or written matter, sample, device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper, booklet or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature not included in the definition of a commercial handbill or newspaper. 
    Park means a park, reservation, playground, beach, recreation center or any other public area in the city owned or used by the city and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
    Private premises means any dwelling, house, building or other structure designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and includes any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building or other structure. 
    Public place means any street, sidewalk, boulevard, alley or other public way and any public park, square, space, grounds and building. 
    Public poles and structures means any public utility pole, lamppost, street sign, fence, wall, bridge, tree, pole, post or any structure belonging to the city. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Code 1980, § 3-1; Ord. No. 759-97, § 1, 10-28-97) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 6-2. - Civic signs in public rights-of-way. 
    Signs, banners, billboards and similar structures and objects directly relating to charitable, historical, religious or other civic services and nonprofit activities may be installed in the public rights-of-way upon a permit issued by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 3-5) 
Sec. 6-3. - Stickers attached to vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to attach any gummed sticker to any vehicle within the city without the consent of the owner of such vehicle. 
(Code 1980, § 3-6) 
Sec. 6-4. - Obscene advertisements. 
    No person shall post, stick or put upon any street, alley, sidewalk, wall, fence, bridge, billboard or other public place within the city or suffer, permit or cause such to be done any printed advertisement, bill, poster or circular which is obscene under state law, or any notice of an illegal trade or business nor shall any person leave or place or cause to be left or placed any such advertisement, bill, poster, circular or notice in or upon any house, building, yard or premises, whether such is enclosed in an envelope or in any other form nor shall any person give or cause to be given to anyone any such advertisement, bill, poster, circular or notice. 
(Code 1980, § 3-8) 
Sec. 6-5. - Posting notices, etc. to public poles and structures. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to post or affix any advertisement, notice, handbill, poster or other paper or device calculated to attract the attention of the public on any public lamppost, utility pole, fence, wall, bridge, tree or upon any other public structure, pole or building except as may be authorized or required by law. 
(Ord. No. 759-97, § 2, 10-28-97) 
Secs. 6-6-6-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HANDBILLS 

Sec. 6-26. - Exemptions. 
    This article shall not apply to the distribution of mail by the United States or to newspapers; provided, however that newspapers shall be placed in such a manner as to prevent their being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. 
(Code 1980, § 3-26) 
Sec. 6-27. - Distribution in public places. 
    No person shall throw or deposit any handbill in or upon any sidewalk, street or other public place within the city. 
(Code 1980, § 3-20(a)) 
Sec. 6-28. - Distributing on posted property. 
    No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any handbill upon any private premises, if requested by anyone thereon not to do so or if there is placed on the premises in a conspicuous position near the entrance thereof a sign bearing the words "no trespassing," "no peddlers or agents," "no advertisement" or any similar notice indicating in any manner that the occupants of the premises do not desire to be molested or have their right of privacy disturbed or to have any such handbill left upon such premises. 
(Code 1980, § 3-22) 
Sec. 6-29. - Depositing on inhabited, private premises. 
    No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any handbill in or upon private premises which are inhabited, except by handing or transmitting any such handbill directly to the owner, occupant or other person then present in or upon such private premises. However, for inhabited private premises which are not posted, as provided in section 6-29, such person, unless requested by anyone upon such premises not to do so, may place or deposit any such handbill in or upon such inhabited private premises, provided that such handbill shall be so placed or deposited as to secure or prevent such handbill from being blown or drifted about such premises or sidewalks, streets or other public places and provided that mailboxes may not be so used when so prohibited by federal postal law or regulations. 
(Code 1980, § 3-24) 
Sec. 6-30. - Dropping from aircraft. 
    No person in an aircraft shall throw out, drop or deposit within the city any litter, handbill or any other object, except as permitted by the city. 
(Code 1980, § 3-25) 
Secs. 6-31-6-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AMPLIFICATION OF SOUND 

Sec. 6-56. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bel is a unit of level when the base of the logarithm is ten. Use of the bel is restricted to levels of quantities proportional to power. 
    Decibel is one-tenth of a bel and is a unit of level when the base of the logarithm is the tenth root of ten, and the quantities concerned are proportional to power. 
    Noncommercial use for purposes of this section shall mean any use other than for commercial advertising purposes. 
    Sound amplifying equipment means any machine or device for the amplification of the human voice, music or any other sound amplifying equipment and includes megaphones, amplifiers, walkie-talkies, amplifiers on fronts of business buildings or other sound devices. The term "sound amplifying equipment" shall not be construed as including standard automobile radios when used and heard only by occupants of the vehicle in which installed or warning devices on authorized emergency vehicles or horns or other warning devices on other vehicles used only for traffic purposes. 
    Sound-level meter is an instrument including a microphone, an amplifier, an output meter, and frequency weighing networks for the measurement of noise and sound levels in a specified manner. 
    Sound pressure level, in decibels, of sound is 20 times the logarithm to base ten of the ratio of the pressure of this sound to the reference pressure, which reference pressure must be explicitly stated. 
    Sound truck or other conveyance includes any vehicle, whether motorized or not, and any airplane, balloon, dirigible or any other type of aircraft having mounted therein, thereon or attached thereto any sound amplifying equipment. 
(Code 1980, § 20-91; Ord. No. 855-00, § 1, 9-12-00) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 6-57. - Commercial advertising prohibited. 
    No person shall operate or cause to be operated any sound truck or other conveyance for commercial advertising purposes on any street or on any public or private alley in the city or in the air over the city with sound amplifying equipment in operation. No person shall operate or cause to be operated any sound amplifying equipment on any public square, public street or public playground for commercial advertising purposes in the city. 
(Code 1980, § 20-92) 
Sec. 6-58. - Noncommercial use-Registration statement required-Exemptions. 
    Before any person shall use or cause to be used a sound truck or other conveyance with its sound amplifying equipment in operation for noncommercial purposes on any street in the city or in the air above the city and before any person shall use or cause to be used any sound amplifying equipment in any public park or public playground or on private property in the city, he shall file a registration statement with the city clerk. No registration statement shall be required for schools, churches, colleges or universities when the sound amplifying equipment is used in conjunction with religious or athletic events. 
(Code 1980, § 20-93; Ord. No. 855-00, § 1, 9-12-00) 
Sec. 6-59. - Same-Form and contents of statement. 
    The registration statement required by section 6-58 shall be in writing, shall be filed in duplicate and shall state the following information: 
(1)  Name and home address of the applicant. 
(2)  Address of place of business of applicant. 
(3)  Type, license number and motor number of sound truck. 
(4)  Name and address of person who owns the sound truck or sound amplifying equipment. 
(5)  Name and address of person having direct charge of the sound truck or sound amplifying equipment. 
(6)  Name and address of all persons who will use or operate the sound truck or sound amplifying equipment. 
(7)  The purpose for which the sound truck or sound amplifying equipment will be used. 
(8)  A general statement as to the section of the city in and over which the sound truck or sound amplifying equipment will be used. 
(9)  The proposed hours of operation of the sound truck or sound amplifying equipment. 
(10)  The number of days of proposed operation of the sound truck or sound amplifying equipment. 
(11)  A general description of the sound amplifying equipment which is to be used. 
(12)  The maximum sound producing power of the sound truck or, otherwise, state the following: 
a.  The wattage to be used. 
b.  The volume in decibels of the sound which will be produced. 
c.  The approximate maximum distance for which sound will be thrown from the sound truck or sound amplifying equipment. 
(13)  Written permission from any schools, churches or hospitals within 100 yards of the proposed location. 
(Code 1980, § 20-94; Ord. No. 855-00, § 1, 9-12-00) 
Sec. 6-60. - Amendments to registration statement. 
    All persons using or causing to be used sound trucks or sound amplifying equipment for noncommercial purposes shall amend any registration statement filed pursuant to section 6-58 within 48 hours after any change in the information furnished in such statement. 
(Code 1980, § 20-95) 
Sec. 6-61. - Certified copy of registration statement used as identification. 
    The city clerk shall return to each applicant under section 6-58 one copy of such registration statement, duly certified by the city clerk as a correct copy of such application. The certified copy of the application shall be in the possession of any person operating the sound truck or sound amplifying equipment at all times while the sound amplifying equipment or any stationary sound amplifying equipment is in operation. Such copy shall be promptly displayed and shown to any police officer upon request. 
(Code 1980, § 20-96) 
Sec. 6-62. - Permitted use of sound amplifying equipment. 
    The noncommercial use of sound amplifying equipment shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  The only sounds permitted shall be music or human speech. 
(2)  Operations shall be permitted between the hours of 9:30 a.m. and 12:00 midnight each day, except Sundays and legal holidays when operations shall be authorized only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 p.m. 
(3)  Sound amplifying equipment shall not be operated from sound trucks unless the sound truck upon which such equipment is mounted is operated at a speed of at least five miles per hour, except when such truck is stopped or impeded by traffic. Where stopped by traffic, the sound amplifying equipment shall not be operated for longer than one minute at each such stop. 
(4)  Sound shall not be issued within 100 yards of hospitals, schools or churches without the written approval of the hospital, school or church within the 100-yard limit. 
(5)  The human speech and music amplified shall not be obscene under state law. 
(6)  The volume of sound shall be controlled so that it will not be audible for a distance in excess of 300 feet from the location of the sound amplifying equipment and so that such volume is not unreasonably loud, raucous, jarring, disturbing or a nuisance to persons within the area of audibility; provided, however, the limitation of audibility to a distance not in excess of 300 feet shall not apply to sound issued from aircraft. 
(7)  All sound amplifying equipment operated shall have limitations on the decibel levels and sound pressure levels allowable. Measurements shall be taken only with properly calibrated sound measurement equipment used in accordance with accepted sound measurement practices. These levels are as follows: 
a.  For outdoor use of any sound amplifying equipment, the decibel levels allowable shall not exceed 100 decibels when measured at a distance of ten feet from in front of the center of the speakers, nor shall it exceed 85 decibels when measured at a distance of 100 feet. 
b.  For indoor use of any sound amplifying equipment, no registration statement shall be required, the decibel levels allowable shall not exceed 75 decibels when measured from the nearest public property. Public property shall include but not be limited to sidewalks, streets and alleyways. 
(8)  Waivers of any part of this section may only be granted by a majority vote of the city council and shall be noted on the registration statement provided by the city clerk. 
(Code 1980, § 20-97; Ord. No. 855-00, § 1, 9-12-00) 
Sec. 6-63. - Use in public parks and playgrounds. 
    Section 6-62, insofar as applicable, shall also apply to any noncommercial use of any sound amplifying equipment in any public park or public playground within the corporate limits of the city. No such sound amplifying equipment shall be used on any public playground in connection with any public school building on days on which such public building is being used for school purposes, without permission from school officials. 
(Code 1980, § 20-98; Ord. No. 855-00, § 1, 9-12-00) 
Sec. 6-64. - Use for dances in streets or in yards. 
    Section 6-62, insofar as applicable, shall apply to any noncommercial use of any sound amplifying equipment on any property or in connection with any street dance or dance being held outdoors on any property; provided, however, the hours during which use shall be permitted for dances shall be between 4:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight of any day of the week except Sundays and legal holidays when operations shall be authorized only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 p.m. 
(Code 1980, § 20-99; Ord. No. 855-00, § 1, 9-12-00) 
Sec. 6-65. - Other uses of sound amplifying equipment. 
    Any other uses of sound amplifying equipment on any property within the corporate limits of the city not addressed by other ordinance(s) shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  Between the hours of 9:30 a.m. and 12:00 midnight, except Sundays and legal holidays when operations shall be authorized only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 p.m., the volume of sound shall be controlled so that it will not be audible for a distance in excess of 300 feet from the location of the sound amplifying equipment, the distance shall be 50 feet during all other hours and at all times the volume shall not be unreasonably loud, raucous, jarring, disturbing or a nuisance to persons within the area of the defined distances. 
(2)  The human speech and music amplified shall not be profane, lewd, indecent or obscene under state law. 
(3)  At no time shall the volume of sound from any sound system located in or near a motor vehicle be at a level so as to be audible more than 50 feet from the vehicle while the vehicle is not located upon the property of the vehicle owner. This subsection shall apply to all portable sound systems commonly known as jamboxes, boomboxes and car stereos. It shall include any battery-operated sound system even if it is not designed to be permanently mounted or attached to a motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 774-98, § 1, 4-14-98; Ord. No. 828-99, § 1, 9-21-99; Ord. No. 855-00, § 1, 9-12-00) 
Sec. 6-66. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating sections 6-57 through 6-65, where no penalty is otherwise provided, shall, upon conviction, be adjudged guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in section 1-20. 
(Ord. No. 774-98, § 1, 4-14-98) 
Chapter 10 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- General penalty for Code violations, § 1-20; advertising, ch. 6; businesses, ch. 22; law enforcement, ch. 70; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 78; traffic regulations, ch. 110. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alcoholic beverages includes all beverages of alcoholic content, whether intoxicating or nonintoxicating. 
    Church means a church building or student center building in which services are regularly held; provided, however, the mere holding of religious services in any building not built and constructed as a church or student center building shall not bring such building within the definition of a church as set out in this chapter. 
    Closed place means a place where all doors are locked and where no patrons are in or about the premises. 
    Intoxicating liquor means alcohol for beverage purposes, alcoholic, spirituous, vinous, fermented, malt or other liquors or combination of liquors, a part of which is spirituous, vinous or fermented, and all preparations for mixtures for beverage purposes containing in excess of one-half of one percent of alcohol by volume, except nonintoxicating beer as defined in this section. 
    Nonintoxicating beer means any beer manufactured from pure hops or pure extract of hops, pure barley malt or other wholesome grains or cereals, wholesome yeast, pure water, free from all harmful substances, preservatives and adulterants and having an alcoholic content of more than one-half of one percent by volume and not exceeding 3.2 percent by weight. 
    Open container means any alcoholic beverage except in the original container which shall not have been opened and the seal upon which shall not have been broken and from which the original cap or cork shall not have been removed. 
    Original package means, with reference to the sale of malt liquor, any package containing three or more standard bottles of beer. With reference to the sale of intoxicating liquor, other than malt liquor, the term "original package" means a package or container containing a quantity of 50 milliliters or more of intoxicating liquor in the manufacturer's original package. With reference to nonintoxicating beer, the term "original package" means any package containing three or more of any size bottle or any other container when such bottles or other containers contain nonintoxicating beer, as defined in this section. 
    Person means and includes any individual, association, joint stock company, syndicate, copartnership, corporation, receiver, trustee, conservator or other officer appointed by any state or federal court. 
    Restaurant bar means any establishment having a restaurant or similar facility on the premises, at least 50 percent of the gross income of which is derived from the sale of prepared meals or food consumed on such premises or which has an annual gross income of at least $275,000.00 from the sale of prepared meals or food consumed on the premises. 
    School means any building which is regularly used as a public, private or parochial school, elementary school, high school, college or university. 
    Substantial quantities of food means the amount of prepared meals and food from which at least 50 percent of the gross income of an establishment is derived. 
    Wholesalers or distributors means persons selling intoxicating liquors or nonintoxicating beer to retailers for resale. 
(Code 1980, §§ 4-1, 4-20; Ord. No. 612-92, § 1, 6-9-92) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-2. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating this chapter, where no penalty is otherwise provided, shall, upon conviction, be adjudged guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in section 1-20. 
(Code 1980, § 4-21) 
Sec. 10-3. - Selling to persons under influence or underage persons. 
(a)  No person shall sell or supply intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer or permit intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer to be sold or supplied to any person who is under or apparently under the influence of alcohol. 
(b)  Intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer shall not be given, sold or otherwise supplied to any person under the age of 21 years, except that this shall not apply to the supplying of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer to a person under such age for medicinal purposes only or by the parent or guardian of such person or to the administering of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer to such person by a physician. 
(Code 1980, § 4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.310, 312.400. 
Sec. 10-4. - Consumption by underage persons. 
    The drinking or consumption of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer shall not be permitted in, upon or about any licensed premises by any person under 21 years of age. 
(Code 1980, § 4-14) 
Sec. 10-5. - Sale by underage persons. 
    No person under the age of 21 years shall sell or assist in the sale or dispensing of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer, except where such person is permitted to do so under the laws of this state. 
(Code 1980, § 4-15) 
State Law reference- Permitted sales of intoxicating liquor and nonintoxicating beer by persons under 21, RSMo 311.300. 
Sec. 10-6. - Misrepresentation of age. 
    No person of the age of 17 years and under the age of 21 years shall represent that he has attained the age of 21 years for the purpose of purchasing, asking for or in any way receiving any intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer. 
(Code 1980, § 4-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.320, 312.405. 
Sec. 10-7. - Purchase or possession by underage persons. 
    Any person under the age of 21 years who purchases or attempts to purchase or has in his possession any intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1980, § 4-17) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.325, 312.407. 
Sec. 10-8. - Intoxication of public officials. 
    Any person elected or appointed to any public office of the city who shall be intoxicated while in the performance of any official act or duty or who shall become so intoxicated as to be incapacitated to perform any official act or duty at the time or in the manner required by law shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1980, § 4-18) 
Sec. 10-9. - Intoxication of firefighters. 
    Any officer or member of the fire company who shall be found in a state of intoxication at any fire or any officer or member of the fire company who shall use or permit the use of any intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer in or about any engine house or fire station thereafter shall be ineligible to be an officer or member of the fire company. 
(Code 1980, § 4-19) 
Cross reference- Fire department, § 50-56 et seq. 
Sec. 10-10. - Possession in open container in public places. 
(a)  Prohibited in public places. It shall be unlawful for any person to be in possession of an alcoholic beverage in an open container when upon any public street, sidewalk, alley or public thoroughfare or on or in any public building or parking lot. 
(b)  Exemptions. This section shall not apply to the consumption of any intoxicating liquor, malt liquor or nonintoxicating beer opened and consumed inside an establishment licensed to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink. 
(c)  Permits for parks and recreational areas. It shall be unlawful for any person to be in possession of an alcoholic beverage in an open container on any property maintained as a park or recreational area by the city without first obtaining a permit. No permit shall be issued for any area within 150 feet of a recreational area on which a person 18 years of age or younger will be involved in an organized recreational activity. When organized recreational activities involve persons 19 years of age or older, permits may be issued for an area outside the actual participating field. Permits may not be issued for a period of time more than 18 hours during any calendar day. Those hours must be between 8:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m. Permits may not be issued for more than four consecutive days. No permit may be issued for the following areas: 
(1)  Municipal swimming pool. 
(2)  Hensley Field (inside fences). 
(3)  Memorial Field. 
(4)  McBride Field. 
(5)  Murphy Field. 
(6)  Seaman Field. 
(7)  Municipal tennis courts. 
(Code 1980, § 4-20; Ord. No. 612-92, § 1, 6-9-92) 
Secs. 10-11-10-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-31. - License-Required; term; renewal. 
    It is unlawful for any person, either by himself or through the use of agents or servants, to engage in the manufacture, brewing, sale or distribution of intoxicating liquors or nonintoxicating beer within the city without first having obtained a license in compliance with this chapter. Such license shall be issued for a period of one year from July 1 of each year. Persons desiring to secure licenses after July 1 shall pay for such portion of the license year remaining at the time such license is issued. Thereafter, all renewals of licenses shall be made on June 30 each year. 
(Code 1980, § 4-2) 
Sec. 10-32. - Qualifications of applicant. 
    No person shall be granted a license under this article who does not meet the qualifications of the state for a state license.
