DIVISION 2. - LEAD BAN 

Sec. 18-144. - General policy. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this division is: 
(1)  To ban the use of lead materials in the public drinking water system and private plumbing connected to the public drinking water system; and 
(2)  To protect city residents from lead contamination in the city's public drinking water system and their own private plumbing systems. 
(b)  Application. This division shall apply to all premises served by the public drinking water system of the city. 
(c)  Policy. This division will be reasonably interpreted by the water purveyor. It is the purveyor's intent to ban use of lead based material in the construction or modification of the city's drinking water system or private plumbing connected to the city's system. The cooperation of all consumers is required to implement the lead ban. 
    If, in judgment of the water purveyor or his/her authorized representative, lead based materials have been used in new construction or modifications after January 4, 2014, due notice shall be given to the consumer. The consumer shall immediately comply by having the lead based materials removed from the plumbing system and replaced with lead free materials. If the lead based materials are not removed from the plumbing system, the water purvey shall have the right to discontinue water services to the premises. 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Sec. 18-145. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this division: 
(1)  Consumer means the owner or person in control of any premises supplied by or in any manner connected to a public water system. 
(2)  Lead based materials means any material containing lead in excess of the quantities specified in subsection (a)(3) below; 
(3)  Lead free means: 
a.  When used with respect to solder and flux, refers to solders and flux containing not more than 0.2 percent lead. 
b.  When used with respect to pipes, pipe fittings, plumbing fittings, and fixtures, refers to pipes, pipe fittings, plumbing fittings, and fixtures containing not more than a weighted average of 0.25 percent lead. 
(4)  Public drinking water system means any publicly or privately owned water system supplying water to the general public which is satisfactory for drinking, culinary, and domestic purposes, and meets the requirements of the state department of natural resources; and 
(5)  Water purveyor means the owner, operator, or individual in responsible charge of a public water system. 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Sec. 18-146. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Pipes, pipe fittings, plumbing fittings or fixtures, including backflow preventers that are used exclusively for non-potable services such as manufacturing, industrial processing, irrigation, outdoor watering, or any other uses where the water is not anticipated to be used for human consumption; (S.W.D.A. 1417(a)(4)(A)) 
(b)  Toilets, bidets, urinals, fill valves, flushometer valves, tub fillers, fire hydrants, shower valves, service saddles, or water distribution main gate valves that are two inches in diameter or larger. (S.W.D.A. 1417 (a)(4)(B)) 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Sec. 18-147. - Lead banned from drinking water plumbing. 
(a)  No water service connection shall be installed or maintained to any premises where lead based materials were used in new construction or modifications of the drinking water plumbing after January 4, 2014. 
(b)  If a premises is found to be in violation of subsection (a) above, water services shall be discontinued until such a time that the drinking water plumbing is lead free. 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Secs. 18-148-18-155. - Reserved.

Section F 101.1. Insert: City of Fulton 
Section F 109.4 Insert: Misdemeanor, $500, 90 
Section F 111.4 Insert: $250, $500 
Section 1103.5.3 Insert: If applicable, prior to occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Secs. 18-169-18-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - INTERNATIONAL FUEL GAS CODE 

Sec. 18-176. - Adopted. 
(a)  There is adopted by the city that certain code known as the 2015 International Fuel Gas Code, published by the Building Officials and Code Administrators International, Inc., with all amendments and appendices thereto, and the code is incorporated as if fully set out in this article, and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the limits of the city. 
(b)  Should a difference in terminology or requirement exist between this article and the code adopted in this section, this article shall take precedence. 
(c)  Copies of the code shall be on file in the office of the city clerk and the planning and code enforcement office. 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Sec. 18-177. - Definitions. 
    When the following words and phrases are used in the fuel gas code adopted by this article, they shall have the following meanings: 
    Board of appeals and Board of survey mean the board of adjustment as created under the zoning ordinance of the city in appendix A to this Code. 
    Corporation counsel means city counselor. 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Sec. 18-178. - Amendments. 
    The fuel gas code adopted by this article is amended as follows: 
Section 101.1. Insert: City of Fulton 
Section 106.6.2 Insert: Fee Schedule as reviewed and established by the City Council from time to time. 
Section 106.6.3 DOES NOT APPLY 
Section 108.4. Insert: Misdemeanor, $500, 90 
Section 108.5. Insert: $250, $500 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Secs. 18-179-18-185. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - MOVING OF BUILDINGS 

Sec. 18-186. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful to move a building into or within the city until a permit shall have been obtained from the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Sec. 18-187. - Bond. 
(a)  Each applicant for a permit required by section 18-177 shall demonstrate proof of liability insurance in effect and shall execute and deposit in the office of the city clerk a cash bond in the amount of $500.00. 
(b)  Such bond shall be conditioned that the applicant will indemnify and save harmless the city from all accidents and damages caused by negligence in protecting his work or by unfaithful or inadequate work done, or from any damage caused by the moving of any building, house or structure, or by any unreasonable delay in moving such house, building or structure from the streets or alleys. The applicant shall also condition that he will pay all fines imposed upon him for any violation of this chapter. 
(c)  The bond shall cover all permits issued for 60 days from such approval and filing of the permits or until the applicant forfeits such bond because of his failure to comply with all of the conditions therein. 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Sec. 18-188. - Display of permit. 
    The holder of a permit to move a building shall, at all times while engaged in such work, have said permit and exhibit it upon request of authorities of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Sec. 18-189. - Clarification of permit. 
    No permit required by this article shall be construed to allow anything not stated in the application for the permit. 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Sec. 18-190. - Notice upon completion of work; inspection. 
    Immediately after the moving of any house, building or structure to the place designated in the permit required by this article, the holder of such permit shall notify the city engineer, who shall, within 24 hours after receipt of such notice, inspect all public and private property along which the moving was done, and ascertain what damage, if any, was caused because of such moving and accordingly approve or disapprove the work. If any damage was caused, the city engineer shall report same to the director of administration and take appropriate action to recover the cost of repair or replacement of such damaged property. 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Secs. 18-191-18-201. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - SWIMMING POOLS 

Sec. 18-202. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building inspector means the city building inspector. 
    Family pool means a body of water and auxiliary structures operated and maintained in conjunction with a community association or operated and maintained at a private residence and intended only for the use of the owner and invited guests. 
    Swimming pool means an artificial or natural receptacle containing a body of water, whether located indoors or outdoors, used or intended to be used for public, semipublic or private swimming, whether or not any change or fee is imposed for such uses, operated and maintained by any person, including all swimming pools operated and maintained in conjunction with or by clubs, motels, hotels, and shall include all structures, appurtenances, equipment, appliances and other facilities appurtenant to and intended for the operation and maintenance of a swimming pool, excluding family pools. 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Sec. 18-203. - Powers and duties of building inspector. 
    The building inspector shall have the authority to make further reasonable rules and regulations to ensure safe and sanitary operation of swimming pools and family pools. The building inspector shall be required to inspect all swimming pools and family pools regularly and to take samples of water is use for the purpose of determining the sanitary condition of the pool and pool area, and for this purpose shall have the right to enter upon the pool premises. If the condition of the pool area or water fails to meet the requirements of this Code or if the pool is not being operated in accordance with this article, the building inspector shall have the power to abate or cause a suspension of the use of such pool until such time as compliance is obtained; provided, however, that the owner and operator of the pool shall have first been notified of the unsatisfactory conditions and given a reasonable period of time to correct the conditions to the satisfaction of the building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Sec. 18-204. - Operating permit required; issuance. 
    Every person owning, operating or maintaining a swimming pool, other than a family pool, shall be required to hold an unrevoked operating permit from the building inspector, such permit to be issued annually upon application and after certification by the building inspector to the effect that all requirements of this article and this Code regarding safety and sanitation have been complied with. If the application is denied, the applicant shall have the right of appeal to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Sec. 18-205. - Operating requirements. 
(a)  Any person owning or operating a swimming pool, other than a family pool or a pool operated as an ancillary service of a motel or hotel, shall provide and maintain the following: 
(1)  At least one lifeguard on duty and at an appointed station for each 50 persons in the pool area during the time that such pool is in use. Such lifeguard shall have completed the senior lifesaving course conducted by the American National Red Cross and shall have in his possession a valid, unexpired card duly authenticated to that effect. However, when organized classes are being conducted by an educational institution, this subsection shall be satisfied by the presence of an appointed swimming instructor of the institution conducting the classes. All such lifeguards or instructors on duty must be physically able and fit to rescue any bather in danger of drowning. 
(2)  Rules for the conduct of bathers to minimize danger of injury to persons using the pool. All such rules shall be approved by the health department. 
(3)  Swimming pools operated in conjunction with a hotel or motel shall at all times when a lifeguard is not on duty have conspicuously posted at the entrance to the pool a sign with letters not less than two inches in height reading "no lifeguard on duty. Swim at own risk". 
(4)  A telephone in working order and the telephone numbers of the fire department and six available doctors posted adjacent to such pool, or the owner or operator of such pool shall provide some other manner or means approved by the health department of effectively summoning the fire department and a doctor. 
(5)  Convenient means of ingress and egress, and shall clearly mark or indicate the depth of water and any dangerous irregularities of the bottom. 
(b)  Any person owning or operating a swimming pool or family pool shall provide and maintain the water in such pool so that it is in conformity with section E4207 of the building code adopted in this chapter at all times when the pool is in use, except that natural bodies of water shall only be required to be certified free of pollution and approved for swimming by the health department. 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Sec. 18-206. - Locking of gates and opening. 
    All openings or holes in the fence required by section E4207 of the building code adopted in this chapter shall be fastened and locked at any and all times that each swimming or family pool is not in use or is unattended. 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Sec. 18-207. - Sanitation and safety of premises. 
    The buildings, grounds, dressing rooms and all other swimming pool or family pool facilities shall be kept in a sanitary and safe condition and maintained free from garbage, trash and other refuse and objects hazardous to health and safety of bathers. 
(Ord. No. 1439-17, § 1, 8-8-17) 
Chapter 22 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to license, tax and regulate businesses, occupations, professions, vocations, activities or things, § 12.1. 
Cross reference- Advertising, ch. 6; alcholic beverages, ch. 10; cable communications, ch. 26; cemetery interment certificate and city burial permit, § 30-56 et seq.; flood regulation development permits, § 54-46 et seq.; food service establishment permits, § 58-76 et seq.; secondhand goods, ch. 90; signs, ch. 22; utilities, ch. 114; taxicab business license, § 118-36 et seq.; taxicab chauffeur's license, § 118-61 et seq. 
State Law reference- Restriction on licensing of businesses, RSMo 71.610. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms and business designations, unless expressly defined in this chapter or by another chapter of this Code, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Auctioneer means every person who shall sell or offer to sell any goods, wares or merchandise or other personal property or any real estate or interest therein at any stand, store or other place in the city at public outcry for his own gain or who shall advertise or in any way hold himself out as an auctioneer for public patronage or who shall receive any fee as commission for his services. 
    Bakery means a business carried on or conducted by any person engaged in the sale or manufacture of bread or other bakery products. 
    Bakery trucks or wagons means trucks or wagons used in the business of selling or delivering bakery products by bakeries or businesses other than bakeries which have their places of business within the city. 
    Broker means a person dealing in stocks and securities or providing an investment service. 
    Circuses and menageries means all circuses, animal shows, wild west shows, menageries and traveling tent shows or museums. 
    Contractor means every person who, in pursuit of his independent business, undertakes to perform a job or piece of work, retaining in himself control of the means, method and manner of accomplishing the desired result, regardless of any limitation as to the means, method and manner of accomplishing the desired result. 
    Garage keeper means every person who shall keep any place or location where motor vehicles or any parts thereof are repaired, stored, cleaned or otherwise worked on. 
    Hotel, inn or public roominghouse means any house or building, the rooms and accommodations of which are offered to the traveling or transient public for hire. 
    Insurance agent means an agent who represents only one insurance company. 
    Insurance broker means a person who represents several insurance companies. 
    Junk and secondhand dealer means one of the following: 
(1)  Generally. Every person buying, selling or offering to buy or sell or in any manner dealing in junk and secondhand goods, with the exception of furniture and household goods, shall be deemed to be a junk or secondhand dealer. 
(2)  Itinerant junk and secondhand dealer. A junk or secondhand dealer temporarily engaged in the business in the city and not permanently located therein and not having any permanent stand or location therein shall be deemed to be an itinerant junk dealer. 
(3)  Regular junk and secondhand dealer. A junk or secondhand dealer having a permanent location in the city and a permanent place of business therein shall be deemed to be a regular junk or secondhand dealer. 
    Loan agent means every person, other than bankers or banking corporations or institutions, who, for a commission, negotiates, obtains or effects loans of money or real estate security or on collateral security or personal guarantees or who effects or negotiates for the purchase or sale of stocks, bonds, bills of exchange, bullion, coin, money or currency, promissory notes or other securities for himself or others. Every person thus defined who is not a licensed real estate agent must obtain a license provided for in section 22-38 before transacting any such business. 
    Newspaper agency means any person who shall engage in the regular daily distribution of daily metropolitan newspapers. 
    Posting agency means any person engaged in the business of posting on signboards, walls or other places bills, posters or other advertising matter or distributing in public places or from store to store or from house to house in the city circulars, handbills, samples or other advertising matter. 
    Public bus means any motor vehicle with a capacity of ten or more people offered to the public as a public bus business for the mere purpose of carrying or transporting passengers for a charge or fee. 
    Real estate agent means every person or firm composed of one or more persons who shall act as agent for any party in the leasing, renting or selling of houses or real estate at private or public sale or who shall receive or collect rents for another for a commission or other compensation or who shall advertise or hang out any sign or device which shall designate him as an agent for the renting, collecting of rents, leasing or selling of houses or real estate and every person who for commission or other compensation is engaged in the selling of or negotiating for the sale of real estate belonging to others. 
    Solicitor means any person who shall go about from place to place in the city selling or offering to sell work, services or merchandise of any kind. 
    Transient vendor means any person traveling either by foot, wagon, automobile, motor truck or any other type of conveyance within the city from place to place in and upon private residences or who shall make use of a telephone to take or attempt to take orders for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise or any personal property of whatever nature for future delivery or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such person has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sales. This definition shall include any person who, for himself or another person, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, tent, railroad boxcar, mobile home, boat, hotel room, lodginghouse, apartment, shop 
or any other place within the city for the sole purpose of whatever nature and taking orders for the sale of such property for future delivery. 
(Code 1980, § 16-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-2. - Enforcement; filing complaints; police record and report of new or changed businesses. 
(a)  The city clerk shall see that this chapter is fully complied with and shall file complaints against all persons known to be violating this chapter. 
(b)  During the normal course of patrol of a police officer, the officer shall make a report to the chief of police of each new place of business subject to license or occupation tax or of each change in or removal of any such business. Such report shall show the name of the person subject to license or occupation tax, the location of the place of business, the kind of business, the date of opening and the license number, if any. 
(c)  The chief of police shall make a report to the city clerk of all businesses subject to license or occupation tax which have been reported by city police, such reports to be accompanied by the city police report referred to therein. 
(Code 1980, § 16-15) 
Secs. 22-3-22-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUSINESS AND OCCUPATION LICENSES 

Sec. 22-26. - Required. 
    Every person who shall maintain, operate or conduct any of the businesses, trades, vocations, avocations or places of amusement or exercise the privileges specified in this chapter shall obtain a license and shall pay the license fee or tax prescribed in this chapter. 
(Code 1980, § 16-2) 
Sec. 22-27. - Application. 
(a)  Any person seeking a license required in this article shall file with the city clerk an application for such license, which application shall contain the following: 
(1)  The classification of the license to be obtained; 
(2)  The nature of the license; 
(3)  The place or location in the city at which the license shall be effective or the business shall be conducted; and 
(4)  If the application is for a license to carry on or conduct a business or vocation, a brief description of the nature of the business, setting forth the kind of merchandise to be sold or the nature of the business, vocation or service to be rendered by the applicant for a license. 
(b)  Condition precedent. No license provided for under this chapter shall hereafter be issued by the city clerk to any person or entity until the proposed licensee produces a copy of a retail sales license issued by the State of Missouri, a statement from the department of revenue that the licensee owes no tax due under RSMo 144.010-144.510 or RSMo 143.191-143.261 and proof that any and all tax, utility or other obligations of the proposed licensee to the city for all preceding years lawfully due shall have been paid. Any proposed licensee who is a contractor in the construction industry shall also be required to provide a certificate of insurance for worker's compensation coverage or an affidavit, the form of which shall be developed by the state division of labor and industrial relations, signed by the applicant attesting that the contractor is exempt from such requirement and no business license shall be issued to any contractor applicant failing to provide such certificate of insurance or affidavit. 
(Code 1980, § 16-3; Ord. No. 1241-09, § 1, 1-13-09) 
Sec. 22-28. - Classification of applicants; appeals from classification. 
    The city clerk shall classify all applicants for a license required in this article, putting them into appropriate classes, and issue appropriate licenses to them. Any person feeling aggrieved by his decision may pay his fee under protest and appeal within 30 days to the city council who shall have power to order the license canceled, the fee repaid and a new and more appropriate license issued. 
(Code 1980, § 16-4) 
Sec. 22-29. - Issuance. 
(a)  All licenses required by the city, unless otherwise specified in this chapter or by ordinance, shall be issued by the city clerk, subject to the approval of the city council. 
(b)  No license or permit shall be issued to any person owing the city any delinquent personal, merchants', or other city taxes until such taxes shall be paid in full to the city. 
(Code 1980, § 16-5) 
Sec. 22-30. - Record of licenses issued. 
    The city clerk shall keep an accurate record of all licenses issued, showing the nature of the business or acts licensed, the name and address of the licensee, the expiration date and any other information as he deems proper. 
(Code 1980, § 16-6) 
Sec. 22-31. - Proration. 
    When any person shall apply for a license from the city and the period for which the license shall run shall be less than 12 months, the license fee or tax charge shall be as follows: 
(1)  If such period is more than three months and less than six months, the license fee charged shall be one-half of the license fee charged for the full 12 months. 
(2)  If such period is more than six months and less than nine months, the license fee charged shall be three-fourths of the license fee charged for the full 12 months. 
(3)  If such period is for more than nine months, the license fee shall be the same as for 12 months. 
(Code 1980, § 16-7) 
Sec. 22-32. - Transfer or assignment. 
    All licenses issued by the city shall be deemed to be mere personal privileges and shall not be transferable or assignable without the consent of the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 16-8) 
Sec. 22-33. - Exhibition; inspection of licensed premises; display. 
(a)  No person operating under a city license shall refuse to exhibit his license to any city official or his deputy upon demand. 
(b)  Any police officer or other properly designated city official or employee shall have the power to enter any place requiring a license under this article during business hours, free of charge, to ascertain whether this chapter is being observed. 
(c)  Every person to whom a license shall be issued under this chapter shall keep the license conspicuously posted in his place of business. 
(Code 1980, § 16-9) 
Sec. 22-34. - Delinquency fee. 
    For each and every month or fraction thereof, except the month of March, that any license tax that remains unpaid, after such becomes due and payable, there shall be added to such license a delinquency fee of five percent per month of the amount of the license tax. The fee provided for in this section shall be in addition to any penalties provided for the violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1980, § 16-10) 
Sec. 22-35. - Revocation. 
(a)  All licenses are revocable at any time by the city council upon satisfactory proof that the licensee has: 
(1)  Violated this chapter or any of the ordinances of the city or any of the federal or state statutes relating to the business or acts done under the license; 
(2)  Misrepresented his goods or services sold or offered for sale in the city; 
(3)  Practiced any fraud upon the public; 
(4)  Sold for food for human beings or animals any unwholesome or unfit substances; 
(5)  Conducted a business not covered by his license; or 
(6)  Conducted any immoral or disorderly place of business dangerous to public health or safety or detrimental to public morals. 
(b)  If any license shall be terminated by revocation, death of the licensee or other cause, all fees or taxes paid the city therefor shall be forfeited to the use of the city. 
(c)  No person whose license has been revoked by the city council shall be entitled to engage in the business or do the acts for which the license was issued in the city unless the council, for good cause, shall remove such disqualifications. 
(Code 1980, § 16-11) 
Sec. 22-36. - Operating without license. 
    Any person engaged in any business, conducting any place or doing any act for which a license is required in the city without first having secured such license and performed the conditions relating thereto or, having obtained a license, violates any of the ordinances relating to his business shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and such conviction shall operate ipso facto, without action by the city council, as a revocation of such license. 
(Code 1980, § 16-12) 
Sec. 22-37. - Expiration. 
    All annual licenses issued by the city, unless specifically stated otherwise within this chapter or other ordinance, shall expire on March 1 of each year. 
(Code 1980, § 16-13) 
Sec. 22-38. - Same-Fees for businesses or occupations generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, whether by himself as owner or proprietor or through any office, manager, superintendent, agent, servant or employee to exercise, or carry on vocations, businesses or agencies within the corporate limits of the city without first taking out and having a license therefor; and the charge for such license shall be as set out in a schedule established by the council from time to time. 
(Code 1980, § 16-14) 
Sec. 22-39. - Pawnbrokers. 
    Pawnbrokers operating within the City of Fulton shall be required to furnish the city police department with copies of the following information as required by RSMo 367.031: 
(1)  The name and address of the pawnshop; 
(2)  The name and address of the pledgor, the pledgor's description, and the driver's license number, military identification number, identification certificate number, or other official number capable of identifying the pledgor; 
(3)  The date of the transaction; and 
(4)  An identification and description of the pledged goods, including serial number if reasonably available. 
    Upon satisfactory proof of failure to comply with this section, the city council in accordance with city Code section 22-35, may revoke the pawnbroker's business license. 
(Ord. No. 843-00, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Secs. 22-40-22-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CIGARETTE DEALERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 730-96, § 1, adopted Nov. 26, 1996, repealed the former Art. III, §§ 22-61-22-81 and enacted a new Art. III as set out herein. The former Art. III pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1980, §§ 16-27-16-47. 

Sec. 22-61. - Definitions. 
    When used in this article the following words shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Cigarette means a roll of tobacco or any substitute thereof wrapped in paper and used for smoking. 
    Consumer means a person who comes into possession of tobacco for the purpose of consuming it, giving it away or disposing of it in any way. 
    Dealer means any person dealing directly with the manufacturer of cigarettes in their purchase and in the business of selling cigarettes as a first seller doing any business in the city. 
    First seller means and includes all persons who make the initial or first sale or distribution of cigarettes within the city. 
    Occupation license tax means the tax imposed by the city under this article upon the business and for the privilege of selling cigarettes at retail in the city. 
    Package means the individual package, box or other container from which sales of cigarettes are normally made or intended to be made. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, society, association, joint stock company, corporation, estate, receiver, trustee, assignee, referee or other person acting in a fiduciary or representative capacity, whether appointed by a court or otherwise, or any combination of individuals. 
    Retailer includes persons other than a dealer or wholesaler as defined in this section, who is engaged in the business of selling cigarettes at retail, who shall sell or offer for sale cigarettes, irrespective of quantity, number of sales, giving the same away or exposing the same where it may be taken, or purchased, or otherwise acquired. 
    Sale means any transfer of title or possession or both, exchange or barter, conditional or otherwise, in any manner or by any means whatsoever, for a consideration, or any agreement therefor. 
    Vending machine operator includes all persons engaged in the distribution or sale of cigarettes by means of coin-operated vending machines. 
    Wholesaler includes persons whose principal business is that of a wholesale jobber and who is known to the trade as such, who sells cigarettes for only the purpose of resale or giving them away, or exposing the same where they may be taken or purchased or otherwise acquired by the retailer. 
(Ord. No. 730-96, § 1, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 22-62. - Occupation tax levy on sale of cigarettes. 
    Every dealer or wholesaler, as defined in section 22-61, engaged in the business of selling cigarettes or offering or displaying the same for sale within the city shall pay an occupation tax at the rate of $2.00 per 1,000 for all cigarettes sold or offered or displayed for sale. This tax shall be paid but once, as provided for in section 22-63, and only by the dealer selling cigarettes or displaying or offering them for sale. This is the one and only license or other tax that cigarette dealers or wholesalers shall pay. The intent and meaning of this article is that the same shall levy an occupation tax based upon and pursuant to the methods provided for by RSMo, 1959, Section 92.040, and pursuant to the powers therein granted and the powers contained in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 730-96, § 1, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 22-63. - Monthly payment. 
    It shall be the duty of every dealer or wholesaler, as defined in section 22-61, selling, offering or displaying for sale any package of cigarettes, to remit the monthly cigarette tax reporting form and full payment to the city clerk by the 15th day of each following month. The canceled check, accompanied by the monthly cigarette tax reporting form, shall be proof of payment. 
(Ord. No. 730-96, § 1, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 22-64. - Rules and regulations-Records. 
    For the purpose of enabling the city clerk to enforce the terms of this article, the following provisions are enacted: 
(1)  Each dealer in the city and those wholesalers and retailers as defined in section 22-61 shall procure and retain invoices showing the amount and value of the shipment of cigarettes received by him, the date thereof, and the name of the shipper, and shall retain this invoice for a period of three years subject to the use and inspection of the city clerk. 
(2)  All dealers, wholesalers and retailers as defined in section 22-61 within the city shall maintain and keep for a period of three years such other records of cigarettes received, sold or delivered within the city as may be required by the city clerk. 
(3)  The city clerk or his duly authorized representatives, are authorized to examine the books, papers, invoices and other records, stock of cigarettes in and upon any premises where they are placed, stored or sold, and equipment of any such dealer, wholesaler, or retailer pertaining to the sale and delivery of cigarettes taxable under this article. 
(4)  To verify the accuracy of the occupation tax imposed and assessed by this article, each person, as defined in section 22-61, is directed and required to give to the city clerk or his duly authorized representatives, the means, facilities and opportunity for such examinations as are provided for and required by this article. 
(5)  In addition to the power granted by this article to the city clerk, he is authorized and empowered to prescribe, adopt, promulgate and enforce rules and regulations relating to the delegation of his powers to a deputy or other employee of his office and any other matter or thing pertaining to the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article. 
(6)  Cigarette tax reporting information received from the state shall be held in confidence and used solely for verifying cigarette tax payments. 
(Ord. No. 730-96, § 1, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 22-65. - Refunds. 
    The city clerk is authorized to adopt, prescribe and promulgate rules and regulations including a monthly cigarette tax reporting form with regard to the presentation and proof of claim for refunds and credits as he may deem advisable. 
(Ord. No. 730-96, § 1, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 22-66. - Oaths and subpoenas. 
    The city clerk or his employees or agents duly designated and authorized by him shall have power to administer oaths and take affidavits in relation to any matter or proceedings in the exercise of their powers and duties under this article. The city clerk shall have power to subpoena and require the attendance of witnesses and the production of books, papers and documents to secure information pertinent to the enforcement of this article and to examine them in relation thereto. 
(Ord. No. 730-96, § 1, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 22-67. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating this article by failing to file the report and make the payment provided for in section 22-63 shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 or imprisoned for not more than 90 days or be punished by both such fine and imprisonment. Failure to file each monthly report and make each monthly payment shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 730-96, § 1, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 22-68. - Dealers outside city. 
    Any dealer whose place of business is outside the corporate limits of the city shall be bound by all of the provisions of this article for any business conducted within the corporate boundaries of the city. 
(Ord. No. 730-96, § 1, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 22-69. - Severability clause. 
    The provisions of this article shall be severable. In the event that any provision of this article is found by a court of competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional, the remaining provisions of this article are valid unless the court finds the valid provisions of this article are so essentially and inseparably connected with, and so dependent upon, the void provision that it cannot be presumed that the city would have enacted the valid provisions without the void ones or unless the court finds that the valid provisions, standing alone, are incomplete and incapable of being executed in accordance with the legislative intent. 
(Ord. No. 730-96, § 1, 11-26-96) 
Secs. 22-70-22-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MERCHANTS 

Sec. 22-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Merchant means a person who deals in the selling any goods, wares or merchandise at any store, stand or place occupied for such purpose within the city, except as otherwise provided by ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 16-59) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-102. - Applicability of certain sections to article. 
    Sections 22-1, 22-2, 22-26 through 22-30, 22-32, 22-33, and 22-35 through 22-37, with the exception of section 22-31, shall apply to this article. 
(Code 1980, § 16-64) 
Sec. 22-103. - License required; application; inspection of records. 
(a)  Every merchant, before doing or offering to do business as such, shall procure from the city clerk a license for his business pursuant to this article. 
(b)  Any person required to obtain a license under this article, the amount of whose license shall be determined otherwise, shall, at the time of applying for such license, file with the city clerk a proper application, signed under the penalties of perjury, by the person applying for such license or someone for him, showing such information as may be required to fix the amount of such license. Any person who shall for himself or for some other person make a false statement shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(c)  Any inspection of records, as provided by this section, shall be done at the direction of the city council only and shall be for the sole purpose of determining compliance with this article. The person doing the annual audit for the city shall be the only authorized authority permitted to make this inspection, and such person shall not disclose any information so obtained to any other person, but shall merely state whether or not the business being inspected is in the properly designated category. 
(d)  For the purpose of this inspection, the business copies of the state sales tax returns covering the period in question shall be deemed sufficient. 
(Code 1980, § 16-60) 
Sec. 22-104. - Separate license for each business; fee for engaging in more than one business. 
(a)  Under this article, if a person shall operate a business in more than one location but all are operated as parts of one business, the license required shall be for the one business and not each separate part. 
(b)  Under this article, separately identified businesses must be separately licensed. When any merchant or corporation is engaged in more than one of the businesses, trades or occupations named in this chapter for which a separate license shall be required, the amount of this license shall be two-thirds of the total of the licenses required for the separate businesses. For this purpose, one wholesale and one retail business operated from the same location are separate businesses. 
(Code 1980, § 16-61) 
Sec. 22-105. - Form of license. 
    The city clerk shall furnish blank merchant licenses, which licenses shall be in the form prescribed by section 22-27. 
(Code 1980, § 16-62) 
Sec. 22-106. - Tax. 
(a)  Retail and wholesale merchants shall pay the tax specified in a schedule adopted by the council from time to time, based on a total gross volume of business or receipts for the previous calendar year. 
(b)  Every such person commencing any business shall procure a temporary license and pay therefor the minimum amount applicable to such business and at the next succeeding March 1 or September 1, whichever date is sooner, shall obtain a new license. The amount of such license tax will be determined and computed on a pro rata average gross business basis during the term such business was conducted under a temporary license, and such monthly average shall be multiplied by 12 or six, if a half-year license is required, to obtain the yearly anticipated gross sales or receipts. For each and every succeeding year thereafter, the amount of such license tax will be determined on a gross business basis per year as provided in this section. 
(Code 1980, § 16-63) 
Secs. 22-107-22-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - UTILITY OCCUPATION TAXES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 22-126-22-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TELEPHONE SERVICE 

Sec. 22-136. - Levied. 
(a)  Every person engaged in the business of supplying telecommunication service for any purpose in the city shall pay to the city clerk, by the 15th of the second month after the first month of doing business, a monthly license tax equal to 8 percent of each month's gross receipts from such business (maximum allowable by law pursuant to information received from Missouri Department of Revenue). 
(b)  This monthly license tax shall be due on the 15th of each month and shall be based on 8 percent of the gross receipts for the preceding month. 
(Code 1980, § 16-113; Ord. No. 1136-06, § 1, 4-25-06; Ord. No. 1149-06, § 1, 10-24-06) 
Sec. 22-137. - Statement of gross receipts; investigation by clerk. 
    Every person engaged in the business of supplying telephone service for any purpose in the city shall file with the city clerk, on June 15 and December 15 of each year a sworn statement of the gross receipts from such business for the six calendar months preceding April 1, in the case of the June 15 report, and October 1, in the case of the December 15 report. The city clerk or his duly authorized deputy is authorized to investigate the correctness and accuracy of the statement required for that purpose and shall have access at all reasonable times to the books, documents, papers and records of any person making such statement in order to ascertain the accuracy thereof. 
(Code 1980, § 16-114) 
Sec. 22-138. - Construction of division. 
    The license tax required in this division shall be in lieu of any other occupation tax required of any person engaged in the business of supplying telephone service for any purpose in the city; provided, however, that nothing contained in this division shall be so construed as to exempt any such person from the payment to the city of the tax which the city levies upon real or personal property belonging to any such person nor the tax required of merchants or manufacturers for the sale of anything other than telephone service nor shall the tax required by this division exempt any such person from the payment of any other tax which may be lawfully required other than an occupation tax on the business of supplying telephone service. 
(Code 1980, § 16-115) 
Secs. 22-139-22-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - COIN-OPERATED SERVICES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-161. - Gambling devices. 
(a)  Prohibition. Nothing in this article shall in any way be construed to authorize, license or permit any gambling device whatsoever or any mechanism that has been judicially determined to be a gambling device or in any way contrary to law, and no license shall be issued pursuant to this article upon any machine or mechanical device which under the law constitutes a gambling device. 
(b)  Seizure and destruction. If the chief of police shall have reason to believe any device required to be licensed under this article is being used as a gambling device, such machine may be seized by the police and impounded, and if, upon trial of the exhibitor for allowing it to be used as a gambling device, the exhibitor is found guilty, such machine shall be destroyed by the police. 
(Code 1980, § 16-125) 
Secs. 22-162-22-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MECHANICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICE LICENSES 

Sec. 22-171. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Mechanical amusement device means any machine which, upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disk, may be operated by the public generally for use as a game, entertainment or amusement, whether or not registering a score. The term includes such devices as marble machines, skill ball, mechanical grab machines and all games, operations or transactions similar thereto under whatever name they may be indicated. 
    Person includes the following: 
(1)  Any person who owns any coin-operated machine; 
(2)  The person in whose place of business any coin-operated machine is placed for use by the public; and 
(3)  The person having control over any coin-operated machine; 
provided, however, the payment of the license fee by any one of such persons enumerated in this definition shall be deemed a compliance with this division. 
(Code 1980, § 16-133) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-172. - Required generally. 
    Any person displaying for public patronage or keeping for operation any mechanical amusement device shall be required to obtain a license from the city. 
(Code 1980, § 16-135) 
Sec. 22-173. - Required for each machine. 
    Not more than one machine shall be operated under one license required by this division, and the applicant or licensee shall be required to secure a license for each machine displayed or operated by him. 
(Code 1980, § 16-143) 
Sec. 22-174. - Application; qualifications of applicant. 
(a)  Application for the license required in this division shall be made to the city clerk. 
(b)  The application for such license shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address. 
(2)  Age, date and place of birth of the applicant. 
(3)  Prior convictions of applicant, if any. 
(4)  Place where machine or device is to be displayed or operated and the business conducted at that place. 
(5)  Description, mechanical features, name of manufacturer and serial number of the machine to be covered by the license. 
(c)  No license shall be issued to any applicant unless he shall be over 21 years of age and a citizen of the United States. 
(Code 1980, § 16-136) 
Sec. 22-175. - Application in duplicate. 
    Application for a license required in this division shall be made out in duplicate, one copy being referred to the chief of police and the other copy to the city electrical inspector or electric department. 
(Code 1980, § 16-137) 
Sec. 22-176. - Approval or disapproval of application. 
(a)  The chief of police shall investigate the location wherein it is proposed to operate the machine for which a license is being sought as required by this division, ascertain if the applicant is a person of good moral character and either approve or disapprove the application. 
(b)  The electrical inspector shall inspect all wiring and connections to the machine, determine if the wiring complies with the electrical code of the city and shall either approve or disapprove the application. 
(Code 1980, § 16-138) 
Sec. 22-177. - Fee. 
    Every applicant for a license required in this division, before being granted such license, shall pay an annual license fee for the privilege of operating or maintaining for operation each mechanical amusement device. The fee shall be established by the city council from time to time. 
(Code 1980, § 16-139) 
Sec. 22-178. - Issuance. 
    No license required in this division shall be issued to any applicant unless his application is approved by the chief of police and the electrical inspector pursuant to section 22-172. 
(Code 1980, § 16-140) 
Sec. 22-179. - Posting. 
    The license required by this division shall be posted permanently and conspicuously at the location of the machine in the premises wherein the device is to be operated or maintained to be operated. 
(Code 1980, § 16-141) 
Sec. 22-180. - Expiration date. 
    Each license issued under this division shall expire on the last day of February each year. 
(Code 1980, § 16-142) 
Sec. 22-181. - Transfer to new machine or device. 
    The license required in this division may be transferred from one machine or device to another similar machine upon application to the city clerk to such effect and upon giving a description and the serial number of the new machine or device. 
(Code 1980, § 16-144) 
Sec. 22-182. - Transfer when licensee moves place of business. 
    If any person licensed pursuant to this division shall move his place of business to another location within the city, the license may be transferred to such new location upon application to the city clerk, giving the street and number of the new location. The new location shall be approved by the chief of police and the city electrical inspector in the same manner as required in section 22-176. 
(Code 1980, § 16-145) 
Sec. 22-183. - Revocation. 
(a)  Every license issued pursuant to this division may be revoked should the licensee, directly or indirectly, permit the operation of any mechanical amusement device contrary to this division, the ordinances of the city or state law. 
(b)  Every license issued pursuant to this division may be revoked by the city council after written notice to the licensee, which notice shall specify the ordinance or law violations with which the licensee is charged and if, after a hearing, the licensee is found guilty of such violations. 
(c)  Ten days' notice of the hearing shall be given the licensee. At such hearing the licensee and his attorney may present and submit evidence of witnesses in his defense. 
(Code 1980, § 16-146) 
Sec. 22-184. - Inspections. 
    The police department shall make regular inspections to ascertain compliance with this division. 
(Code 1980, § 16-134) 
Secs. 22-185-22-205. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ORGANIZED TRADE FAIR AND CRAFT SHOWS 

Sec. 22-206. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Organized trade fair and craft show means the sale or offering for sale of miscellaneous goods, wares or merchandise to the public under the auspices of any organization, under generally informal circumstances in the city and not on a regular basis as limited in section 22-206. 
(Code 1980, § 16-161) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-207. - Limitation on number. 
    No organized trade fair and craft show may be held by any organization more frequently than three times in any calendar year. No such sale shall be held for more than three consecutive days. Any activity in the nature of a trade fair and craft show which occurs more frequently than limited in this section shall be deemed the establishment of a mercantile business, and the person or organization engaging in such business shall be deemed a merchant within the meaning of that term as defined in section 22-101. 
(Code 1980, § 16-162) 
Sec. 22-208. - Permit required; application; fee. 
(a)  Anyone desiring to hold an organized trade fair and craft show shall first apply for and obtain from the city clerk a permit to be issued on forms approved by the clerk. 
(b)  The application for such permit shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address, and telephone number of the applicant. 
(2)  The proposed dates for holding the organized trade fair and craft show. 
(3)  The proposed location of the fair or show. 
(4)  A statement to the effect that the applicant has not applied for or obtained three such permits within the calendar year for which this permit is sought, such statement to be signed by the applicant under oath. 
(c)  Such application shall be accompanied by a permit fee established by the city council from time to time. 
(d)  Any person not in compliance with this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1980, § 16-163) 
Sec. 22-209. - Permit forfeiture for false statements in application. 
    If any statement made in the application for a permit required by this article is false, any permit issued pursuant thereto shall be forfeited ipso facto, and the applicant shall be deemed guilty of making a false affidavit and shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1980, § 16-164) 
Chapter 30 - CEMETERIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Historic preservation, ch. 62; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98; traffic and vehicles, ch. 110. 
State Law reference- Vital statistics, RSMo 193.010 et seq.; transportation and disposition of dead bodies, RSMo 194.010 et seq.; cemeteries generally, RSMo 214.010 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Pioneer Cemetery designated. 
    The plot of ground originally known as the Old Cemetery and located in the northwest corner of block 56 according to the new city plat of the city as recorded in plat book 3, pages 44 and 72, records of the county, and being on the south side of West Fourth Street of the city, except for that portion lying in Westminster Avenue, shall be officially known and designated as the Pioneer Cemetery. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1) 
Sec. 30-2. - Hillcrest Cemetery designated. 
    The tracts of ground as shown in plat book 1, page 58, survey book S, page 102, and warranty deed in book 252, page 508, records of the county, and being bounded on the north by East Eighth Street and Smith Branch, on the west by Hillcrest Street and on the south and east by the property of the Missouri School for the Deaf shall be officially known and designated as the Hillcrest Cemetery. 
(Code 1980, § 7-2) 
Sec. 30-3. - Southside Cemetery designated. 
    The tracts of ground as shown in plat book 3, pages 43 and 71 and plat book 7, page 86, third addition, records of the county, shall be known as the Southside Cemetery. 
(Code 1980, § 7-3) 
Sec. 30-4. - Conveyance procedures. 
    All conveyances made in the cemeteries by the city or owners shall be by a certificate showing grave, lot and block number as shown on the plat of the respective cemetery on file with the city clerk. 
(Code 1980, § 7-3.1) 
Sec. 30-5. - Duties of city engineer and sexton. 
    It shall be the duty of the city engineer and sexton to lay off all graves in the city-owned cemeteries and perform such other duties and work as directed by the streets and sidewalks committee of the council, and all burials shall be done under their supervision. 
(Code 1980, § 7-81) 
Sec. 30-6. - Workers subject to control of city engineer and sexton. 
    All workers employed in the construction of vaults, erecting monuments or other similar activities in the cemeteries shall be subject to the control and direction of the city engineer or sexton. 
(Code 1980, § 7-82) 
Sec. 30-7. - Special permit for certain workers. 
    Any worker failing to conform to section 30-6 shall not be permitted afterwards to work in the cemetery, unless such person shall have a special permit from the council, signed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk, which permit may be revoked at any time. 
(Code 1980, § 7-83) 
Sec. 30-8. - Penalty. 
    Any person convicted of a violation of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1980, § 7-84) 
Sec. 30-9. - Establishment of grades; responsibility for improvements. 
    The city shall establish the grade of all graves, lawns and avenues and shall direct generally all improvements within the cemeteries, upon all graves, before as well as after interments have been made therein. The city will have charge of all planting, sodding, surveying and improvements generally at the cemeteries. 
(Code 1980, § 7-8) 
Sec. 30-10. - Planting. 
    Permanent plantings of grasses, shrubs, flowers, etc., in cemeteries are made by the city, and private plantings may be permitted only at the discretion of the sexton. The purchase of the graves does not confer any right to do planting, etc., without the express approval of the proper officials of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 7-10) 
Sec. 30-11. - Traffic rules. 
(a)  No person or vehicle will be allowed to enter the cemetery, except through regular entrances maintained for the public for such purpose, without the permission of the sexton. 
(b)  The use of roads and paths in the cemeteries as thoroughfares or public highways, either by vehicles or on foot, is prohibited. Violators of this subsection shall be considered as trespassers. 
(c)  There shall be no driving allowed over the graves or upon the lawns under any pretense whatsoever, except for the normal maintenance and operation of the cemeteries. 
(d)  Buses, trucks or other conveyances of cumbersome description will not be allowed to enter the grounds, except by special permission. 
(e)  Admission of vehicles upon the roads of the cemetery will be permitted as a privilege and not as a right inherent to the purchase of a grave or otherwise. As a privilege it is restricted to those who observe the traffic rules adopted by the city officials. 
(f)  The speed limit for vehicles is limited to a maximum of 15 miles per hour. 
(g)  Vehicles are not permitted to make U-turns upon roads, but must go around the section. 
(h)  Visitors on foot have the primary right to the use of the roads, and all vehicle drivers are required to observe their right by careful driving and a strict adherence to the rules. 
(i)  Drivers will carefully observe and obey any traffic signs or markings displayed in the cemeteries. 
(j)  Any driver who runs any vehicle upon the lawns, across gutters or anywhere else where damage results therefrom shall be required to make good such damages. 
(k)  The sounding of horns, sirens or other audible signals within the cemetery is prohibited, except in connection with a funeral service. 
(Code 1980, § 7-15) 
Sec. 30-12. - Visitors. 
(a)  The cemeteries are open to visitors from 7:00 a.m. to sunset, from April 1 to October 31 and from 8:00 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. from November 1 to March 31. 
(b)  All visitors are expected to respect the solemnity and beauty of the cemetery and strictly observe the rules established by the city for the purpose of securing quiet and good order at all times within the cemeteries. 
(c)  Children under age 16 without permission of the sexton will be excluded at all times, unless accompanied by an adult who will be responsible for their conduct. School children under supervision of a teacher, art students, botanists, ornithologists, students of forestry or others who may benefit from a study of the works of art and nature will be welcome to the cemeteries. 
(d)  All persons are strictly prohibited from plucking any plants, whether wild or cultivated, disturbing birds, breaking or injuring any tree or shrub, fountain, pool, tower or in any way defacing the grounds of the cemeteries. 
(e)  The proprietors of graves and their families shall be allowed access to the grounds of city cemeteries at any time during normal operating hours or otherwise by permission. 
(f)  The city engineer shall have the right to order from the cemetery any person who has no business therein at any time. 
(Code 1980, § 7-16) 
Sec. 30-13. - Removal of detrimental or dangerous trees or shrubs. 
    If any trees or shrubs situated on any grave shall, because of their roots, branches or otherwise, become detrimental to the adjacent lots, avenues or streets or dangerous or inconvenient to passersby, the city engineer shall enter upon such grave and remove such trees or shrubs or parts thereof as may be detrimental, dangerous or inconvenient. 
(Code 1980, § 7-17) 
Sec. 30-14. - Corner posts. 
    All corner posts in cemeteries shall be level with the ground so that it will be possible for a lawnmower to pass over them. 
(Code 1980, § 7-18) 
Sec. 30-15. - Pond or fence enclosure prohibited; grounds to be uniform. 
    No pond or fence enclosure shall be built, kept or maintained within city cemetery grounds, and the ground shall be placed and kept in a uniform condition. 
(Code 1980, § 7-19) 
Secs. 30-16-30-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - INTERMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-36. - Certain forms of burial prohibited. 
    Any form of burial which will leave the remains above the level of the ground is prohibited, except in a mausoleum approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1980, § 7-30) 
Sec. 30-37. - Grave space costs. 
    The cost of grave spaces in city cemeteries shall be $200.00 for a standard four-foot by ten-foot grave space and $120.00 for a four-foot by five-foot grave space. 
(Code 1980, § 7-31) 
Sec. 30-38. - Perpetual care cemetery fund. 
(a)  Under RSMo 214.020 there is established a perpetual care cemetery fund for Hillcrest Cemetery and Southside Cemetery owned by the city. 
(b)  Ten percent of the income derived from sale of lots in Hillcrest Cemetery and Southside Cemetery shall be deposited in the perpetual care cemetery fund. Such funds shall be invested from time to time in United States government bonds or of the state or may be placed in any bank or savings and loan association which is authorized to do business in this state, so long as the funds so deposited are protected by federal deposit insurance. 
(c)  The principal of the perpetual care cemetery fund shall not be used for any purpose whatsoever and no money shall be transferred out of such perpetual care cemetery fund except for the purpose of being invested and for repurchase of cemetery lots previously sold. 
(d)  The income derived from the perpetual care cemetery fund shall be used for the preservation, care, upkeep and adornment of such cemeteries or the repurchasing of cemetery lots previously sold and for no other purpose. 
(Code 1980, § 7-31.1) 
Sec. 30-39. - Interment procedures. 
(a)  The number of interments which may properly be made upon a grave in cemeteries is definitely fixed at one per grave space at the time of purchase, and no more will be permitted. 
(b)  The arrangement and location of graves upon a lot is determined by the city, as it is necessary that uniformity shall prevail. 
(c)  No interment may be made unless the remains are accompanied by a city burial permit or written approval by the city clerk's office. 
(d)  Except in emergency cases, one working day's notice is required for the preparation of a grave, and interments are not to be made before 10:00 a.m. or after 4:00 p.m. 
(e)  No bands are allowed to enter the cemetery except for a funeral or on Memorial Day or at other times by permission from the sexton. 
(f)  As a minimum, all standard interments will incorporate the use of a casket and a concrete grave liner with lid in which the casket will be placed. Cremated or infant interments shall incorporate the use of a container approved by the city engineer. 
(g)  Normal graves will be four feet wide by ten feet long and may be used for either one standard burial or two cremated burials. Additionally, some four-foot by five-foot graves are available and can be used for one cremated burial or one memorial grave. 
(Code 1980, § 7-32) 
Sec. 30-40. - Permission from mayor required for disinterments. 
    Disinterments will be allowed only upon notarized written consent or request of the purchaser of the grave or surviving heirs of a deceased purchaser or by appropriate court order and only after permission in writing is first obtained from the mayor and in accordance with state law. 
(Code 1980, § 7-33) 
Charter reference- Mayor to sign instruments binding the city, § 4.3(f). 
Sec. 30-41. - Interments for remuneration prohibited. 
    No owner shall allow interments in his grave spaces for remuneration. 
(Code 1980, § 7-34) 
Sec. 30-42. - Owner to designate intended interments. 
    Whenever possible, the owner of a grave is required, during his lifetime, to designate in writing to the city the names of those members of his family or others whom he wishes to have interred upon the grave. Such writing will be filed with the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1980, § 7-35) 
Secs. 30-43-30-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CERTIFICATE AND CITY BURIAL PERMIT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 

Sec. 30-56. - Required. 
    The city engineer shall not allow any person to be buried in a city cemetery unless a city burial permit or written permission has first been obtained from the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1980, § 7-40) 
Sec. 30-57. - Information required for burial. 
    All burial permits issued for burial in city cemeteries must state the name, age, residence, date of death, type of enclosure and time of interment of the person to be buried, the length of the graves required and the lot and block number in which the grave is to be dug. 
(Code 1980, § 7-41) 
Sec. 30-58. - Issuance restricted. 
    No city burial permit shall be issued to bury in any grave purchased or conveyed after April 8, 1920, unless such grave is conveyed directly from the city to the person demanding the permit or to the heir of such person or to an ancestor from whom the applicant shall have derived title by descent. 
(Code 1980, § 7-42) 
Sec. 30-59. - Reburials. 
    All reburials shall require a new city burial permit. 
(Code 1980, § 7-45) 
Sec. 30-60. - Burial permit and disinterment fees. 
(a)  The cost of burial permits and disinterments shall be as established by the city council from time to time. 
(b)  For any special request for the closing of graves after 5:00 p.m. any day of the week, the cost shall be the same as for weekends and holidays. 
(c)  No permit shall be granted until the price specified has been paid. 
(Code 1980, § 7-46) 
Secs. 30-61-30-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GRAVES 

Sec. 30-81. - Right to use of grave. 
    Upon the death or judicially declared incompetency of a grave owner, it is the duty of the heirs, devisees, guardian or personal representative to file with the city competent proof of their right to the use of the grave and burials upon the grave may not be permitted until such proof is presented. 
(Code 1980, § 7-4) 
Sec. 30-82. - City's right of access. 
    The city reserves unto itself the right of ingress and egress over all graves at all times. 
(Code 1980, § 7-5) 
Sec. 30-83. - Markers. 
    All locations of grave markers and their foundations shall be approved by the city engineer and erected by and at the expense of the party purchasing them. 
(Code 1980, § 7-54) 
Sec. 30-84. - Depth of vault. 
    Each vault in a cemetery shall be covered by at least 32 inches of soil. 
(Code 1980, § 7-55) 
Sec. 30-85. - Level with the ground. 
    All graves shall be kept level with the ground. 
(Code 1980, § 7-56) 
Sec. 30-86. - Rights of purchasers; certificate of purchase. 
(a)  The purchaser of a cemetery lot shall have the right to set no more than one approved tree on each lot. 
(b)  No live shrubs or vines of any kind shall be planted or put upon any grave in the cemeteries belonging to the city except such as shall meet the approval of the city engineer, and only such graves as conform to this section shall receive care from the city. 
(c)  The city clerk shall issue a certificate to the purchaser showing the location of the grave and granting the right of interment by issuance of a city burial permit for each grave. 
(Code 1980, § 7-57) 
Sec. 30-87. - Purchase and use restricted. 
    No person shall be permitted to own more than ten graves in a city cemetery at one time or to purchase or hold any grave for any other purpose than for burial. 
(Code 1980, § 7-58) 
Sec. 30-88. - Use of graves only for burial or memorial. 
    The graves in the three city cemeteries shall be sold only for the purpose of burying human remains or for establishing memorials to deceased humans. 
(Code 1980, § 7-58.1) 
Sec. 30-89. - Sale or transfer. 
    No purchaser of any grave or part of a grave by certificate in a city cemetery shall sell or transfer it or any part thereof to any private person. However, the city shall at all times be required to pay to such purchaser who desires to dispose of the unoccupied grave space or to his heirs an amount equal to 100 percent of the purchase price. When unoccupied grave spaces are returned to the city, the original deed shall also be returned. If a grave space is transferred, it shall be by endorsement of the certificate and shall be made at the expense of the endorser. 
(Code 1980, § 7-59) 
Sec. 30-90. - Transfer of graves with consent of city. 
    The grave owner cannot sell or convey any grave in a cemetery without first obtaining the written consent of the city. All transfers must be made through the city clerk. 
(Code 1980, § 7-60) 
Sec. 30-91. - Curbing, fencing or railing. 
    No person shall be allowed to put curbing around any grave in any cemetery under the control of the city. Care shall not be given by the city to any grave upon which the curbing, fencing or railing has not been removed except for existing curbing, fencing or railing. 
(Code 1980, § 7-61) 
Sec. 30-92. - Filling of graves. 
    The material used in the filling of graves shall be good, clean earth. Any owner of a grave which is low or swags because of the topography thereon or because of the height of surrounding graves which have been formerly filled shall have the right to fill his grave to a depth that will make it conform to or harmonize with the surrounding graves. Where the ground of a grave and that of adjacent graves has a uniform slope, the owner will be permitted to grade his grave to a depth of 12 inches; provided, however, the general plans of filling shall be done in accordance with the rules that may be made by the city engineer, which rules shall conform as near as may be to this section. 
(Code 1980, § 7-63) 
Sec. 30-93. - Donations for care of graves. 
    All donations or bequests made by any person for the care of any particular grave in the cemetery shall be made to the city, which funds, so received, shall be used as provided in the gift or devise or in the manner provided in the rules of the city where no special provision is made. The cost of managing the fund and doing the work shall be from time to time deducted therefrom. 
(Code 1980, § 7-64) 
Sec. 30-94. - Individual grave markers required. 
(a)  All graves must be marked by a permanent grave marker within one year of the date of burial. Temporary grave markers are allowed to mark the grave site until a permanent grave marker is erected. 
(b)  Certain areas of Hillcrest and Southside Cemeteries have been reserved for flush-type flat markers only. All other areas allow the use of either upright tombstones or flat markers. All grave markings are subject to approval by the city pursuant to section 30-83. 
(Code 1980, § 7-65) 
Sec. 30-95. - Ornamentation. 
(a)  The city retains control and supervision of all graves which are sold, and the city retains the right to have its sexton enter upon any grave and prohibit, modify or remove any structure, object, improvement or adornment on such grave which may have been placed thereon in violation of the rules or which may be considered a nuisance or injurious to the public. 
(b)  Baskets; glass, crockery, wire, metal or any other kind of receptacle for flowers; glass cases; boxes containing artificial flowers, wreaths, etc., will not be permitted upon any grave, except as set forth under section 30-97. 
(Code 1980, § 7-66) 
Sec. 30-96. - Potted plants. 
    Persons may place memorials, flowers and potted plants on graves for five working days or until removed subject to the rules provided by this article. 
(Code 1980, § 7-67) 
Sec. 30-97. - Cut flowers. 
(a)  Receptacles for cut flowers will be allowed on graves when sunk below the surface of the lawn so that they do not obstruct the lawnmower or appear unsightly when not filled with flowers. 
(b)  Upon request at the sexton's office, any particular basket or design may be stored for a period not exceeding one week after removal. If not called for in this period, it may be otherwise disposed of, without right of claim by the owner. 
(Code 1980, § 7-68) 
Sec. 30-98. - Emblems. 
    Metal emblems or markers, flags and guidons are prohibited on graves, except to celebrate Memorial Day and Veterans Day. They may be placed by authorized representatives of lodges, posts, camps, etc., not to exceed two days before Memorial Day or Veterans Day and removed not later than three days thereafter. Thereafter, such emblems will be removed from the grave by the cemetery employees and stored for a maximum of seven days, at no risk to the city. It is preferable that all such emblems be removed by the organization or person placing them. 
(Code 1980, § 7-69) 
Chapter 34 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 
Footnotes:
