Cross reference- General penalty for Code violations, § 1-20; courts, ch. 38; stormwater runoff and management, § 46-56 et seq.; fire prevention and protection, ch. 50; floods, ch. 54; law enforcement, ch. 70; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 78; planning, ch. 86; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98; traffic and vehicles, ch. 110; utilities, ch. 114; zoning regulations, app. A. 
State Law reference- Civil defense, RSMo ch. 44. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 34-1. - Adoption of the National Incident Management System (NIMS). 
    The city has formally adopted the National Incident Management System (NIMS) as the standard for incident management. 
(Ord. No. 1454-18, § 2, 1-9-18) 
Secs. 34-2-34-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LOCAL ORGANIZATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Establishment of local disaster planning organization required, RSMo 44.080. 

Sec. 34-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Chief executive officer means the mayor or other official appointed by the city council or elected by the public to administer the city government and its operations. 
(Code 1980, § 8-16) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 34-27. - Establishment and composition of emergency management agency. 
(a)  There is created within and for the city an emergency preparedness organization to be known as the city emergency management agency, which is responsible for the preparation and implementation of emergency functions required to prevent, minimize and repair injury and damage due to disasters, to include emergency management of resources and administration of such economic controls as may be needed to provide for the welfare of the people, and emergency activities, excluding functions for which military forces are primarily responsible, in accordance with RSMo 44.080 and the state disaster operations plan adopted thereunder. 
(b)  This organization shall consist of a director and other additional members to be appointed by the mayor to conform to the state organization and procedures for the conduct of emergency operations as outlined in the state disaster operations plan. 
(Code 1980, § 8-17) 
Sec. 34-28. - Functions. 
    The municipal organization created by this article shall perform such emergency preparedness functions within the city as shall be prescribed in and by the state Disaster Operations Plan and program prepared by the governor and such orders, rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the governor and, in addition, shall perform such duties outside the corporate limits as may be required pursuant to any mutual aid agreement with any other political subdivision, municipality or quasimunicipality, entered into as provided by RSMo 44.090 and the state disaster operations plan. 
(Code 1980, § 8-18) 
Sec. 34-29. - Oath of members. 
    No person shall be employed or associated in any capacity in any organization established under this article who advocates or has advocated a change by force or violence in the constitutional form of the government of the United States or in this state or the overthrow of any government in the United States by force or violence or who has been convicted of or is under indictment or information charging any subversive act against the United States. Each person who is appointed to serve in such organization shall, before entering upon his duties, take an oath, in writing, before a person authorized to administer oaths in this state, which oath shall be substantially as follows: 
"I, ___________, do so solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Missouri against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence; and that during such a time as I am a member of the (name of the disaster or emergency organization), I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence." 
(Code 1980, § 8-19) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 44.115. 
Sec. 34-30. - Office space. 
    The mayor or city council is authorized to designate space in any city-owned or city-leased building for the organization established under this article as its office. 
(Code 1980, § 8-20) 
Sec. 34-31. - Director. 
    The director of the organization established by this article will be appointed by the mayor and shall serve during the pleasure of the mayor. The director's responsibilities include the following: 
(1)  The director shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration and operations of local emergency preparedness activities. 
(2)  The director shall be responsible for maintaining records and accounting for the use and disposal of all items of equipment placed under the jurisdiction of the emergency management office. 
(Code 1980, § 8-21) 
Sec. 34-32. - Executive officers' authority. 
    The mayor and the director of the organization established by this article, in accordance with RSMo 44.080(2) and 44.090, may: 
(1)  Expend funds, make contracts, obtain and distribute equipment, materials and supplies for emergency preparedness purposes; provide for the health and safety of persons, including emergency assistance to victims of an enemy attack, and for the safety of property; and direct and coordinate the development of disaster plans and programs in accordance with the policies and plans of the federal and state disaster and emergency planning. 
(2)  Appoint, provide or remove rescue teams, auxiliary fire and police personnel and other emergency operations teams, units or personnel who may serve without compensation. 
(3)  In an enemy attack, waive the provisions of statutes requiring advertisements for bids for the performance of public work or entering into contracts. 
(4)  With the approval of the governor and consistent with the state disaster operations plan, enter into mutual aid agreements with other public and private agencies within and without the state for reciprocal aid. 
(5)  Accept services, materials, equipment, supplies or funds granted or loaned by the federal government for disaster planning and operations purposes. 
(Code 1980, § 8-22) 
Sec. 34-33. - Mobile support units. 
    The director of the organization created by this article shall form mobile support units as provided for in RSMo 44.080, and the state disaster operations plan and shall designate the leaders thereof. Any member of a mobile support team who is a municipal employee or officer, while serving on call to duty by the governor or the state director of civil defense, shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights and immunities incident to such employment or office. 
(Code 1980, § 8-23) 
Sec. 34-34. - Mutual aid agreements. 
(a)  The mayor, with the approval of the governor, may enter into mutual aid arrangements or agreements with other public and private agencies within and without the state for reciprocal emergency aid. Such arrangements or agreements shall be consistent with the state survival plan, and in time of emergency it shall be the duty of each local organization for disaster operations to render assistance in accordance with the provisions of such mutual aid arrangements or agreements. 
(b)  The director of the local organization for emergency preparedness may assist in negotiation of reciprocal mutual aid agreements between his organization and other public and private agencies and between the governor and the adjoining states or political subdivisions thereof and shall carry out arrangements relating to the local unit. 
(Code 1980, § 8-24) 
Sec. 34-35. - Use of existing equipment, supplies and facilities. 
    In carrying out the emergency powers under this article, the governor and the chief executive officer or the city council are directed to use the services, equipment, supplies and facilities of existing departments, offices and agencies of the state and of the city, and the officers and personnel of all such departments, offices and agencies are directed to cooperate with and extend such services and facilities to the governor and the state disaster and planning office upon request. 
(Code 1980, § 8-25) 
Sec. 34-36. - Acceptance of federal and state aid. 
    Whenever the federal government or state government or any officer or agency thereof shall offer to the state or through the state to this city services, equipment, supplies, material or funds by way of gift, grant or loan for the purpose of civil defense, the state, acting through the governor, or this city, acting with the consent of the governor and through its chief executive officer, may accept such offer, and upon acceptance the governor or chief executive officer of this city may authorize any officer of the state or of this city, as the case may be, to receive such services, equipment, supplies, materials or funds on behalf of the state or this city, subject to the terms of the offer. 
(Code 1980, § 8-26) 
Sec. 34-37. - Emergency procedure for procurement. 
    In an emergency as defined in RSMo 44.010(4), the municipal director of local emergency preparedness is authorized on behalf of the city to procure such services, supplies, equipment or material as may be necessary for such purposes in view of the exigency, without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to municipal contracts or obligations as authorized by RSMo 44.080(3), provided that if the city council meets at such time, he shall act subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by the council. 
(Code 1980, § 8-27) 
Sec. 34-38. - Waiver of formal contract procedure during enemy attack. 
    In an enemy attack, the mayor or city council may waive any time-consuming procedures and formalities otherwise required by statute pertaining to the advertisement for bids for the performance of public work or entering into contracts. 
(Code 1980, § 8-28) 
Chapter 38 - COURTS[1] 
  

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- General penalty for Code violations, § 1-20; civil emergencies, ch. 34; law enforcement, ch. 70; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 78; traffic, ch. 110. 
State Law reference- Municipal courts, RSMo 479.010 et seq. 

Sec. 38-1. - Violations of ordinances to be tried in circuit court. 
    City ordinance violation cases shall be filed in division six of the 13th Judicial Circuit Court of the state for the county and shall be heard and determined by an associate circuit judge of the 13th Judicial Circuit Court, as provided by RSMo 479.040. 
(Code 1980, § 18-1) 
Sec. 38-2. - Court costs. 
(a)  The court costs to be assessed under this chapter are to be in addition to the fine and according to the following schedule: 
(1)  Costs of the court in accordance with the Missouri Municipal Division Court Operating Rule 21.01. 
(2)  In all cases except those for nonmoving traffic violations, costs for the training of police officers in the amount of $2.00. 
(3)  Other costs, such as for the issuance of a warrant, a commitment or a summons, as provided before the associate circuit judge in criminal prosecutions. 
(4)  Actual costs assessed against the city by the county sheriff for apprehension or confinement in the county jail. 
(5)  Mileage, in the same amount as provided to the sheriff in criminal violations, for each mile and fraction thereof the officer must travel (both directions) in order to serve any warrant or commitment or order of the court. 
(b)  An additional court cost in the amount of $1.00 is hereby imposed upon every municipal court case (except parking violations and other nonmoving traffic offenses) to fund the "Missouri Police Officers Standards and Training Commission Fund" as created under the statutes of the state. The municipal court clerk shall collect such funds for any court case that is resolved and remit the $1.00 court costs to the finance officer, and the finance officer will remit the money to the state. 
(c)  Missouri statewide court automation program surcharge. In addition to any costs which may be assessed by the municipal division pursuant to statute, ordinance or court rule, in every proceeding filed in the municipal division for violation of an ordinance a surcharge of $7.00 shall be assessed. Such surcharge shall also be assessed in cases in which pleas of guilty are processed in the traffic violations bureau or general violations bureau. No such surcharge shall be collected when the proceeding or defendant has been dismissed by the court, when costs are waived, or when costs are to be paid to the city. Such surcharge shall be collected by the court administrator and transmitted monthly to the chief financial officer. Funds collected under this subsection shall be used by the city only to pay to the Missouri director of revenue to the credit of the Missouri statewide court automation fund as provided by RSMo 488.012.3(5) and 488.027.2. 
(Code 1980, § 18-2; Ord. No. 659-93, §§ 1, 3, 11-23-93; Ord. No. 1174-07, § 1, 4-10-07; Ord. No. 1406-15, § 1, 12-15-15) 
State Law reference- Fee and costs limits, RSMo 479.260(2), 590.140. 
Sec. 38-3. - Traffic violations bureau clerk. 
(a)  The position of traffic violations bureau clerk is established. The clerk and assistants appointed by such clerk shall perform the responsibilities imposed by or pursuant to RSMo 479.050, with respect to the traffic violations bureau for the city, including: 
(1)  Collecting fines and costs which are assessed in the traffic violations bureau. 
(2)  Remitting to the proper official fines and costs which are collected within the time and in the manner provided by statute, court rule or ordinance. 
(b)  The salaries of the traffic violations bureau clerk and assistants, if any, shall be established by the city clerk within the budget and appropriations which are established and made by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 18-3) 
Sec. 38-4. - Disposition of stolen property. 
(a)  When property alleged to have been stolen, purloined, embezzled or obtained by false pretenses shall come into the custody of the chief of police, he shall hold the property, subject to the order of the court authorized to direct the disposition thereof. 
(b)  Upon satisfactory proof of the title of any owner of such property, the judge may order the property to be delivered to such owner, on his paying the reasonable and necessary expenses incurred in the safekeeping and preservation of such property, to be certified to by the judge, which order shall entitle the owner to demand and receive such property. 
(Code 1980, § 18-4) 
Sec. 38-5. - Payment of fine in installments. 
    When a fine is assessed by an associate circuit judge, it shall be within his discretion to provide for the payment of the fine on an installment basis under such terms and conditions as he may deem appropriate. 
(Code 1980, § 18-5) 
Chapter 42 - ELECTIONS[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - Wards designated; polling places. 
    Generally. The city shall be divided into four wards to be designated and numbered as first ward, second ward, third ward and fourth ward, respectively. Unless otherwise indicated ward one voting place shall be in the Fulton City Hall, Ward Two voting place shall be in the Callaway County Public Library, Ward Three voting place shall be in the South Side Baptist Church and ward four voting place shall be in the First Baptist Church. 
    Ward boundaries shall be designated as described in the attached Exhibit "A" and incorporated herein by reference as if fully set out at this point. 
(Code 1980, § 9-9; Ord. No. 888-01, § 1, 10-23-01; Ord. No. 1309-11, § 1, 12-20-11) 
Editor's note- It should be noted that Exhibit A is not set out at length herein but is on file and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk.
