ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; fire department, § 50-56 et seq. 

Sec. 70-26. - Established; purpose. 
    There is established for the city in accordance with the Charter a merit system police department, the purpose of which is to ensure the safety and general welfare of the community. 
(Code 1980, § 23-16) 
Sec. 70-27. - Composition; probationary period. 
(a)  The police department established pursuant to section 70-26 shall have a chief of police, a deputy chief of police, a minimum of three sergeants and 17 other officers. The structure of the department shall be recommended by the chief of police to the director of administration who shall have the authority to implement the structure with the consent of the council. 
(b)  No person shall be granted full tenure as a regular police officer until such person shall have satisfactorily completed a probationary period of 12 months. 
(Code 1980, § 23-17) 
Sec. 70-28. - Duties of chief of police. 
    The chief of police shall act in accordance with policies set forth by the director of administration and shall be responsible for the enforcement of all laws and ordinances of the city and shall: 
(1)  Be responsible for the proper administration, efficiency and general conduct of the police department. 
(2)  Be responsible for the assignment and reassignment of all personnel and for the efficiency, discipline, general conduct and appearance of such personnel. In this capacity he shall have the authority to prescribe and enforce the rules and regulations for the operation of the department. 
(3)  Take such action as he deems necessary for the protection of the safety and welfare of persons and property. 
(Code 1980, § 32-10(A)) 
Sec. 70-29. - Functions. 
    The police department shall perform the following functions: 
(1)  Identify criminal offenders and criminal activity and, where appropriate, apprehend offenders and participate in subsequent court proceedings. 
(2)  Reduce the opportunities for the commission of some crimes through preventive patrol and other measures. 
(3)  Aid persons who are in danger of physical harm. 
(4)  Protect constitutional guarantees. 
(5)  Facilitate the movement of people and vehicles. 
(6)  Assist those who cannot care for themselves. 
(7)  Resolve conflicts. 
(8)  Identify problems that are potentially serious law enforcement or governmental problems. 
(9)  Create and maintain a feeling of security in the community. 
(10)  Promote and preserve civil order. 
(11)  Provide other services, both emergency and nonemergency. 
(Code 1980, § 32-10(B)) 
Sec. 70-30. - Appointment of officers from list of eligibles. 
    The director of administration shall appoint or promote all officers within the police department from a list of eligible candidates recommended by the personnel board. 
(Code 1980, § 23-18) 
Sec. 70-31. - Term of office. 
    All persons appointed to the police department shall be entitled to hold office during good behavior and efficient service. 
(Code 1980, § 23-19) 
Sec. 70-32. - Compensation. 
    The salary of the personnel of the police department established pursuant to section 70-26 shall be determined by the council. 
(Code 1980, § 23-20) 
Sec. 70-33. - Suspension, demotion or discharge of personnel. 
(a)  The chief of police may suspend, demote or discharge any personnel of the police department for misbehavior, malfeasance or inefficiency. 
(b)  Any person suspended, demoted or discharged for misbehavior, malfeasance or inefficiency may appeal such suspension, demotion or discharge through the grievance procedures established in the personnel manual. 
(Code 1980, § 23-21) 
Sec. 70-34. - Appointment of chief of police. 
    The director of administration with the consent of the mayor shall appoint a chief of police. 
(Code 1980, § 23-22) 
Sec. 70-35. - Duties and responsibilities of officers. 
    Every police officer shall be prompt in the discharge of his duties and shall at all times hold himself in readiness to obey and execute all lawful orders, rules and regulations of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 23-23(b)) 
Chapter 78 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- General penalty for Code violations, § 1-20; alcoholic beverages, ch. 10; civil emergencies, ch. 34; courts, ch. 38; human relations, ch. 66; law enforcement, ch. 70; traffic and vehicles, ch. 110. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Aiding and abetting. 
    Any person who commits, attempts to commit, conspires to commit or aids or abets in the commission of any act declared to be in violation of the ordinances of the city, whether individually or in connection with one or more other persons or as a principal, agent or accessory, shall be guilty of such offense, and every person who falsely, fraudulently, forcibly or willfully induces, causes, coerces, requires, permits or directs another to violate any section of this chapter is likewise guilty of such offense and shall be punished as provided in section 1-20. 
(Code 1980, § 20-1) 
Sec. 78-2. - Obedience to lawful orders required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to obey a lawful order of any police officer given in the line of duty. 
(Code 1980, § 20-2) 
Sec. 78-3. - Interference with police officer. 
    No person shall resist, hinder, obstruct, run away from or otherwise interfere with a police officer in the discharge of his official duties. 
(Code 1980, § 20-4) 
State Law reference- Resisting arrest, RSMo 575.150; interference with legal process, RSMo 575.160. 
Sec. 78-4. - False impersonation. 
    No person shall commit the crime of false impersonation, which is committed if such person: 
(1)  Falsely represents himself to be a public servant with purpose to induce another to submit to his pretended official authority or to rely upon his pretended official acts; and: 
a.  Performs an act in that pretended capacity; or 
b.  Causes another to act in reliance upon his pretended official authority; or 
(2)  Falsely represents himself to be a person licensed to practice or engage in any profession for which a license is required by the laws of this state with purpose to induce another to rely upon such representation; and: 
a.  Performs an act in that pretended capacity; or 
b.  Causes another to act in reliance upon such representation. 
(Code 1980, § 20-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 575.120. 
Sec. 78-5. - False declarations-Generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, with the purpose to mislead a public servant in the performance of his duty, to: 
(1)  Submit any written false statement, which he does not believe to be true: 
a.  In an application for any pecuniary benefit or other consideration; or 
b.  On a form bearing notice, authorized by law, that false statements made therein are punishable; or 
(2)  Submit or invite reliance on: 
a.  Any writing which he knows to be forged, altered or otherwise lacking in authenticity; or 
b.  Any sample, specimen, map, boundary mark or other object which he knows to be false. 
(b)  The falsity of the statement or the item under subsection (a) of this section must be as to a fact which is material to the purposes for which the statement is made or the item submitted, and the provisions of RSMo 575.040(2) and (3), shall apply to prosecutions under subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  It is a defense to a prosecution under subsection (a) of this section that the actor retracted the false statement or item, but this defense shall not apply if the retraction was made after: 
(1)  The falsity of the statement or item was exposed; or 
(2)  The public servant took substantial action in reliance on the statement or item. 
(d)  The defendant shall have the burden of injecting the issue of retraction under subsection (c) of this section. 
(Code 1980, § 20-6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 575.060. 
Sec. 78-6. - Same-Proof of falsity of statements. 
    No person shall be convicted of a violation of section 78-5 based upon the making of a false statement, except upon proof of the falsity of the statement by: 
(1)  The direct evidence of two witnesses; 
(2)  The direct evidence of one witness, together with strongly corroborating circumstances; 
(3)  Demonstrative evidence which conclusively proves the falsity of the statement; 
(4)  A directly contradictory statement by the defendant under oath together with: 
a.  The direct evidence of one witness; or 
b.  Strongly corroborating circumstances; or 
(5)  A judicial admission by the defendant that he made the statement knowing it was false. An admission, which is not a judicial admission, by the defendant that he made the statement knowing it was false may constitute strongly corroborating circumstances. 
(Code 1980, § 20-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 575.070. 
Sec. 78-7. - Mining. 
(a)  Prohibited. No person, either in person or by agent, shall prospect or mine any property within the city. 
(b)  Permitting use of property. No person, either in person or by agent, shall permit any prospecting or mining on property owned or controlled by him within the city. 
(Code 1980, § 20-8) 
Sec. 78-8. - Escape and aiding in escape. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, while being detained, imprisoned or held in custody by any police officer, to break away, escape or attempt to escape from such officer or place of detainment or custody. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to attempt to rescue any person from the custody of a police officer. 
(Code 1980, § 20-9) 
Sec. 78-9. - Resisting or interfering with arrest. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, knowing that a law enforcement officer is making an arrest, for the purpose of preventing the officer from effecting the arrest, to: 
(1)  Resist the arrest of himself by using or threatening the use of violence or physical force or by fleeing from such officer; or 
(2)  Interfere with the arrest of another person by using or threatening the use of violence, physical force or physical interference. 
(b)  This section applies to arrests with or without warrants and to arrests for any crime or ordinance violation. 
(c)  It is no defense to a prosecution under subsection (a) of this section that the law enforcement officer was acting unlawfully in making the arrest; however, nothing in this section shall be construed to bar civil suits for unlawful arrest. 
(Code 1980, § 20-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 575.150. 
Sec. 78-10. - Interference with legal process. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, knowing any person is authorized by law to serve process, for the purpose of preventing such person from effecting the service of process, to interfere with or obstruct such person. 
(b)  As used in this section, the term "process" includes any writ, summons, subpoena, warrant other than an arrest warrant or other process or order of a court. 
(Code 1980, § 20-11) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 575.160. 
Sec. 78-11. - Misdemeanor assault. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit the crime of misdemeanor assault. A person commits the crime of misdemeanor assault if: 
(1)  He attempts to cause or recklessly causes physical injury to another person; or 
(2)  With criminal negligence he causes physical injury to another person by means of a deadly weapon; or 
(3)  He purposely places another person in apprehension of immediate physical injury; or 
(4)  He recklessly engages in conduct which creates a grave risk of death or serious physical injury to another person; or 
(5)  He knowingly causes physical contact with another person knowing the other person will regard the contact as offensive or provocative. 
(Ord. No. 675-94, § 1, 10-25-94) 
Sec. 78-12. - Smoking prohibited in certain locations. 
(a)  No person shall smoke any cigarette, cigar, pipe, or other tobacco product inside any building or designated portion of a building, public or private, where signs have previously been erected prohibiting smoking. 
(b)  Signs prohibiting smoking shall be deemed sufficient when the signs contain: 
(1)  A reference to this section; and 
(2)  The words "NO SMOKING" or words to similar effect, or the international "NO SMOKING" symbol consisting of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle with a bar across it. 
(Ord. No. 594-92, § 1, 2-24-92) 
Secs. 78-13-78-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST MORALS 

Sec. 78-31. - Indecent exposure and nudity. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly expose his genitals under circumstances in which he knows that his conduct is likely to cause affront or alarm. 
(b)  The owner, operator, proprietor or managing agent of any business establishment, whether or not alcoholic beverages are served or consumed on the premises, shall not permit any dance, performance or exhibition to occur on the premises wherein the dancers, employees, performers or exhibitors are nude or partially nude. A dancer, employee, performer or exhibitor shall be deemed to be nude or partially nude if either or both of the breasts or the pelvic area or the buttocks are not covered with opaque clothing. 
(Code 1980, § 20-23; Ord. No. 662-94, § 1, 2-26-94) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 566.130. 
Secs. 78-32-78-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Secondhand goods, ch. 90; litter, § 94-51 et seq. 

Sec. 78-51. - Petit larceny. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to appropriate to his own use the property or services of another of a value less than $150.00 without consent of the owner or by means of deceit, by exercising dominion over the property in a manner inconsistent with rights of the owner, by taking, using, transferring, concealing or retaining possession of the property. 
(b)  The court shall proceed to hear evidence and determine the value thereof and may, in addition to any other punishment determined by the court, order the defendant to make restitution in the amount of the value of the property stolen. 
(Code 1980, § 20-51) 
State Law reference- Stealing, RSMo 570.030. 
Sec. 78-52. - Trespass. 
(a)  A person commits the offense of trespass if he knowingly enters unlawfully or knowingly remains unlawfully in a building or inhabitable structure or upon real property. 
(b)  A person does not commit the offense of trespass by entering or remaining upon real property unless the real property is fenced or otherwise enclosed in a manner designed to exclude intruders or as to which notice against trespass is given by: 
(1)  Actual communication to the actor; or 
(2)  Posting in a manner reasonably likely to come to the attention of intruders. 
(Code 1980, § 20-52) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 569.140. 
Sec. 78-53. - Malicious destruction of property. 
(a)  No person shall remove, break up or otherwise destroy or injure any bridge, culvert, sidewalk, pavement, crosswalk in or upon any street, thoroughfare or alley of the city without having lawful authority to do so. 
(b)  No person in the city shall willfully and without lawful authority cut down, pull or root up, saw, peel, cut, hack, injure or destroy any fruit tree or ornamental tree, shrub or cultivated root or plant, grape or strawberry vines or currant, gooseberry, raspberry or blackberry bushes standing or growing on or attached to the land of another or which may be growing in or along any street, thoroughfare, sidewalk, park or public place or pick, destroy or carry therefrom any portion of the fruit of any cultivated tree, vine or bush. 
(c)  No person shall willfully cut, break or otherwise injure or destroy any lamppost, awning post, awning, spouting, door, window, railing, porch, sign or fence within the city. 
(d)  No person shall remove, take or tear down, deface, mark, injure or destroy any sign belonging to another or deface, injure or remove any sign indicating the number of any street without having lawful authority to do so. 
(e)  No person in the city shall interfere with freight of any kind which shall be in any railroad car or truck or in any freight depot or warehouse, by standing or sitting on the freight or by taking it down after it has been piled up or by uncovering the freight or in any way or by any means injuring the freight. 
(f)  No person shall molest, disturb, damage, injure or in any manner interfere with the batteries, wires, poles, instruments or other appliances belonging to any telegraph, telephone, cable TV, or public utility company doing business in the city. 
(g)  No person shall knowingly or willfully damage, tamper with, operate, ride upon or in, deface or mark upon or burn any property belonging to the city without the authority to do so. 
(h)  No person shall put or cause to be put any dead animal, carcass or any part thereof or any offal or other filth into any reservoir, water tank or tower used or intended to be used for the purpose of supplying the inhabitants of the city with water or shall in any manner or by any means defile, attempt to defile or cause to be defiled the water contained in any such reservoir, water tank or tower. 
(i)  Any person who violates this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished in accordance with section 1-20. 
(Code 1980, § 20-53) 
Secs. 78-54-78-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE 

Sec. 78-76. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in sections 78-77 and 78-78, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Private property means any place which at the time is not open to the public. It includes property which is owned publicly or privately. 
    Property of another means any property in which the actor does not have a possessory interest. 
    Public place means any place which at the time is open to the public. It includes property which is owned publicly or privately. 
(b)  If a building or structure is divided into separately occupied units, such units are separate premises. 
(Code 1980, § 20-64) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 574.030. 
Sec. 78-77. - Peace disturbance. 
(a)  A person commits the offense of peace disturbance if such person: 
(1)  Unreasonably and knowingly causes alarm to another person not physically on the same premises by: 
a.  Personally abusive language addressed in a face-to-face manner to a specific person and uttered under circumstances such that the words have a direct tendency to cause an immediate violent response by a reasonable recipient; 
b.  Tending to incite a fight; or 
c.  Fighting. 
(2)  Is in a public place or on private property of another without consent and unreasonably and knowingly causes alarm to another person or persons by: 
a.  Personally abusive language addressed in a face-to-face manner to a specific person and uttered under circumstances such that the words have a direct tendency to cause an immediate violent response by a reasonable recipient; 
b.  Tending to incite a fight; or 
c.  Fighting. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for any person to commit an act of peace disturbance. 
(Code 1980, § 20-65; Ord. No. 611-92, § 1, 5-26-92) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 574.010. 
Sec. 78-78. - Private peace disturbance. 
(a)  A person commits the offense of private peace disturbance if such person is on private property and unreasonably and purposely causes alarm to another person on the same premises by fighting. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for any person to commit an act of private peace disturbance. 
(Code 1980, § 20-66; Ord. No. 611-92, § 1, 5-26-92) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 574.020. 
Sec. 78-79. - Unlawful assembly. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly assemble with six or more other persons and agree with such persons to violate any of the criminal laws of this state or of the United States with force or violence. 
(Code 1980, § 20-67) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 574.040. 
Sec. 78-80. - Rioting. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly assemble with six or more other persons and agree with such persons to violate any of the criminal laws of this state or of the United States with force or violence and thereafter, while still so assembled, to violate any of such laws with force or violence. 
(Code 1980, § 20-68) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 574.050. 
Sec. 78-81. - Refusal to disperse. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, being present at the scene of an unlawful assembly or at the scene of a riot, to knowingly fail or refuse to obey the lawful command of a law enforcement officer to depart from the scene of such unlawful assembly or riot. 
(Code 1980, § 20-69) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 574.060. 
Sec. 78-82. - False alarms. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm agent means any person employed by an alarm business whose duties include altering, installing, maintaining, moving, repairing, replacing, selling, servicing, responding to, or causing others to respond to an alarm device. 
    Alarm business means any business operated by a person or entity who engages in the activity of altering, installing, leasing, maintaining, moving, repairing, replacing, selling, servicing, or responding to an emergency alarm system, or which causes any of these activities to take place. 
    Alarm system means any mechanical or electrical device which is designed to be activated manually or automatically upon the detection of an unauthorized entry, intrusion, fire, or other emergency in or on any building, structure, facility, or premises through the emission of a sound or transmission of a signal or message. 
    Alarm user means any person who uses an alarm system to protect any building, structure, facility, or premises. 
    Audible alarm means a local alarm located on the building, structure, facility or premises protected and equipped with an exterior sound-producing device, such as a gong, buzzer, siren, bell or horn. 
    Automatic dialing device means an alarm system which automatically dials a specific telephone number and transmits an emergency message by a recording over regular telephone lines when actuated. 
    False alarm means any activation of an alarm system intentionally, by inadvertence, negligence, unintentional act or malfunction of the alarm system to which the city police or fire department, respond when there is no unauthorized entry, intrusion, fire or emergency; provided that the following shall not be considered false alarms: 
(1)  Alarms caused by an attempted illegal or unauthorized entry of which there is visible or demonstrated evidence. 
(2)  Alarms caused by heat or smoke from a fire. 
(3)  Alarms caused by damage to the alarm system, provided that such incidents are promptly reported to the company providing the means of transmission. 
(4)  Alarms caused by acts over which the user has no control, such as windstorm, thunder, lightning or other similar phenomena. 
(5)  Alarms intentionally caused by a person acting under a reasonable belief that a need exists to summon the police or fire department, for which purpose the alarm was installed. Indiscriminate use of the alarm system to summon the police shall be considered a violation of this section. 
(6)  Alarms occurring on a repeated basis without apparent cause but where reasonable effort in the judgment of the police chief or fire chief, or his designated representative is being made by the alarm user, business alarm, alarm agent, or other concerned person to correct the malfunction expeditiously. 
(b)  Penalties. Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter or failing to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by the fine provided for. In the event of violation of false alarms after the second false alarm in any twelve-month period, the alarm user, in lieu of court appearance, may pay to the municipal court, a penalty of $50.00. 
(c)  Enforcement. For the purpose of enforcing provisions of this chapter, the police chief or fire chief, or his designee shall have the authority, at reasonable times and upon reasonable oral notice, to enter any building, structure, facility or premises in the city in or upon which an alarm system or alarm business is located, to inspect the installation or operation of such alarm system or alarm business. Any alarm user may request a written notice of inspection, which shall be made at alarm user's expense by a licensed electrical contractor acceptable to him and to the city. If such inspection reveals any violation of the provision of this chapter, the alarm user or alarm business shall be granted 30 days to correct such violation. 
(d)  Non-liability of the city. The city shall not be liable for any defects in operation of signal line systems for any failure or neglect to respond appropriately upon receipt of an alarm from any such source, nor for the failure or neglect of any alarm business or alarm agent. 
(e)  Licensing. Any alarm business or alarm agent installing an alarm system within the city shall be licensed and bonded in compliance with applicable ordinances of the county and if required by applicable ordinances of the city or state statutes. 
(f)  Violations. A false alarm is declared a violation of this chapter. Upon determination by the police department that a false alarm has occurred there shall be no penalty for the first two false alarms during the first two weeks following the installation of an alarm system. 
    Thereafter, the penalty fee for false alarms shall be as provided. 
(g)  Automatic dialing of police. No person shall install or use an automatic dialing device that is programmed to dial the police or fire department's telephone number. 
(h)  Audible alarm cutoff. All alarm systems with an audible alarm shall be equipped with a ten minute cutoff timer. 
(i)  Alarm business; operational instruction. Any alarm business or alarm agent that sells, leases or installs an alarm system in the city shall furnish the alarm user with written instructions for the operation of the system. The alarm business or alarm agent shall provide training in the operation of the system and, upon request from the alarm user, refresher training. 
    Alarm systems installed after March 19, 1987, shall meet or exceed standards set by American National Standards Institute (ANSI) and/or Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc. (UL) for the applicable alarm system. 
(j)  Alarm system repair service. Any alarm business or alarm agent that sells, leases or installs an alarm system within the city must offer either directly, or through an agency, repair service for the alarm system to maintain it in proper working order. 
(k)  Alarm user responsibilities. The alarm user shall be responsible for maintaining the alarm system in good repair to assure reliability of operation. 
(Code 1980, § 20-70; Ord. No. 1356-13, § 1, 9-24-13) 
Sec. 78-83. - Disorderly houses or premises. 
    No person shall conduct a disorderly dance house or keep any other disorderly house or shall knowingly permit any tenement of any building in his possession or under his control to be used for any such purpose. 
(Code 1980, § 20-71) 
Sec. 78-84. - Curfew for persons under seventeen; responsibility of parents or guardians. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any minor under the age of 17 years to loiter, idle, wander, stroll or to drive or ride in an automobile, or play in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds, public places and public buildings, places of amusement and entertainment, vacant lots or other unsupervised places between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the following day, except on Fridays and Saturdays when the hours shall be 12:00 midnight to 6:00 a.m. of the following day, except that this section does not apply to a minor accompanied by his parent, guardian, or other adult person having the care and custody of the minor, or where the minor is upon an emergency errand or legitimate business directed by his or her parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of the minor. Each violation of this subsection shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other person having the care and custody of a minor under the age of 17 years to knowingly permit such minor to violate the provisions of subsection (a) of this section. Each violation of the provisions of this subsection shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  Any police officer finding a child violating the provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall warn the child to desist immediately from such violation. The police officer may take the child into custody and release him to his parent or guardian or release the child at the scene with a written notice of referral to the juvenile court. 
(d)  After receiving notice of the first violation by the child, any parent, guardian or other adult person in charge of such child who knowingly permits such child to again violate this section, shall upon being convicted, be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 680-94, § 1, 12-13-94) 
Secs. 78-85-78-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC SAFETY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 58. 

Sec. 78-106. - Fencing of open well, vault or cistern. 
    No person shall dig any well, cistern or vault and leave the well, cistern or vault open or exposed and without a sufficient fence or other protection around it. 
(Code 1980, § 20-83) 
Sec. 78-107. - Leaving cellar door or grating open. 
    No person shall suffer or permit any cellar door or grating to be and remain open or in an unsafe or dangerous condition whereby persons may be in danger of falling on or over such cellar door or into such cellar or vault. 
(Code 1980, § 20-84) 
Sec. 78-108. - Abandonment of airtight or semiairtight containers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon, discard or knowingly permit to remain on premises under his control, in a place accessible to children, any abandoned or discarded icebox, refrigerator or other airtight or semiairtight container, which has a capacity of 11/2 cubic feet or more and an opening of 50 square inches or more and which has a door or lid equipped with hinge, latch or other fastening device capable of securing such door or lid, without rendering such equipment harmless to human life by removing such hinges, latches or other hardware which may cause a person to be confined therein. 
(b)  Subsection (a) of this section does not apply to an icebox, refrigerator or other airtight or semiairtight container located in that part of a building occupied by a dealer, warehouseman or repairman. 
(c)  The defendant shall have the burden of injecting the issue under subsection (b) of this section. 
(Code 1980, § 20-85) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 577.100. 
Sec. 78-109. - Weapons-Possession, manufacture, transport, repair or sale of certain weapons prohibited. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he knowingly possesses, manufactures, transports, repairs or sells: 
(1)  A switchblade knife; 
(2)  A bullet or projectile which explodes or detonates upon impact because of an independent explosive charge after having been shot from a firearm; or 
(3)  Knuckles, as defined in RSMo 571.010(10). 
(b)  A person does not commit an offense under this section if his conduct: 
(1)  Was incident to the performance of official duty by the armed forces, national guard, a governmental law enforcement agency or a penal institution; 
(2)  Was incident to engaging in a lawful commercial or business transaction with an organization enumerated in subsection (b)(1) of this section; 
(3)  Was incident to using an explosive weapon in a manner reasonably related to a lawful industrial or commercial enterprise; 
(4)  Was incident to displaying the weapon in a public museum or exhibition; or 
(5)  Was incident to dealing with the weapon solely as a curio, ornament or keepsake or to using it in a manner reasonably related to a lawful dramatic performance. 
(Code 1980, § 20-86(b)) 
Sec. 78-110. - Same-Unlawful use. 
(a)  A person commits the offense of unlawful use of weapons if he knowingly: 
(1)  Possesses a firearm or projectile weapon while intoxicated; or 
(2)  Carries a firearm or any other weapon readily capable of lethal use into any church or place where people have assembled for worship or into any school or into any election precinct on any election day or into any building owned or occupied by any agency of the federal government, state government or political subdivision thereof or into any public assemblage of persons met for any lawful purpose. 
(3)  Carries a concealed firearm into a city building as follows: 
a.  No person who has been issued a concealed carry endorsement by the state director of revenue under RSMo § 571.094 or who has been issued a valid permit or endorsement to carry concealed firearms issued by another state or political subdivision of another state, shall, by authority of that endorsement or permit, be allowed to carry a concealed firearm or to openly carry a firearm in any building or portion of a building owned, leased or controlled by the city. 
b.  Signs shall be posted at each entrance of a building entirely owned, leased or controlled by the city stating that carrying of firearms is prohibited. Where the city owns, leases or controls only a portion of a building, signs shall be posted at each entrance to that portion of the building stating that carrying of firearms is prohibited. 
c.  This section shall not apply to buildings used for public housing by private persons, highways or rest areas, firing ranges, or private dwellings owned, leased or controlled by the city. 
d.  Any person violating this section may be denied entrance to the building or ordered to leave the building. Any city employee violating this section may be disciplined. No other penalty shall be imposed for a violation of this section. 
e.  No person who has been issued a certificate of qualification which allows the person to carry a concealed firearm before the director of revenue begins issuing concealed carry endorsements in July, 2004, shall, by authority of that certificate, be allowed to carry a concealed firearm or to openly carry a firearm in any building or portion of a building owned, leased or controlled by the city. 
(b)  Subsection (a)(2) of this section shall not apply to or affect any of the following: 
(1)  All state, county and municipal law enforcement officers possessing the duty and power of arrest for violation of the general criminal laws of the state or for violation of ordinances of counties or municipalities of the state or any person summoned by such officers to assist in making arrests or preserving the peace while actually engaged in assisting such officer. 
(2)  Wardens, superintendents and keepers of prisons, penitentiaries, jails and other institutions for the detention of persons accused or convicted of crime. 
(3)  Members of the armed forces or national guard while performing their official duty. 
(4)  Those persons vested by article V, section 1, of the state constitution with the judicial power of the state. 
(5)  Any person whose bona fide duty is to execute process, civil or criminal. 
(c)  Subsection (a)(4) of this section does not apply when the actor is transporting such weapons in a nonfunctioning state or in an unloaded state when ammunition is not readily accessible or when such weapons are not readily accessible. 
(Code 1980, § 20-86(a); Ord. No. 944-03, § 1, 11-18-03) 
Sec. 78-111. - Discharge of firearms, air rifles, bows and similar instruments prohibited. 
    No person, except the chief of police, a police officer or law enforcement officer or other officer in the discharge of his duty, shall discharge or fire off any gun, pistol, rifle, shotgun or revolver which may be used for the explosion of cartridges or any air gun, BB gun, gas-operated gun or spring gun or any instrument, toy or weapon commonly known as a "peashooter," "slingshot" or "beany," or any bow made for the purpose of throwing or projecting missiles of any kind by any means whatsoever, whether such instrument is called by any name set forth in this section or by any other name. Except, hunting and burning will be permitted on large tracts of land (unplatted 200 acres or more, and/or separated by a roadway) located within the city limits. 
    Except, bow and arrow hunting, for deer only, will be permitted during specified days and times, to be determined by the State of Missouri Department of Conservation along with the City of Fulton. All hunters must comply with state laws regarding bow and arrow hunting for deer along with specified regulations applying to the special hunt within the city limits. 
    Bow and arrow target practice will be allowed only at archery ranges. 
(Code 1980, § 20-87; Ord. No. 1111-05, § 1, 10-11-05; Ord. No. 1276-10, § 1, 4-27-10; Ord. No. 1345-13, § 1, 4-23-13) 
Sec. 78-112. - Sale and discharge of fireworks. 
    The provisions of this section represent the City of Fulton's regulations and prohibitions of fireworks within its city limits and shall not supersede the State of Missouri's laws and regulations concerning fireworks. 
(a)  Definitions. 
Consumer fireworks. Explosive devices designed primarily to produce visible or audible effects by combustion and includes aerial devices and ground devices, all of which are classified as fireworks, UN0336, 1.4G by regulation of the United States Department of Transportation, as amended from time to time, and which were formerly classified as Class C Common Fireworks by regulation of the United States Department of Transportation. 
Display fireworks. Explosive devices designed primarily to produce visible or audible effects by combustion, deflagration or detonation. This term includes devices containing more than two grains (130MG) of explosive composition intended for public display. These devices are classified as fireworks, UN0335, 1.3G by regulation of the United States Department of Transportation, as amended from time to time, and which were formerly classified as Class B Display Fireworks by regulation of the United States Department of Transportation. 
(b)  Consumer fireworks. 
(1)  Period of sale limited. The fireworks season shall be the period, beginning on the twentieth day of June and continuing through the tenth day of July of the same year and the period beginning on the twentieth day of December and continuing through the second day of January of the next year, which shall be the only period of time that seasonal retailers may be permitted to sell consumer fireworks. 
(2)  Business license/approval required. A business license must be obtained from the city clerk's office during normal business hours and prior to the sale of fireworks in the city. Approval from the state fire marshall's office and the city fire department is also required. 
(3)  Discharge lawful-When. The discharge, detonation or shooting of consumer fireworks shall only be permitted between the hours of 1:00 p.m. and 11:00 p.m. on the third, fourth and fifth of July each year, and on December 31 between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 1:00 a.m. New Year's Day. 
The discharge, detonation or shooting of fireworks at any other time is prohibited except by special approval of the city council. 
(4)  Disturbance of the peace. If a written (signed) complaint is received and verified by the city police department for disturbance of the peace of the neighbors, discharging shall immediately cease. 
(5)  Restrictions on throwing/discharging fireworks. It is hereby declared to be unlawful for any person to throw (shoot) fireworks out of vehicles, under vehicles, at vehicles, at buildings, at people, or in the vicinity of a church service (500 feet), on any public street or other public place within the city. 
(c)  Display fireworks. 
(1)  Licensed operator required. Effective August 28, 2004 Missouri State Statute (RSMo 320.126.4) became law requiring all fireworks displays "shall be supervised, managed, or directed by a Missouri licensed operator or pyrotechnic operator on site", operators must be licensed by the division of fire safety. Assistants shall be at least 18 years old. 
(2)  Permit required. The city does require a fireworks display permit. Fire department officials will conduct an inspection to make sure the display will meet all state or local laws and regulations. The fire department will also stand by at permitted public displays to ensure safety and proper handling of pyrotechnics. 
(3)  Approval to discharge in city parks. It shall be unlawful to discharge (shoot) display fireworks in city parks without the special approval of the city council. 
(d)  Cancellations. In dry, adverse or drought weather conditions the fire chief, his designate or other official designated by the city council may cancel or limit the use of fireworks in the city. 
(e)  Penalty. Any person who violates this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, be punished in accordance with section 1-20 of this Code. 
(Code 1980, § 20-88; Ord. No. 1282-10, § 1, 8-24-10) 
Chapter 82 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 46; floods, ch. 54; historic preservation, ch. 62; planning, ch. 86; solid waste, ch. 94; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98; subdivisions, ch. 102; utilities, ch. 114; zoning, app. A.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 82-1. - Department established; purpose. 
    There is established for the city in accordance with the Charter a parks and recreation department, the purpose of which is to provide recreational facilities and activities for all residents of the community. 
(Code 1980, § 21-16) 
Sec. 82-2. - Compensation of department personnel. 
    The salary of the personnel of the parks and recreation department, established pursuant to section 82-1, shall be determined by the council. 
(Code 1980, § 21-18) 
Secs. 82-3-82-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SUPERINTENDENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 82-26. - Appointment. 
    The director of administration with the consent of the mayor shall appoint a superintendent of parks and recreation. 
(Code 1980, § 21-17) 
Sec. 82-27. - Duties. 
    The superintendent of parks and recreation shall plan, promote, organize and supervise a comprehensive municipal park and recreation program and administer the program in the interest of the entire community and shall: 
(1)  Develop, operate and maintain all city parks, recreational areas and facilities. 
(2)  Supervise the recreational use of playgrounds, playfields, recreation centers, swimming pools, ball diamonds and such other recreation areas and facilities as may be made available to carry out the city's recreation program. 
(3)  Conduct and supervise any form of recreational, cultural or social activities assigned to him that will employ the leisure time of the citizens in a wholesome and constructive manner. 
(Code 1980, § 32-13) 
Secs. 82-28-82-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARKS AND RECREATION BOARD[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; planning and zoning commission, § 86-26 et seq.; solid waste department, § 94-26 et seq.; administration and enforcement of traffic regulations, § 110-31 et seq.; board of public utilities, § 114-51 et seq. 

Sec. 82-51. - Established; purpose; appointment; composition. 
(a)  There is established a parks and recreation board, the purpose of which is to advise the superintendent of parks and recreation regarding types of programs to be operated and facility improvements. The board shall act as a liaison to reach various community and neighborhood groups to develop an ongoing parks and recreation program. 
(b)  The board shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the council and shall consist of nine members selected from the citizens of the city, with at least one member of the board being from each ward. 
(Code 1980, § 21-20) 
Sec. 82-52. - Terms of members, removal from office. 
(a)  The members of the parks and recreation board shall hold office for three-year staggered terms from July 1 following their appointment. Annually, the mayor shall, before July 1 of each year appoint three members who shall hold office for three years or until their successors are appointed. 
(b)  Upon the recommendation of the mayor, a member of the parks and recreation board may be removed by a vote of five members of the city council. A member may also be removed by six votes of the city council independently of the mayor's approval or recommendation. 
(c)  Any member who fails to attend three consecutive regular meetings without being formally excused by the board shall forfeit membership. 
(Code 1980, § 21-21) 
Sec. 82-53. - Officers. 
(a)  Within 15 days after their appointment, the parks and recreation board shall meet and elect one of its members as chairman and one as vice-chairman. The chairman of the board shall preside over the meetings. 
(b)  The city clerk or a person designated by the director of administration shall be the recording secretary and shall keep a record of all actions taken at the meeting. A copy of the minutes of every meeting of the parks and recreation board shall be delivered to the city council and shall be public record. 
(Code 1980, § 21-22) 
Sec. 82-54. - Meetings. 
    Within 15 days after their appointment, the parks and recreation board shall meet to establish a regular quarterly meeting date and thereafter shall meet quarterly. 
(Code 1980, § 21-23) 
Secs. 82-55-82-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - USE REGULATIONS 

Sec. 82-76. - Hours of use. 
(a)  Established. The recreation areas under the administration and supervision of the department of parks and recreation shall be open to the public from 6:00 a.m. until 12:00 midnight each day, unless otherwise approved by the director of administration. 
(b)  Enforcement. Any person not observing the hours established in subsection (a) of this section shall be deemed in violation and shall be prosecuted under section 1-20. 
(Code 1980, §§ 21-32, 21-33) 
Chapter 86 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; civil emergencies, ch. 34; environment, ch. 46; floods, ch. 54; health and sanitation, ch. 58; historic preservation, ch. 62; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 74; parks and recreation, ch. 82; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98; subdivisions, ch. 102; traffic and vehicles, ch. 110; utilities, ch. 114; zoning, app. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 86-1. - Board of adjustment. 
    In order that unwarranted hardship, which constitutes an unreasonable deprivation of use as distinguished from the mere grant of a privilege, may be avoided, the board of adjustment constituted to hear appeals from the planning and zoning commission shall be empowered to modify or vary the regulations in specific cases involving building line regulations. 
(Code 1980, § 22-6) 
Sec. 86-2. - Adoption of master development plan and program. 
(a)  For the purpose of assisting and guiding the mayor, the city council and local decision makers in the management of growth and change in the city, there is adopted by the city council the city's master development plan and program, as prepared by Booker Associates, Inc., at the direction of the city council. 
(b)  The city's master development plan and program is adopted pursuant to approval by the planning and zoning commission, as provided by RSMo 89.340. 
(c)  The master development plan and program is incorporated into and made a part of this section as fully as if set out in full in this section, with the exception of appendix E, which is deleted in full. 
(Code 1980, § 22-7) 
Secs. 86-3-86-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; historic preservation commission, § 62-26 et seq.; parks and recreation board, § 82-51 et seq. 
State Law reference- City planning commission, RSMo 89.310 et seq.; authority to appoint existing plan commission or zoning commission, RSMo 89.070. 

Sec. 86-26. - Established; purpose. 
(a)  There is established a planning and zoning commission, the purpose of which shall be to promote the health, safety and general welfare of the community. 
(b)  The commission shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the council and shall consist of not more than 15 and not less then seven members, including the mayor, a member of the council selected by the council, the city engineer or similar city official and not more than 12 nor less than four citizens appointed by the mayor and approved by the council. All citizen members of the commission shall serve without compensation. 
(c)  The planning and code enforcement officer or his designee shall attend all meetings of the planning and zoning commission, but shall not vote. 
(Code 1980, § 22-18; Ord. No. 641-93, § 1, 5-25-93) 
Sec. 86-27. - Terms of members, removal from office. 
(a)  The members of the planning and zoning commission shall hold office for four years, except that the terms of the citizen members first appointed shall be for varying periods so that succeeding terms will be staggered. 
(b)  Any vacancy in a membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by appointment as aforesaid. 
(c)  The council may remove any citizen member for cause stated in writing and after public hearing. 
(d)  Any member who fails to attend three consecutive regular meetings without being formally excused by the commission shall forfeit his/her membership. 
(Code 1980, § 22-19; Ord. No. 641-93, § 1, 5-25-93) 
Sec. 86-28. - Officers. 
(a)  The commission shall elect its chairman and secretary from among the citizen members. The term of chairman and secretary shall be for one year with eligibility for reelection. 
(b)  The city clerk or a person designated by the director of administration shall be the recording secretary and keep a record of all actions taken at the meeting. A copy of the minutes of every meeting of the planning and zoning commission shall be delivered to the city council and shall be public record. 
(Code 1980, § 22-20; Ord. No. 641-93, § 1, 5-25-93) 
Sec. 86-29. - Meetings. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall meet to establish a regular meeting date and thereafter shall meet at least twice a year in January and July. Special meetings may be called at any time as needed. 
(Code 1980, § 22-21; Ord. No. 641-93, § 1, 5-25-93; Ord. No. 958-04, § 1, 5-25-04) 
Sec. 86-30. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The duties and responsibilities of the planning and zoning commission shall be as outlined in article I of this chapter, and the commission shall have any other duties as may be requested by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 22-22; Ord. No. 641-93, § 1, 5-25-93) 
Chapter 90 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Advertising, ch. 6; businesses, ch. 22; offenses against property, § 78-51 et seq.; solid waste, ch. 94. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 90-1-90-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RUMMAGE SALES 

Sec. 90-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Rummage sale means the sale or offering for sale of miscellaneous goods, wares or merchandise to the public under generally informal circumstances and not on a regular basis, as limited in section 90-27. The term "rummage sale" shall include all such activities whether denominated by the term "rummage sale," "yard sale," "garage sale" or any other term of like connotation. 
(Code 1980, § 16-96) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 90-27. - Limitation on number. 
    No rummage sale may be held in any one residential location by any person at any given address more frequently than four times in any one calendar year. Rummage sales shall not be held more than three consecutive days. Any activity in the nature of a rummage sale which occurs more frequently than limited in this section shall be deemed the establishment of a mercantile business, and the person engaging in such business shall be deemed a merchant within the meaning of that term as defined in section 22-101. 
(Code 1980, § 16-97) 
Sec. 90-28. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1420-16, § 1, adopted Aug. 9, 2016, repealed § 90-28, which pertained to the requirement of purchasing a rummage sale permit, and derived from the Code of 1980, § 16-98. 
Sec. 90-29. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1420-16, § 1, adopted Aug. 9, 2016, repealed § 90-29, which pertained to false statements on rummage sale permit applications, and derived from the Code of 1980, § 16-99. 
Chapter 92 - SIGNS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1128-06, adopted Feb. 14, 2006, repealed ch. 92, which consisted of §§ 92-1-92-64, and enacted new provisions to be designated as ch. 92, §§ 92-1-92-65. Former ch. 92 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 674-94, adopted Sept. 27, 1994; Ord. No. 745-97, adopted June 10, 1997; Ord. No. 769-98, adopted Feb. 24, 1998; and Ord. No. 914-02, adopted Sept. 24, 2002. 
Charter reference- Powers of city, § 2.1 et seq.; council, § 3.1 et seq.; director of administration, § 5.1 et seq.; licensing, taxation, and regulation of businesses, occupations, professions, etc., § 12.1. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; duties of chief financial officer, § 2-112; director of administration, § 2-201 et seq.; advertising, ch. 6; obscene advertisements, § 6-4; handbills, § 6-26 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; businesses, ch. 22; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98; subdivisions, ch. 102; traffic and vehicles, ch. 110. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 92-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in the chapter, the following words shall mean: 
    Advertising media: Banner, pennant, streamer, wind operated mechanism, flashing lights, and any other type of fluttering or flashing device, or person or animal used for attracting attention. 
    Awning: Any device or structure entirely supported by the structure to which it is attached and which is covered by canvas, cloth or other material, which may be retractable or rolled to the structure by which it is supported. 
    Canopy: Any structure other than an awning, attached to a building or structure and supported independently of that building structure. Porticos and portecocheres shall be considered canopies for the purpose of this chapter. 
    Church bulletin board: A sign attached to the exterior of a church or located elsewhere on the church premises and used to indicate the services and/or other activities of the church. 
    Director: The director of administration of the City of Fulton and any of his delegates or assistants. 
    Erect: To build, construct, attach, hang, rehang, place, affix, locate, relocate, paint or repaint. 
    Flagpole: A pole constructed of metal or similar material permanently affixed to the ground or a structure designed for the display of a flag. 
    Marquee: A device or structure entirely supported by the structure to which it is attached which is permanent in nature and projects over the entrance or door of a building. 
    Office building: A building occupied by one or more businesses or noncommercial entities. 
    Shopping plaza and shopping center: A tract of ground occupied by one or more businesses or commercial entities. 
    Sign: Any letter, word, model, design, device, representation, name, identification, description, display or illustration which is affixed to, supported by, painted or represented directly or indirectly upon a building, structure or a piece of land which directs attention to an object, product, place, activity, person, institution, organization or business. However, the definition of a sign shall not include the flag of the United States of America, the State of Missouri, other foreign countries or states. The definition of a sign also shall not include any display of official court or public office notices, nor shall a sign include any letter, word, model, design, device, representation, name, identification, description, display or illustration located completely within an enclosed building, not otherwise endangering public health and safety. The definition of a "sign" includes all sign supports and structural trim as defined herein. 
    Sign, advertising: A sign advertising any off-premises business, product, or function, mounted above ground. Can be no higher than 35 feet above ground to the top of sign and no more than 200 square feet. 
    Sign, attached: A wall sign or projecting sign attached to a building wall or the generally vertical plane of a mansard type roof. 
    Sign, commercial neighborhood business: A ground sign allowed in a commercial neighborhood business (C-NB) zoning district, a district which is allowed only along Business Highway 54. 
    Sign, construction: A temporary sign used during construction of new buildings, or reconstruction of or additions to existing buildings, such as those identifying the project and denoting the owner, architect, engineer, contractor and/or financing institutions of the project. 
    Sign, directional/informational: A sign which indicates a direction or provides information for vehicular or pedestrian traffic or other movement information. 
    Sign, directory: An occupational or identification sign containing at least one name within a single sign. 
    Sign, flashing: An illuminated sign on which artificial light is not steady or on which colors change. 
    Sign, fluttering: A sign which flutters and includes pennants, banners, nongovernmental flags or other flexible material which moves with the wind or by some artificial means. 
    Sign, ground: Any detached sign mounted on the ground having its highest point not more than ten feet above the ground. 
    Sign, hanging: Any sign hanging entirely beneath a canopy, portico or marquee, or similar structure. 
    Sign, institutional or governmental: A sign identifying the institutional or governmental facility. 
    Sign, marquee, canopy and awning: A sign attached to or illustrated on a marquee, canopy, or awning respectively. 
    Sign, moveable: A sign which is not permanently affixed to a structure or the ground. 
    Sign, moving: A sign, all or any part of which, moves by any means. Such sign includes a fluttering sign. 
    Sign, nonconforming: A sign legally erected under any previously existing ordinances of the city which does not conform to the provisions of this chapter. 
    Sign, on site informational: An informational sign located on a commercial, institutional, governmental, or other similar site which gives parking, fire protection, traffic flow (other than directional signs), height clearance, pedestrian, or other similar information and which does not advertise the business or use located on the site. 
    Sign, political: A temporary sign advocating or opposing any political proposition or candidate for public office. 
    Sign, post: Any detached sign which is supported by one or more posts the bottom edge of which is the minimum of ten feet above the ground. 
    Sign, projecting: Any sign which projects more than 12 inches beyond the plane of the wall on which the sign is erected or attached. 
    Sign, reader board: Any permanent sign upon which a changeable message may be placed or which projects a moving or changing message in lights such as, but not limited to "time and temperature" readouts. 
    Sign, real estate: A sign pertaining only to the prospective rental, lease or sale of the property on which it is located. 
    Sign, roof: Any sign erected on a roof. For the purposes of this chapter, signs erected on top of a marquee, portico, canopy or similar structure shall be considered roof signs. Signs erected on the generally vertical plane of a mansard or similar style roof shall not be considered roof signs. 
    Sign, sandwich type board or "A" frame: A sign for display only during business hours and not to interfere with pedestrian traffic. 
    Sign, subdivision: An entry sign identifying a residential subdivision entry, subdivision name and/or street names within the subdivision. Such a sign may include a map of the subdivision. 
    Sign, temporary: Any sign intended for a limited period of display. 
    Sign, wall: A sign erected or attached against the wall of any building or against the generally vertical plane of a mansard type roof with the plane for the sign face parallel to the plane of the wall below the roof line. 
    Sign area: The total area of the space to be used for advertising purposes, including the spaces between open-type letters and figures, including the background structure, or other decoration or addition which is an integral part of the sign. Sign supports shall be excluded in determining the area of a sign. A double-faced sign shall have double the total area of a single-faced sign. 
    Sign facing or surface: Any surface of a sign upon, against or through which the advertising message is displayed or illustrated on the sign, including structural trim, which displays or upon which is displayed any color, message, name or symbol of any kind for the purpose advertising, announcing, directing or attracting attention from the outside of a building and which can be seen from a single location on an adjacent street provided that the ends, or thickness, of a sign shall not be counted as a separate sign face unless an advertising message is conveyed thereon. 
    Sign structure: The sign and all parts associated with its construction or support. 
    Sign supports: All structures by which a sign is held up, including, for example, poles, braces, guys and anchors. All such supports shall be considered part of the sign as defined herein. 
    Structural trim: The molding, battens, cappings, nailing strips, latticing and platforms which are attached to the sign structure. 
    Zoning ordinance: The zoning ordinance of the City of Fulton and/or chapter of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Fulton, and the current district map related thereto. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06; Ord. No. 1245-09, 3-10-09) 
Sec. 92-2. - Effect of zoning regulations. 
    No permit shall be issued for a sign nor shall any sign be erected, installed, maintained or displayed in any zoning district of the City of Fulton except as illustrated below. 
(a)  Signs in residential districts: Subject to the limitations herein set forth, the following signs shall be permitted in the R-1, R-2, R-3, MH-1, PUD districts: 
(1)  Church bulletin boards not to exceed 20 square feet; 
(2)  Political signs; 
(3)  Real estate and construction signs; 
(4)  Temporary signs for political purposes, real estate and rummage sales as defined in chapter 90 shall be exempt from fees; 
(5)  Permanent subdivision signs; 
(6)  Institutional or governmental signs; 
(7)  Official government flags; 
(8)  Wall signs in conjunction with legitimate commercial activity not to exceed 32 square feet; 
(9)  Directional/informational signs; and 
(10)  On-site informational signs. 
(b)  Signs in commercial districts: Subject to the limitations hereinafter set forth, the following signs shall be permitted in the C-1, C-2, C-3, M-1, M-2 districts: 
(1)  All signs and flags permitted in residential districts; 
(2)  Sign, directory; 
(3)  Sign, ground; 
(4)  Sign, hanging; 
(5)  Sign, canopy, and/or awning; 
(6)  Sign, reader board; 
(7)  Sign, roof; 
(8)  Sign, temporary; 
(9)  Sign, wall; 
(10)  Sign, post; 
(11)  Sign, fluttering; 
(12)  Sign, sandwich type board or "A" frame; 
(13)  Sign, projecting; 
(14)  Sign, advertising, and 
(15)  Sign, movable. 
(c)  Signs, advertising shall be permitted in C-3 districts only. 
(d)  Signs in A-1 district shall be limited to advertisement of agricultural products only and activities related directly to the property. All signs in subsection (b) above shall be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-3. - Registration of signs required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or have erected a sign of any type defined in this chapter, or to collect or contract for the payment of any rental or charge on account of any such sign placed, to be placed, maintained or to be maintained within the city unless such sign is authorized by permit by the director of administration or his/her designee. 
(b)  Registration shall be made on forms furnished by the City of Fulton and each sign so registered shall receive a number which shall be recorded and kept by the director, or designee for that purpose. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the director, or designee to make, at least annually, a thorough inspection of all signs in the city. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-4. - Removal of unlawful signs, notice to be given. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner of the property on which a sign has been erected to cause any unlawful sign to be removed. 
(b)  In cases involving all signs except moveable signs, the property owner shall be given five working days after issuance of notice to remove all unlawful signs. Notice shall be given by leaving a written report of the violation with an individual of lawful age at the owner's place of business or by addressing a certified letter to said owner and mailing same to his last known address. 
(c)  Any property owner allowing an unlawful sign to continue to be displayed for more than five working days after a notice to remove said sign is issued shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $50.00 per day for each day that the unlawful sign is displayed, without further notice. 
(d)  In the event that a moveable sign is unlawfully displayed, it shall be the responsibility of the owner of the property on which such sign is located to cause the unlawful sign to be removed within two days after issuance of a notice to remove such sign, and the penalty for nonremoval shall be that set forth above. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-5. - Signs conflicting with traffic-control devices prohibited. 
    Any sign or device which by color, location or design resembles, conflicts or interferes with traffic-control signs or devices is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Secs. 92-6-92-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERMITS AND FEES 

Sec. 92-21. - Required. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided herein, no sign of the types defined in section 92-1 shall be erected, nor the location of any existing sign changed, until a permit therefore shall have been issued by the director or his/her designee. 
(b)  No existing sign shall be enlarged, rebuilt, structurally altered or relocated except in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and until a permit therefore has been issued by the director or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-22. - Application for permit. 
    No permit shall be granted until after an application has been filed with the director or designee showing the plans and specifications, including dimensions, material and details of construction of the proposed sign structure, nor until all the provisions of this chapter relating to such sign structure have been complied with. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-23. - Authority for director to vary form or contents of applications. 
    The director may prescribe suitable regulations, not inconsistent with the provisions of this article, concerning the form or content of all applications for permits herein required. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-24. - Fees. 
(a)  The application for a permit required by this article shall be accompanied by a permit fee as set out below: 
(1)  The fee for a permit for a sign, as defined herein, at any one location, regardless of size, including temporary signs, shall be as follows: 
$20.00 for the first sign. 
$5.00 for each additional sign or ballast. 
(2)  The permit fee for multifaced or multisided signs shall be based on the total area of all faces or sides. 
(b)  The permit fees herein provided for shall cover the inspection of the location of the proposed signs and inspections during and after construction and erection; and all moneys so collected by the director or his/her designee shall be turned over to the finance officer for deposit in the general revenue fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-25. - Issuance of permit not to relieve owner from duty of maintaining sign safety. 
    The issuance of a permit required by this article shall not relieve the owner or lessee of the premises from the duty of maintaining any of the structures regulated by this article. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Secs. 92-26-92-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STANDARDS AND REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 92-41. - Signs in violation of chapter prohibited; exception. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, install, have installed, maintain or display, on or in connection with any premises within the City of Fulton, any sign, poster, letter, picture or advertising device in violation of any provisions of this chapter, or any type of sign not specifically allowed and detailed in this article. 
(b)  The use of any sign or advertising device lawfully existing and maintained as of the date of approval of this chapter, and made unlawful by the provisions of this chapter, may be continued and maintained, provided however, that in the event such sign or advertising device is damaged or destroyed to the extent of 50 percent of its replacement value or is altered or moved, or is no longer nonconforming due to a change in use of its associated property such that the new use requires different signs, then such sign or advertising device shall be made to comply with all of the requirements of this chapter, or removed. 
(c)  A sign shall cease being legally nonconforming upon the closing or change of ownership of the business with which it is associated. No subsequent use or owner will have any claim to the nonconforming sign and may only erect signs which comply with the Code of Ordinances of the City of Fulton. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-42. - Display of advertising on signs restricted; removal of signs no longer applicable to property required. 
(a)  Except for signs advertising or announcing the development of property for residential purposes at another location within the city as provided for in section 92-61, no sign shall display any advertising matter except that which pertains to the business conducted on the premises or in the building upon which such sign is placed. 
(b)  Any sign which is no longer applicable to the property or building upon which such sign is located shall be considered an unlawful sign, and shall be removed under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-43. - Unsafe signs. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or permit to remain upon any premises owned, leased, occupied or used by him with notice thereof, any unsafe or insecure sign liable to injure any person or property, or to maintain or permit to remain on any such premises any sign which because of its deteriorated condition or appearance would have a negative effect upon other property in the city. 
(b)  Any sign found to be unsafe under the provisions of this section shall be deemed an unlawful sign and shall be ordered removed under the provisions of section 92-4. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-44. - Prohibited signs. 
    The following types of signs are prohibited: 
(1)  Flashing signs except when defined in section 92-1 as reader boards. 
(2)  Marquee signs; 
(3)  Moving signs (operated mechanically, electrically, electronically, or by wind or other forces of nature except as provided in section 92-46); 
(4)  Paper, cloth, cardboard or other similar nonpermanent material signs except as provided in section 92-63; 
(5)  Post signs except as provided for in sections 92-52, 92-55 and 92-57. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-45. - Signs not to obstruct fire escapes. 
    No sign of any description shall be installed, erected, constructed or maintained in such a manner as to obstruct any fire escape. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-46. - Mechanical contrivances prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, install, maintain or display on or in connection with any premises owned, occupied or used by him any sign, which shall contain flashers, animators or mechanical movements or contrivances of any kind, excepting clocks and electronic reader boards. Any such sign so erected shall be an unlawful sign within the meaning of this chapter and shall be subject to removal by the director or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-47. - Awning and canopy signs. 
    All awning and canopy signs shall be subject to the general restrictions of wall signs and shall: 
(1)  Not exceed two feet in height; 
(2)  Maintain a clearance of at least ten feet above the ground or pavement in any place where there will be pedestrian or vehicular traffic beneath it; and 
(3)  Be painted or similarly affixed and may be constructed of the same material as the awning or canopy when such signs are applied to cloth or similar material. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-48. - Church bulletin boards. 
    Church bulletin boards shall be subject to the general restrictions of ground signs or wall signs, whichever is applicable, and not exceed 20 square feet in sign area. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-48.1 - Commercial neighborhood business sign. 
All commercial neighborhood business signs shall: 
(1)  Be a ground sign located in the commercial neighborhood business (C-NB) zoning district which is allowed only along Business Highway 54. 
(2)  Be limited to a height of no more than six feet including the supporting structure. 
(3)  Be limited to 24 square feet per face and may be internally lit. 
(4)  Be limited to only one sign of any type per residential structure. 
(Ord. No. 1245-09, 3-10-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1245-09, adopted Mar. 10, 2009, enacted provisions intended for use as § 92-49. To preserve the style of this Code, and at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been codified as § 92-48.1. 
Sec. 92-49. - Construction signs. 
    All construction signs shall be subject to the general restrictions of ground signs, if applicable, and shall: 
(1)  Be limited to one such sign per subdivision, or development; 
(2)  Not to exceed 32 square feet in area; and 
(3)  Be removed within ten days of the final inspection of the last structure of the subdivision or development. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-50. - Directional and information signs. 
    All directional and informational signs shall: 
(1)  Not exceed three feet in height and six square feet in area; 
(2)  Contain only directional text; 
(3)  Use no advertising verbiage except logo and name; 
(4)  Be limited to six signs per parcel or development; and 
(5)  Not be counted toward total allowable signage. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-51. - Directory signs. 
    All directory signs and properties displaying directory signs are subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  Only office buildings and shopping centers are allowed to display a directory sign. 
(2)  Where a single parcel of land contains multiple office buildings, shopping centers, or combinations thereof, each may have a directory sign provided there is a minimum of 500 linear feet of roadway frontage between each sign. 
(3)  Shopping centers and office buildings containing less than 30,000 square feet of gross floor area may have a directory sign containing a total of 200 square feet. 
Shopping centers and office buildings containing 30,000-50,000 square feet of gross floor area may have a directory sign containing a total of 300 square feet. 
Shopping centers and office buildings containing 50,000 square feet or more of gross floor area may have a directory sign containing a total of 400 square feet. 
The distribution of space on any such sign will be as follows: 
a.  A maximum of 50 percent of such sign may contain the name of the shopping center or the office building. The remaining sign area shall be divided equally between the units of the center or the building. 
b.  In the event of subsequent division or combination of units within a shopping center or other building, each unit shall be allowed a maximum sign area proportional to that unit's percentage of the gross square footage of the shopping center or other building. 
(4)  A directory sign not meeting the provisions for wall signs may be erected on one or more posts, provided such sign: 
a.  Has a maximum height of 25 feet above the ground level below the sign; 
b.  Has a minimum height of ten feet above the mean ground level below the sign; 
c.  Is not within ten feet of any property line; 
d.  Is constructed in a front yard as defined in the zoning ordinance; 
e.  Is built of noncombustible materials; 
f.  Is illuminated only internally. 
(5)  No shopping center or office building shall have any ground or post sign other than a directory sign. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-52. - Fluttering signs. 
(a)  Nongovernment flags no greater than five by eight feet. 
(b)  Pennants, streamers or other flexible material which moves with the wind or by some artificial means. 
(c)  Shall be located at least ten feet from property lines. 
(d)  Shall not exceed thirty five feet in height from ground to top of pole. 
(e)  No fluttering sign shall be erected within 25 feet of street intersections. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-53. - Ground signs. 
    Ground signs are subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  They shall be located no closer than six feet to adjacent right-of-way lines or structures; 
(2)  They shall not obstruct vision at any intersection or vehicular access point; 
(3)  They may not exceed six feet in height above the mean ground level under the sign; 
(4)  The height of any planter, pedestal or support structure shall be included in the calculation of sign height; 
(5)  No associated support structure shall exceed a height of six feet;
