(6)  No ground sign shall exceed 100 square feet in area except as provided in this chapter; 
(7)  Not more than one ground sign shall be erected on any one lot or tract of land, except that one sign for each 300 feet of frontage may be erected provided that such signs are located 300 feet apart on such lot or tract of land. No ground sign when erected on a lot fronting on intersecting streets shall be erected within 25 feet of the intersection of the streets; 
(8)  They shall not be erected on any parcel or premises which has an existing ground or directory sign except as provided herein; and 
(9)  On corner lots a ground sign will be allowed on each street side of such building. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-54. - Hanging signs. 
    All hanging signs shall: 
(1)  Only be permitted under permanent structures such as canopies and covered walkways; 
(2)  Be firmly attached to their mounting and may not move in the wind; 
(3)  Provide a minimum of seven feet of clearance to ground level; and 
(4)  Not exceed six inches high by 18 inches wide in area. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-55. - Informational post signs. 
    Post signs indicating the direction to any noncommercial institution or place may be erected and maintained on the parkway or side of a public street, alley or place under the following conditions: 
(1)  The sign serves a public purpose and a public necessity for such directional sign exists; 
(2)  The noncommercial institution or place is within the City of Fulton; and 
(3)  Such sign shall not exceed 18 inches by 24 inches in size, and shall be installed under the supervision of the director or designee in a manner and at a height so as not to interfere with the ordinary and lawful use of the street. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-56. - Institutional and governmental signs. 
(a)  Institutional and governmental signs shall: 
(1)  Be either ground or wall signs; 
(2)  Not be over 32 square feet in area or exceed ten feet in height above the mean grade at its base in any residential zone district; 
(3)  Be located only on the property at a governmental agency or not-for-profit institutional property; 
(4)  Not be nearer than ten feet to any property line, and 
(5)  Be subject to the general restrictions of ground or wall signs except as provided herein. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not be construed so as to prohibit a governmental agency or institution from having signs otherwise allowed in any commercial district. 
(c)  The director of administration shall approve all banners erected across or along the public right-of-way for noncommercial purposes. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-57. - Post signs. 
(a)  Post signs shall not be over 85 square feet in area per face and 170 square feet total. Except that an additional one-half square foot of sign area may be allowed for every lineal foot of street frontage over 175 feet up to a total of not more than 250 square feet per side or 500 square feet total. 
(b)  Shall be located at least ten feet from property line. 
(c)  Shall not exceed 35 feet from ground to top of sign. Except signs with frontage along By-Pass U.S. Highway 54 may be 50 feet in height. 
(d)  Not more than one post sign shall be erected on any one lot or tract of land, except that one sign for each 300 feet of frontage may be erected provided that such signs are located 300 feet apart on such lot or tract of land. No post sign when erected on a lot fronting on intersecting streets shall be erected within 25 feet of the intersection of the streets. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-58. - Projecting signs. 
(a)  Must be 15 feet above the pavement. 
(b)  Cannot be over four feet tall or 42 inches wide in area. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-59. - Roof signs. 
    Not withstanding other provisions of this chapter to the contrary, roof signs are allowed only when the unique architectural design of the structure does not provide a location for a wall sign. When allowed, roof signs shall: 
(1)  Be limited in size to a sign area not greater that ten percent of the area of the front wall of the building or portion of the building occupied, or 100 square feet, whichever is less; 
(2)  Be allowed only to advertise the business conducted in the building upon which the sign is mounted; 
(3)  Not extend beyond the exterior walls of the building upon which the sign is mounted; and 
(4)  Be constructed entirely of noncombustible materials. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-60. - Seasonal signs and display. 
    Property owners and tenants shall be permitted to put up and display decorations and displays celebrating or denoting religious holidays or events, the seasons of the year, state and national holidays and similar occasions, subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  No such display shall be in place for a period exceeding 75 days; 
(2)  No such display may convey a commercial advertising message or bear the name of a business or product; and 
(3)  Should any such display fail to meet the criteria outlined herein, it shall be deemed to be in violation of section 92-4. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-61. - Signs for sale or lease of real estate and commercial properties. 
(a)  Signs which advertise the sale or lease of real estate of less than one acre and which are located upon the property or premises to which such signs refer shall not exceed six square feet in area, shall not be erected with ten feet of any line of the property on which it is erected and shall not exceed two in number for any lot or tract of ground advertised; but shall be otherwise exempt from the remaining provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Signs which advertise the sale, lease or coming development of real estate of one acre or more shall be located upon the property or premises to which such signs refer, shall not exceed 32 square feet in area, and shall be limited to one in number for any tract or parcel. 
(c)  One sign announcing the development of property for residential purposes at another location within the city may be permitted and maintained, provided however, that no such sign shall exceed 32 square feet total display area nor be displayed or maintained longer than is allowed by this chapter, and provided that no more than one such sign is erected, displayed or maintained at any one time for any individual development. 
(d)  Any signs allowed under this section shall not be included in any total signage allocation for said parcel or development and shall be removed within ten days of the sale or lease of the property being advertised. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-62. - Subdivision signs. 
    Subdivision signs shall: 
(1)  Not be located within any dedicated right-of-way; 
(2)  Conform to the general provisions of ground signs except as provided herein; 
(3)  Be limited in location to subdivision entrances; and 
(4)  Have a maximum sign area of 100 square feet of total sign area although this may be split between each side of an entrance road. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-63. - Temporary signs. 
    Notwithstanding other provisions of this chapter to the contrary, temporary signs advertising or announcing a special event or sale of merchandise may be permitted and maintained subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  Temporary signs shall be either ground signs or wall signs and shall be governed by the appropriate general regulations except as contained herein; 
(2)  Temporary signs shall: 
a.  Not exceed 32 square feet in sign area. 
b.  Have no more than two sides. 
c.  Not be displayed for longer than 15 consecutive days. 
d.  Be limited to one sign for any particular business at any time. 
e.  Only be displayed on the building or premises of the business advertised. 
f.  Be displayed no more than four times in any 12-month period. 
g.  Not be displayed for two consecutive 15-day periods. 
h.  Obtain and pay for a temporary permit for each occasion of display. 
Exemption: Temporary signs for political purposes, real estate and rummage sales as defined in chapter 90 shall be exempt from fees. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-64. - Wall signs. 
    Wall signs are subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  Except as provided herein, no wall sign or signs shall be allowed to exceed 100 square feet for any single building, store or occupied unit. 
(2)  Any commercial building or occupied unit shall be permitted a wall sign having an area equal to 20 percent of the area of the front wall of the building or portion of the building occupied. 
(3)  A sign not to exceed 300 square feet may be placed on a building the front wall of which is not less than 300 feet to the right-of-way line of a public street or to the limits of any other street or roadway. 
(4)  Any building occupied by a single tenant and having a front wall area of over 2,000 square feet adjoining a public street may have a wall sign with a sign area not in excess of ten percent of the area of the front wall of such building, provided however, that the area of a wall sign shall not exceed 300 square feet. 
(5)  A building on a corner lot may have signs on each street side of such building, and the area of each wall adjoining a public street shall be computed separately to determine the size of the sign which may be erected on each wall. 
(6)  All wall signs shall be made of noncombustible materials. Moldings and cappings may be made of wood. 
(7)  All wall signs shall be safely and securely attached to a building. 
(8)  No wall sign shall project beyond or above the face of the surface to which it is attached. 
(9)  No wall sign shall be erected so as to cover the doors or windows of any building, or otherwise prevent free ingress and egress to or from any window, door or fire escape of any building. 
(10)  No wall sign shall extend more than 12 inches from the surface to which it is attached. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 92-65. - Maximum total sign area. 
    The maximum total sign area that may be exhibited or maintained by, for or on behalf of any one person or business establishment occupying any tract of land or premises shall be 200 square feet; except as set out in sections 92-57 and 92-64. 
(Ord. No. 1128-06, 2-14-06) 
Chapter 93 - SMOKING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The election of Nov. 2, 2010, enacted the provisions of Ord. No. 1288-10 which became effective December 1, 2010. 

Sec. 93-1. - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the Fulton Clean Indoor Air Act of 2010. 
(Ord. No. 1288-10, 11-2-10) 
Sec. 93-2. - Findings and intent. 
    The Fulton City Council does hereby find that: 
2006 United States Surgeon General's Report 
 Secondhand smoke exposure causes disease and premature death in children and adults who do not smoke. 
 Exposure of adults to secondhand smoke has immediate adverse effects on the cardiovascular system and causes coronary heart disease and lung cancer.  There is no risk-free level of exposure to secondhand smoke. 
 Establishing smoke-free workplaces is the only effective way to ensure that secondhand smoke exposure does not occur in the workplace, because ventilation and other air cleaning technologies cannot completely control for exposure of nonsmokers to secondhand smoke. 
2009 Institute of Medicine Report 
 Exposure to secondhand smoke increases the risk of coronary heart disease by 25 to 30 percent. 
 It was shown that there was a decrease in the rate of heart attacks after a smoking policy was implemented. 
 It was concluded that secondhand smoke exposure increases the risk of coronary heart disease and heart attacks and that smoking policies reduce heart attacks. 
CARDIO2000 case-control study 
 A significant amount of secondhand smoke exposure occurs in the workplace. Employees who work in smoke-filled businesses suffer a 25-50% higher risk of heart attack and higher rates of death from cardiovascular disease and cancer, as well as increased acute respiratory disease and measurable decrease in lung function. 
California Environmental Protection Agency (Cal EPA) 
 Secondhand smoke is particularly hazardous to elderly people, individuals with cardiovascular disease, and individuals with impaired respiratory function, including asthmatics and those with obstructive airway disease. 
United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) 
 The CDC has warned that all patients at increased risk of coronary heart disease or with known coronary artery disease should avoid all indoor environments that permit smoking. 
The American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers 
(ASHRAE) position document 
 ASHRAE has determined that there is currently no air filtration or other ventilation technology that can completely eliminate all the carcinogenic components in secondhand smoke and the health risks caused by secondhand smoke exposure, and recommends that indoor environments be smokefree in their entirety. 
The Society of Actuaries 
 The Society of Actuaries has determined that secondhand smoke costs the U.S. economy roughly 10 billion dollars a year, 5 billion dollars in estimated medical costs associated with secondhand smoke exposure and 4.6 billion dollars in lost productivity. 
    Accordingly the City of Fulton finds and declares that the purpose of this chapter is to protect public and employee health by prohibiting smoking in places of employment. 
(Ord. No. 1288-10, 11-2-10) 
Sec. 93-3. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, whenever used in this chapter, shall be constructed as defined in this section: 
    Bar means an establishment that is devoted to the serving of alcoholic beverages for consumption by guests on the premises and in which the serving of food is only incidental to the consumption of those beverages, including but not limited to, taverns, nightclubs, cocktail lounges, and cabarets. 
    Business means a sole proprietorship, partnership, joint venture, corporation, or other business entity, either for-profit or not-for-profit, including retail establishments where goods and services are sold; professional corporations and other entities where legal, medical, dental, engineering, architectural, or other professional services are delivered. 
    Employee means a person who is employed by an employer in consideration for direct or indirect monetary wages or profit, and a person who volunteers his or her services for an entity. 
    Employer means a person, business, association, municipal corporation, or trust, with one or more individual persons. 
    Enclosed area means all space between a floor and ceiling that is bounded on all sides by walls, doorways, or windows, whether open or closed. A wall includes any retractable divider, garage door, or other physical barrier, whether temporary or permanent. 
    Place of employment means an area under the control of a public or private employer, including, but not limited to, work areas, private offices, employee lounges, restrooms, conference rooms, meeting rooms, classrooms, employee cafeterias, hallways, and vehicles. 
    Restaurant means an eating establishment, including but not limited to, coffee shops, cafeterias, sandwich stands, and private and public school cafeterias, which gives or offers the sale of food to the public, guests, or employees, as well as kitchens and catering facilities in which food is prepared in the premises for serving elsewhere. The term "restaurant" shall include a bar area within the restaurant. 
    Smoking means inhaling, exhaling, burning, or carrying any lighted or heated cigar, cigarette, or pipe in any manner or in any form. 
(Ord. No. 1288-10, 11-2-10) 
Sec. 93-4. - Prohibition of smoking in enclosed places of employment. 
    Smoking shall be prohibited in all enclosed places of employment within the City of Fulton, including but not limited to, the following places: 
(a)  Areas available to the general public in businesses patronized by the public, including but not limited to, banks, laundromats, professional offices, and retail establishments. 
(b)  Bars. 
(c)  Child care and adult day care facilities. 
(d)  Convention facilities. 
(e)  Educational facilities, both public and private. 
(f)  Libraries, museums. 
(g)  Polling places. 
(h)  Restaurants. 
(i)  Restrooms, lobbies, reception areas, hallways, stairways, break rooms, and other common-use areas. 
(j)  Retail stores. 
(k)  Rooms, chambers, places of meeting or public assembly, including school buildings, under the control of any agency, board, commission, committee or council of the city or a political subdivision of the state, to the extent the place is subject to the jurisdiction of the city. 
(l)  Theaters and other facilities primarily used for exhibiting motion pictures, stage, dramas, lectures, musical recitals, or other similar performances. 
(Ord. No. 1288-10, 11-2-10) 
Sec. 93-5. - Notification to employees of prohibition of smoking in places of employment. 
    This prohibition on smoking shall be communicated to all existing employees by the effective date of this chapter and to all prospective employees upon their application for employment. 
(Ord. No. 1288-10, 11-2-10) 
Sec. 93-6. - Prohibition of smoking in outdoor areas. 
    Smoking shall be prohibited in the following outdoor places within a distance of 15 feet outside entrances, operable windows, and ventilation systems of enclosed areas where smoking is prohibited, so as to insure that tobacco smoke does not enter those areas. 
(Ord. No. 1288-10, 11-2-10) 
Sec. 93-7. - Declaration of establishment as nonsmoking. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, an owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of an establishment, facility, or outdoor area may declare that entire establishment, facility, or outdoor area as a nonsmoking place. Smoking shall be prohibited in any place in which a sign conforming to the requirements of subsection 93-8(a) of this chapter is posted. 
(Ord. No. 1288-10, 11-2-10) 
Sec. 93-8. - Posting of signs and removal of ashtrays. 
(a)  "No Smoking" signs or the international "No Smoking" symbol (consisting of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle with a red bar across it) shall be clearly and conspicuously posted in every place of employment where smoking is prohibited by this chapter, by the owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of that place. 
(b)  Every place of employment where smoking is prohibited by this chapter shall have posted at every entrance a conspicuous sign clearly stating that smoking is prohibited. 
(c)  All ashtrays intended for use on premises shall be removed from any area where smoking is prohibited by this chapter by the owner, operator, manager, or other person having control of the area. 
(Ord. No. 1288-10, 11-2-10) 
Sec. 93-9. - Nonretaliation; nonwaiver of rights. 
(a)  No person or employer shall discharge, refuse to hire, or in any manner retaliate against an employee, applicant for employment, or customer because that employee, applicant, or customer exercises any rights afforded by this chapter or reports or attempts to prosecute a violation of this chapter. Notwithstanding section 93-10 of this chapter, violation of this subsection shall be a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 for each violation. 
(b)  An employee who works in a setting where an employer allows smoking does not waive or otherwise surrender any legal rights the employee may have against the employer or any other party. 
(Ord. No. 1288-10, 11-2-10) 
Sec. 93-10. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  A person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited by the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of an infraction, punishable by a fine not exceeding $50.00. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in subsection 93-9(a), a person who owns, manages, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment and who fails to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of an infraction, punishable by: 
(1)  A fine not exceeding $100.00 for a first violation. 
(2)  A fine not exceeding $200.00 for a second violation within one year. 
(3)  A fine not exceeding $500.00 for each additional violation within one year of the previous violation. 
(c)  In addition to the fines established by this section, violation of this chapter by a person who owns, manages, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment may result in the suspension or revocation of any permit or license issued to the person for the premises on which the violation occurred. 
(d)  Violation of this chapter is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, which may be abated by the city administrator by restraining order, preliminary and permanent injunction, or other means provided for by law, and the city may take action to recover the costs of the nuisance abatement. 
(e)  Each day on which a violation of this chapter occurs shall be considered a separate and distinct violation. 
(Ord. No. 1288-10, 11-2-10) 
Sec. 93-11. - Enforcement. 
    An owner, manager, operator, or employee of an establishment regulated by this chapter shall direct a person who is smoking to extinguish the product being smoked. If the person does not stop smoking, the owner, manager operator, or employee shall refuse service and shall immediately ask the person to leave the premises. If the person in violation refuses to leave the premises, the owner, manager, operator, or employee shall contact a law enforcement agency. 
    This chapter shall be enforced by the city administrator as he/she sees fit in accordance with the violation penalties describes in the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1288-10, 11-2-10) 
Sec. 93-12. - Other applicable laws. 
    This chapter shall not be interpreted or construed to permit smoking where it is otherwise restricted by other applicable laws. 
(Ord. No. 1288-10, 11-2-10) 
Sec. 93-13. - Severability. 
    If any provision, clause, sentence, or paragraph of this chapter or the application thereof to any person or circumstances shall be held invalid, that invalidity shall not affect the other provisions of this chapter which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this end the provisions of this chapter are declared to be severable. 
(Ord. No. 1288-10, 11-2-10) 
Sec. 93-14. - Effective date. 
    This chapter shall be effective 30 days from and after the date of its adoption. 
(Ord. No. 1288-10, 11-2-10) 
Chapter 94 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 46; floods, ch. 54; health and sanitation, ch. 58; parks and recreation, ch. 82; secondhand goods, ch. 90; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98; subdivisions, ch. 102; sewers and sewage disposal, § 114-171 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 94-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Battery or lead-acid battery means a battery designed to contain lead and sulfuric acid with a nominal voltage of at least six volts and of the type intended to use in motor, recreational, agricultural, construction, lawn and watercraft vehicles, etc. 
    Bulky rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of combustible and noncombustible waste materials from dwelling units; commercial, industrial, institutional, professional offices; or agricultural establishments which are either too large or too heavy to be safely and conveniently loaded in solid waste transportation vehicles by solid waste collectors with the equipment available therefor. 
    Collection means removal of solid waste from its place of storage to the transportation vehicles. 
    Compost site means an area used for the accumulation and reduction of yard waste into a decomposed state. 
    Composting means a controlled biological reduction of organic wastes to humus. 
    Curbside means a location adjacent to and not more than five feet from any street. 
    Demolition and construction waste means waste materials from the construction or destruction of residential, industrial or commercial structures. 
    Disposable solid waste container means disposable plastic or paper sacks with a capacity of not more than 35 gallons specifically designed for storage of solid waste. 
    Dwelling unit means any room or group of rooms located within a structure and forming a single habitable unit with facilities which are used or are intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking and eating. 
    Garbage means putrescible animal or vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, serving or consumption of food. 
    Hazardous wastes include but are not limited to pathological wastes, explosive wastes, pesticides, pesticide containers, toxic or radioactive materials. 
    Landfill means a refuse depository for the processing or final disposal of solid waste, which depository is licensed, permitted or approved by governmental bodies and agencies having jurisdiction. 
    Litter means solid wastes or unwanted material deposited in an improper place or manner. 
    Major appliance means clothes washers and dryers, water heaters, trash compactors, dishwashers, microwave ovens, conventional ovens, ranges, stoves, wood stoves, air conditioners, refrigerators and freezers. 
    Manager means the manager of the solid waste management program and department of the city or his authorized representative. 
    Multiple-housing facility means a housing facility containing more than one dwelling unit under one roof with a master water meter. 
    Nuisance means any act done or committed or suffered to be done or committed by any person or any substance or thing kept, maintained, placed or found in or upon any public or private place which is injurious or dangerous to the public health. 
    Occupant means any person who, along or jointly or severally with others, shall be in actual possession of any dwelling unit or of any other improved real property, either as owner or as a tenant. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, political subdivision or organization of any kind or the legal representative, agent or assign. 
    Processing means incinerating, composting, baling, shredding, salvaging, compacting and other processes whereby solid waste characteristics are modified or solid waste quantity is reduced. 
    Recyclable item or recyclables means newsprint, cardboard, steel, aluminum cans, glass, plastic and any other item designated by the solid waste manager. 
    Solid waste means unwanted or discarded waste materials in a solid or semisolid state, including but not limited to garbage, ashes, street refuse, rubbish, dead animals, animal and agricultural wastes, yard wastes and special wastes, but not including hazardous waste. 
Commercial solid waste means solid waste resulting from the operation of any commercial, industrial, institutional, professional office or agricultural establishment, except two or more commercial establishments in a single building requiring, in the opinion of the manager, only one solid waste pick up per week shall be considered a single commercial establishment. 
Residential building solid waste means solid waste resulting from the maintenance and operation of dwelling units, excluding individual sleeping rooms in motels, hotels, dormitories, boardinghouses, condominiums and like facilities. 
    Solid waste container means a receptacle used by any person to store solid waste during the interval between solid waste collections. 
    Solid waste disposal means the process of discarding or getting rid of unwanted material; in particular, the final disposition of solid waste by man. 
    Solid waste disposal area means any area used for the disposal of solid waste from more than one residential premises or one or more commercial, industrial, manufacturing, recreational or governmental operations. 
    Solid waste management means the entire solid waste system of storage, collection, transportation, processing and disposal. 
    Storage means keeping, maintaining or storing solid waste from the time of its production until the time of its collection. 
    Tire means a continuous solid or pneumatic rubber covering encircling the wheel of a motor vehicle or trailer as defined in RSMo ch. 301. 
    Transportation means the transporting of solid waste from the place of collection or processing to a solid waste processing facility or solid waste disposal area. 
    Waste tire means a tire that is no longer suitable for its original intended purpose because of wear, damage or defect. 
    Yard waste means leaves, grass, clippings, yard and garden vegetation to include shrubs, vegetable and flower garden waste and brush and trees produced as the result of lawn and garden care and maintenance. Christmas trees are included in this definition. The term does not include stumps, roots or shrubs with intact root balls. 
(Code 1980, § 12-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 94-2-94-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOLID WASTE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; parks and recreation board, § 82-51 et seq. 

Sec. 94-26. - Established. 
    There is established a solid waste department, the purpose of which is to provide for the solid waste management of the city. The department shall be organized and maintained as provided for by the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 12-2) 
Sec. 94-27. - Appointment of manager. 
    The director of administration with the consent of the mayor shall appoint a manager for the solid waste department. 
(Code 1980, § 12-3) 
Sec. 94-28. - Responsibilities of manager. 
(a)  The solid waste manager shall be responsible for all matters relating to the operation of the city landfill, trash pickup and solid waste management. 
(b)  The manager shall have supervisory responsibility for all activities and personnel of the solid waste department. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the manager to make all necessary inspections and investigations of any and all premises to see that this chapter is complied with, and it shall further be the duty of the manager to administer and enforce all sections of this chapter. 
(Code 1980, §§ 12-4, 32-15) 
Sec. 94-29. - Compensation. 
    The salary of the personnel of the solid waste department, established pursuant to section 94-26, shall be determined by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 12-5) 
Secs. 94-30-94-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LITTER[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Offenses against property, § 78-51 et seq. 

Sec. 94-51. - Throwing upon streets, sidewalks or public places. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place within the city, except in public receptacles, in authorized private receptacles for collection or in official city dumpsters. 
(Code 1980, § 12-15) 
Sec. 94-52. - Placing in receptacles to prevent scattering. 
    Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. 
(Code 1980, § 12-16) 
Sec. 94-53. - Sweeping into gutters, streets or public places. 
    No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. 
(Code 1980, § 12-17) 
Sec. 94-54. - Cleanliness of sidewalks generally. 
    Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk in front of their premises free of litter. 
(Code 1980, § 12-18) 
Sec. 94-55. - Merchants to keep sidewalks free of litter. 
    Persons owning or occupying places of business within the city shall keep the sidewalk in front of their business premises free of litter. 
(Code 1980, § 12-19) 
Sec. 94-56. - Throwing from vehicle. 
    No person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit any litter upon any street or other public place within the city or upon private property. 
(Code 1980, § 12-20) 
Sec. 94-57. - Throwing in parks. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any park within the city, except in public receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of the park or upon any street or other public place. Where public receptacles are not provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere, as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1980, § 12-21) 
Sec. 94-58. - Throwing in fountains, lakes or other water bodies. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any fountain, pond, lake, stream, bay or other body of water in a park or elsewhere within the city. 
(Code 1980, § 12-22) 
Sec. 94-59. - Dropping from aircraft. 
    No person in any aircraft shall throw out, drop or deposit within the city any litter. 
(Code 1980, § 12-23) 
Sec. 94-60. - Depositing on occupied private property. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any occupied private property within the city, whether owned by such person or not; provided, however, the owner or person in control of private property may maintain authorized private receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon any private property. 
(Code 1980, § 12-24) 
Sec. 94-61. - Depositing on vacant private property. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant private property within the city, whether owned by such person or not. 
(Code 1980, § 12-25) 
Sec. 94-62. - Blowing from loaded trucks. 
    No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the city unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley or other public place. 
(Code 1980, § 12-26) 
Sec. 94-63. - Maintenance of private premises. 
    The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter. However, this section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized receptacles for collection. 
(Code 1980, § 12-27) 
Secs. 94-64-94-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STORAGE, COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 94-86. - Authority for rules and regulations. 
(a)  Manager's authority. The manager shall make, amend, revoke and enforce reasonable and necessary rules and regulations under this chapter, governing but not limited to: 
(1)  Preparation, drainage and wrapping of garbage deposited in solid waste containers. 
(2)  Specifications for solid waste containers, including the type, composition, equipment, size and shape thereof. 
(3)  Identification of solid waste containers and of the covers thereof and of equipment thereto appertaining, if any. 
(4)  Weight limitations on the combined weight of solid waste containers and the contents thereof and weight and size limitations on bundles of solid waste too large for solid waste containers. 
(5)  Storage of solid waste in solid waste containers. 
(6)  Sanitation, maintenance and replacement of solid waste containers. 
(7)  Schedules of and routes for collection and transportation of solid waste. 
(8)  Collection points of solid waste containers. 
(9)  Collection, transportation, processing and disposal of solid waste. 
(10)  Processing facilities and fees for the use thereof. 
(11)  Disposal facilities and fees for the use thereof. 
(12)  Records of quantity and type of wastes received at processing and disposal facilities. 
(13)  Handling of special wastes such as toxic wastes, sludges, ashes, agriculture, construction, bulky items, tires, automobiles, oils, greases, batteries, etc. 
(14)  Issuance of permits for hauling solid waste by other than city vehicles. 
(b)  Chief financial officer and other officials' authority. The chief financial officer or such other city official who is responsible for preparing utility and other service charge billings for the city is authorized to make and promulgate reasonable and necessary rules and regulations for the billing and collection of solid waste collection and disposal service charges, as provided in division 3 of this article. 
(c)  Copy. A copy of any and all rules and regulations made and promulgated under this section shall be approved by the director of administration and filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1980, § 12-44) 
Sec. 94-87. - Containers required. 
    The occupant of every dwelling unit and of every institutional, commercial or business, industrial, professional office or agricultural establishment producing solid waste shall provide sufficient and adequate containers for the storage of all solid wastes, except bulky rubbish and demolition and construction waste, to serve each such dwelling unit and establishment and shall maintain such solid waste containers at all times in good repair. 
(Code 1980, § 12-36) 
Sec. 94-88. - Placement in containers required; maintenance of containers and surrounding area. 
    The occupant of every dwelling unit and of every institutional, commercial, industrial, agricultural or business establishment shall place all solid waste to be collected in proper solid waste containers, except as otherwise provided in this article, and shall maintain such solid waste containers and the area surrounding them in a clean, neat and sanitary condition at all times. 
(Code 1980, § 12-37) 
Sec. 94-89. - Container specifications. 
(a)  Residential waste. Residential solid waste shall be stored in containers which are leakproof, waterproof and fitted with a flytight lid and which shall be properly covered at all times, except when depositing waste therein or removing the contents thereof. The containers shall have handles, bails or other suitable lifting devices or features. Containers shall be of a type originally manufactured for residential solid waste, with tapered sides for easy emptying. They shall be of lightweight and sturdy construction. The weight of any individual container and contents shall not exceed 50 pounds. Galvanized metal containers or rubber, fiberglass or plastic containers which do not become brittle in cold weather may be used. Disposable solid waste containers with suitable frames or containers as approved by the director may be also used for storage of residential solid waste. 
(b)  Commercial waste. Commercial solid waste shall be stored in solid waste containers as approved by the manager. The containers shall be waterproof, leakproof and shall be covered at all times, except when depositing waste therein or removing the contents thereof, and shall meet all requirements as set forth by section 94-86. 
(Code 1980, § 12-38) 
Sec. 94-90. - Tree limbs. 
    Tree limbs less than four inches in diameter and brush shall be securely tied in bundles not larger than 48 inches long and 18 inches in diameter when not placed in storage containers. The weight of any individual bundle shall not exceed 50 pounds. 
(Code 1980, § 12-39) 
Sec. 94-91. - Yard wastes, recyclables. 
    Yard wastes and recyclables shall be stored in transparent bags or so contained as to have their contents visible and prevent the dispersal of wastes placed therein upon the premises served, upon adjacent premises or upon adjacent public rights-of-way. The weight of any individual container and contents shall not exceed 50 pounds. 
(Code 1980, § 12-40) 
Sec. 94-92. - Removal of unapproved containers. 
    Solid waste containers which are not approved will be collected, together with their contents, and disposed of. 
(Code 1980, § 12-41) 
Sec. 94-93. - Transportation. 
(a)  All solid waste transportation vehicles shall be maintained in a safe, clean and sanitary condition and shall be so constructed, maintained and operated as to prevent spillage of solid waste therefrom. All vehicles to be used for transportation of solid waste shall be constructed with watertight bodies and with covers which shall be an integral part of the vehicle or shall be a separate cover of suitable material with fasteners designed to secure all sides of the cover to the vehicle and shall be secured whenever the vehicle is transporting solid waste, or, as an alternate, the entire bodies thereof shall be enclosed, with only loading hoppers exposed. No solid waste shall be transported in the loading hoppers. 
(b)  Permits shall not be required for the removal, hauling or disposal of earth and rock material from grading or excavation activities or transportation and disposal of demolition and construction or inert industrial wastes; however, all such material shall be conveyed in tight vehicles, trucks or receptacles, so constructed and maintained that none of the material being transported shall spill upon the public rights-of-way. 
(Code 1980, § 12-42) 
Sec. 94-94. - Disposal. 
(a)  Solid wastes shall be deposited at a processing facility or disposal area approved by the city, complying with all requirements of the state department of natural resources and RSMo 260.200-260.276. 
(b)  The manager may classify certain wastes as hazardous wastes which will require special handling and shall be disposed of only in a manner acceptable to the manager and which will meet all local, state and federal regulations. 
(c)  The dumping of solid waste at any place within the city limits, except at the designated city disposal ground or at such other places as may be directed by the manager, is prohibited. 
(Code 1980, § 12-43) 
Sec. 94-95. - Prohibited practices. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Deposit solid waste in any solid waste container other than his own, without the written consent of the owner of such container, or with the intent of avoiding payment of the service charge provided in division 3 of this article for solid waste collection and disposal. 
(2)  Interfere in any manner with solid waste collection and transportation equipment or with solid waste collectors in the lawful performance of their duties as such, whether or not such equipment and collectors are those of the city. 
(3)  Burn solid waste, unless an approved incinerator is provided or unless a variance has been obtained from the appropriate air quality control agency. 
(4)  Dispose of any refuse by depositing the refuse in any public alley, street, roadway, vacant lot or property of any kind or character within the city or belonging to the city or in any stream or body of water within the city or by burning garbage. However, nothing in this subsection shall be construed to prohibit the disposition of refuse by means of burning the refuse in an incinerator enclosed within a building and complying with applicable state law. Information obtained from waste disposed or deposited in violation of this subsection shall give rise to a rebuttable presumption that the person so identified committed the violation. 
(5)  Engage in the business of collecting, transporting, processing or disposing of solid waste within the corporate limits of the city without a permit from the city or operate under an expired permit or operate after a permit has been suspended or revoked. This permit is contingent upon the terms of this subsection and the specified type of solid waste and may be issued by the manager after the applicant obtains a city license. 
(6)  Scavenge or scatter any solid waste, including recyclables deposited by residents for pickup by solid waste collectors. 
(b)  The city shall not collect for disposal at its sanitary landfill nor shall it accept for disposal at its sanitary landfill any items prohibited by its license or by governmental bodies and agencies having jurisdiction, including but not limited to the following items: 
(1)  Hazardous waste. 
(2)  Infectious waste. 
(3)  Biomedical waste. 
(4)  Lead-acid batteries. 
(5)  Tires of any kind. 
(6)  Major appliances. 
(7)  Waste oil or oil of any kind, including oil filters or oily towels. 
(8)  Bulk liquids. 
(9)  Semisolids. 
(10)  Sludge. 
(11)  Highly flammable or volatile substances. 
(12)  Unexpended pesticide containers. 
(13)  Pesticides. 
(14)  Raw animal manure. 
(15)  Septic tank pumpings. 
(16)  Industrial process sludge. 
(17)  Radioactive waste. 
(18)  Explosives. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the city from establishing special pickup points or days to assist the residents of the city in disposing of the items mentioned in subsection (b) of this section. 
(Code 1980, § 12-46; Ord. No. 602-92, § 1, 4-28-92) 
Secs. 94-96-94-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COLLECTION 

Sec. 94-106. - Use of city vehicles; permit for use of other than city vehicles. 
(a)  All solid waste within the city shall be collected and disposed of by city vehicles only in accordance with and subject to this chapter. 
(b)  The manager may issue permits for the collection of solid wastes by other than city vehicles should the health and environment of the city so demand. All permits shall be issued only upon compliance with the rules and regulations established under section 94-86. 
(Code 1980, § 12-54) 
Sec. 94-107. - Hazardous or harmful substances; bulky rubbish. 
(a)  Nothing in this chapter shall require the city to accept, collect or dispose of any material, the collection or disposal of which is prohibited or regulated by the state or federal government as a hazardous substance, nor to require the city to collect or dispose of any material or object which, in the sole discretion of the manager, poses any undue threat of harm to the citizens or employees of the city or to any public property or improvement. 
(b)  All solid waste from premises to which collection services are provided by the city shall be collected, except bulky rubbish; provided, however, that bulky rubbish will be collected if tied securely in bundles not exceeding reasonable limitations of weight and bulk to be fixed by regulations to be made and promulgated by the manager. 
(c)  Any waste prohibited from landfills by the state or the federal government shall not be collected by the city. 
(d)  Any bulky waste shall not be collected by the city. 
(Code 1980, § 12-55) 
Sec. 94-108. - On-premises collection. 
(a)  Persons desiring on-premises collection may make application to the manager for such collection on forms approved by the manager. Such applications may be made in the following cases: 
(1)  For those persons who are permanently or temporarily physically unable to place their residential solid waste at the curb due to illness, accident, age or other physical incapacity. In such case and where the physical incapacity is temporary, the manager shall so determine in writing, and on-premises collection shall continue only for the time permitted by the manager. Nothing in this subsection shall prohibit a person from making subsequent applications for temporary on-premises collection. For those persons whom the manager determines to be permanently incapacitated, on-premises collection shall continue until terminated by the manager. 
(2)  Any person desiring on-premises collection, whether physically incapacitated or not, may apply to the manager for such collection on forms approved by the manager. The manager shall have discretion to approve or disapprove such application. 
(b)  Any application made under subsection (a) of this section and approved by the manager shall be personal in nature and nontransferable and shall terminate upon the conditions established by the manager in approving the application. 
(Code 1980, § 12-56) 
Sec. 94-109. - Bulky rubbish collection procedures. 
    Bulky rubbish shall be collected by request to the manager. The manager shall establish the procedure for collecting bulky rubbish. 
(Code 1980, § 12-58) 
Sec. 94-110. - Collectors' right of entry. 
    Solid waste collectors are authorized to enter upon private property for the purpose of collecting solid waste therefrom as required by this chapter. Solid waste collectors shall not enter dwelling units or other residential buildings for the purpose of collecting residential solid waste. Commercial solid waste may be removed from within commercial establishments upon written request of the owner and approval by the manager. 
(Code 1980, § 12-59) 
Sec. 94-111. - Frequencies. 
    The following collection frequencies shall apply to collections of solid waste within the city: 
(1)  Residential. All residential solid waste, except yard waste, recyclables and bulky trash, shall be collected weekly. Should a city-designated holiday fall on the day of solid waste pickup, the solid waste manager shall give ten days' prior public notice as to the designated collection day. 
(2)  Commercial. All commercial solid waste shall be collected at least once a week and shall be collected at more frequent intervals as may be fixed by the manager or requested by the commercial establishment upon a determination that more frequent intervals are necessary for the preservation of the health and safety of the public. 
(Code 1980, § 12-60) 
Sec. 94-112. - Storage and placement of waste and waste containers. 
(a)  Residential. Residential solid waste, yard waste and recyclable containers shall be stored upon the residential premises. All containers for collection, tree limbs, yard wastes and recyclables shall be placed as near as practicable to the curb or edge of the nearest public or private street or alley abutting the property upon which the residence is located, except for those persons arranging with the manager for on-premises collection as permitted by section 94-108. No container shall be placed adjacent to any alley that is not accessible by a tandem truck driving through from street to street. Containers shall not be placed for collection more than 24 hours before the regular scheduled collection day. 
(b)  Commercial. Commercial solid waste containers shall be stored upon private property, unless the owner shall have written permission from the city to use public property for such purposes. The storage site shall be well-drained; fully accessible to collection equipment, public health personnel and fire inspection personnel. 
(Code 1980, § 12-61) 
Secs. 94-113-94-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SERVICE CHARGES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) ---

Sec. 94-126. - Imposed. 
    There is imposed, as provided in this division, for the collection and disposal of solid waste and the improvement of the general public health and environment, a service charge payable monthly in advance for each dwelling unit and each commercial establishment. 
(Ord. No. 1488-19, § 1, 3-26-19) 
Sec. 94-127. - Disposition of receipts. 
    All funds collected under this division shall be deposited to the account of the solid waste fund. 
(Ord. No. 1488-19, § 1, 3-26-19) 
Sec. 94-128. - Amounts.

The city will place a cart at the resident's house and tip it once a week for $1.00 per month; the charge is independent of the size of the recycling cart. 
(c)  Commercial cart. Charges for once a week curbside commercial solid waste collection shall be $23.00 a month per cart. Includes waste. 
(d)  Dumpsters. Charges for emptying of dumpsters shall be as follows:

(Ord. No. 1488-19, § 1, 3-26-19) 
Sec. 94-129. - Termination upon proof that unit or establishment is unoccupied; resumption. 
    The service and service charge shall be terminated only when the water service has been shut off at the meter by city personnel and the trash cart has been removed from the property by city personnel. 
    Services shall be commenced upon resumption of the aforementioned water service connection by city personnel and placement of the city trash cart by city personnel. 
(Ord. No. 1488-19, § 1, 3-26-19) 
Sec. 94-130. - Billing. 
(a)  The service charge provided for in this division is levied upon the occupant or tenant of each occupied dwelling unit, commercial business unit and industrial unit, unless the occupant is part of a rental complex for which solid waste service is being contracted for or provided by the owner of the complex, or in the absence of information as to the person who is either the owner or the tenant, billing therefor shall be made to the owner. Service charges shall be payable to the department empowered to collect service charges levied by the city. 
(b)  All service charges shall be rendered monthly as an additional billing on the utility bill and payable as such utility bill is paid. 
(Ord. No. 1488-19, § 1, 3-26-19) 
Sec. 94-131. - Persons outside city. 
    The manager shall have the authority to render solid waste collection and disposal service to any party who resides within a distance of one statute mile beyond the city boundaries and to assess service charges in an amount to be determined by the manager with approval of the council. 
(Ord. No. 1488-19, § 1, 3-26-19) 
Sec. 94-132. - Authority to enforce collection. 
    The system of services established by this division is designated as an integral part of the city's program of health and sanitation, to be operated as an adjunct to the city's system for providing potable water and the city's system for providing sewage disposal. The city may enforce collection of the charges imposed by this division by bringing proper legal action against the occupant of any dwelling unit or owner of any commercial establishment to recover any sums due for such service, plus a reasonable attorney's fee to be fixed by the court, plus the cost of such action. 
(Ord. No. 1488-19, § 1, 3-26-19) 
Chapter 98 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; cemeteries, ch. 30; civil emergencies, ch. 34; environment, ch. 46; fire prevention and protection, ch. 50; floods, ch. 54; health and sanitation, ch. 58; historic preservation, ch. 62; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 74; parks and recreation, ch. 82; planning, ch. 86; signs, ch. 92; solid waste, ch. 94; subdivisions, ch. 102; utilities, ch. 114; zoning, app. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 98-1. - Hoisting or suspending merchandise. 
(a)  Any person who shall hoist on the outside of any building and over any street, sidewalk or thoroughfare of the city any merchandise or other article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. However, nothing in this subsection shall be so construed as to include persons engaged in the construction or repair of any building or the employees of such persons. 
(b)  No person shall suspend any merchandise or other article in front of any store or house more than two feet from the wall thereof and at any height less than 61/2 feet above the pavement. 
(Code 1980, § 24-1) 
Sec. 98-2. - Display or sale of merchandise. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person through any officer or employee thereof to place or stand for sale or advertising purposes any goods, wares or merchandise of any kind, directly or indirectly, upon the surface of the improved portion of any street, alley or roadway within the city, within the area commonly known as "parking" which lies between the curb of any street and the edge of the sidewalk lying closest to the curb within the city and upon any public sidewalk within the city. However, one-fourth of the width of the sidewalk or two feet of the width of the sidewalk, whichever is less, lying nearest to the abutting property may be used by the abutting property owner for the display of goods, wares and merchandise. 
(Code 1980, § 24-2) 
Sec. 98-3. - Permission for use during construction. 
    Any person may use the squares, streets, alleys or sidewalks in the construction of any new building or in the removal, repair or alteration of any building or for the purpose of piling thereon building materials and tools. However, such person shall first obtain the written permission of the planning and code enforcement officer or person acting for the planning and code enforcement officer to use such parts of the squares, streets, alleys or sidewalks for such purposes and for such time as he may designate. Such person shall maintain at such places so used at night an artificial light, when necessary, sufficient to warn travelers of the location of such places. The use of any portion of any square, street, alley or sidewalk for such purposes not granted and specified in written permission is prohibited. 
(Code 1980, § 24-3) 
Sec. 98-4. - Taking or depositing turf, loam or gravel. 
    No person shall take from or deposit on any street, alley, thoroughfare, sidewalk or other public place of the city or on property not owned or controlled by him, without having lawful authority, any turf, loam, gravel, rock or other material. 
(Code 1980, § 24-4) 
Sec. 98-5. - Flying kites, throwing snowballs, playing games. 
    Any person who shall, in and upon any street, alley or public place within the city, fly a kite, throw snowballs, play at any game of amusement or engage in any sport or exercise likely to injure the public or obstruct the passage of vehicles shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1980, § 24-5) 
Sec. 98-6. - Begging. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit alms or beg, as the term is ordinarily understood, upon a public street or sidewalk within the city. 
(Code 1980, § 24-6) 
Sec. 98-7. - Hedge fences-Cutting and trimming. 
    Every person owning a hedge fence or property enclosed by such fence along or near a public street of the city shall keep such hedge cut and trimmed to a maximum height of three feet and shall not permit such hedge to overhang sidewalks. Property owners shall also keep ornamental shrubbery, trees or any other obstruction that obscures the sight area of traffic on corners cut or trimmed to a maximum height of three feet and shall not permit the shrubbery or trees to overhang or obstruct sidewalks or obstruct the view of traffic at corners. 
(Code 1980, § 24-7) 
Sec. 98-8. - Same-Notice to cut untrimmed hedge. 
    It shall be the duty of the planning and code enforcement officer, as soon as notified that there is situated in the city upon or near a public street a hedge fence which has not been cut as required by section 98-7, to notify the owner or lessor of the property upon which the untrimmed hedges are located. The planning and code enforcement officer shall notify in writing the owner of the fence or property or the agent or person in possession of such land or property so fenced by the hedge to cut the hedge down to the required height within ten days of receipt of notification. 
(Code 1980, § 24-8) 
Sec. 98-9. - Same-Failure to cut after notice. 
    After ten days from the date of the service of the notice pursuant to section 98-8, if the owner of such fence or property or agent or person in possession of such land or property so fenced by such hedge shall fail or refuse to cut the hedge down to the required height, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. The city may trim such hedge or cause the hedge to be trimmed and charge the costs thereof to the owner; provided, however, that trimming by the city or its designee shall not preclude the imposition of a penalty. 
(Code 1980, § 24-9) 
Sec. 98-10. - Use of coasting devices prohibited in certain areas. 
(a)  Persons upon roller skates or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device shall not be permitted on any sidewalk, street, parking lot or other public place in the central business district. The central business district shall be deemed to be that area set forth in appendix A, section 3(A)C-1. 
(b)  Any person who shall use such coasting device on any street, sidewalk, parking lot or other public way shall do so in a careful and prudent manner and not in a manner as to cause or be likely to cause danger or damage to any person or property. The user of any coasting device or like instrument shall give way to any pedestrian, motor vehicle or any other user of the sidewalk, street, parking lot or other public way and shall not interfere with the proper use of any sidewalk, street, parking lot or any other public way by any other person. 
(c)  Every rider of a coasting device shall ride only on the right side of the street. 
(d)  Coasting devices shall not be used on any street, sidewalk, parking lot or any other public way in the city between one-half hour before sunset and one-half hour after sunrise. 
(e)  Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided by section 1-20. 
(Code 1980, § 24-66) 
Sec. 98-11. - Numbering of houses, buildings and mobile homes. 
    Houses, buildings and mobile homes shall be numbered in accordance with the following: 
(1)  The city engineer shall establish the street number of all houses and buildings in the city. It is made the duty of the owner of each house or building fronting on a public street to keep and maintain the number so established on such a house or building, in numerals at least three inches high in a contrasting color to the mounting surface, at a place where it shall be clearly visible from such street. In addition it is made a duty of the owner of each house or building in the central business district which abuts an alley to keep and maintain the number so established on such house or building in numerals at least three inches high in contrasting color to the mounting surface, at a place where it shall be clearly visible from such alley. 
(2)  The owner or manager of a mobile home park shall establish a map of the layout of the mobile home park, showing the location of individual mobile home spaces by number, and shall keep or maintain the number so established on such individual mobile home space lot or on the mobile home at a place where it shall be clearly visible from the street, drive or roadway on which it fronts. 
(3)  Any person violating this subsection shall be prosecuted as provided by section 1-20. 
(Code 1980, § 31-5(b)) 
Secs. 98-12-98-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR 

Sec. 98-31. - Conformance to specifications; costs. 
(a)  All construction and repair work on streets, alleys, sidewalks, curbs and gutters in the city shall be performed in accordance with specifications on file in the office of the city engineer, as approved and amended by the council from time to time. 
(b)  The cost of construction and repair of streets, alleys, sidewalks, curbs and gutters in the city may be assessed and collected as provided by state law. 
(Code 1980, § 24-21) 
Sec. 98-32. - Alteration of standards. 
    Under unusual circumstances where the adherence to the specifications referred to in section 98-31 may cause a severe hardship on the parties involved, the city council may, by a two-thirds vote, alter the minimum standards to fit the unusual situation. 
(Code 1980, § 24-22) 
Secs. 98-33-98-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 98-56. - Permit required. 
    No person shall make or cause to be made any excavation in; encroachment on; lay, locate, erect, remove, maintain or repair any conduit, pole, pole line, wire, main, pipe, conductor, sewer, tramway or drain within, upon, over or across; or move any building or other structure upon, over or across any street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, highway, sidewalk or public easement without first having filed an application with and obtained a permit therefor from the city clerk. No permit required under this section shall be issued without the approval of the city engineer. 
(Code 1980, § 24-35) 
Sec. 98-57. - Review of and recommendation on permit by city engineer. 
    All applications for permits required under this article shall be referred to the city engineer for his review and recommendation. If he finds that the applicant has complied with all the requirements of this article and all other ordinances, laws and regulations of the city, he shall recommend to the city clerk that the permit be issued. 
(Code 1980, § 24-36) 
Sec. 98-58. - Permit fee. 
    The city clerk shall collect for the granting of each permit required under this article a fee as established by the city council from time to time, which fee shall be paid into the city treasury to the credit of the general revenue fund. 
(Code 1980, § 24-41) 
Sec. 98-59. - Restoration deposit. 
    No person shall receive any permit to excavate in or under any street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, highway, sidewalk or public easement until such person shall have first deposited with the city a minimum deposit of $100.00, which deposit shall remain with the city until such street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, highway, sidewalk or public easement in or under which the excavation has been made shall have been restored to as good condition as it was prior to such excavation being made and until the city is notified by the city engineer that such restoration has been made. 
(Code 1980, § 24-37) 
Sec. 98-60. - Restoration by city. 
    If the person making an excavation under a permit issued under this article shall delay or refuse, after due notice from the city engineer, to restore such street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, highway, sidewalk or public easement in or under which such excavation has been made to as good condition as it was prior to such excavation, it shall be the duty of the city engineer to make such restoration. The expense of the restoration shall be deducted from the deposit referred to in section 98-61, and the balance thereof, if any, after all lawful charges against it have been made, shall be returned to the person making such deposit. 
(Code 1980, § 24-38) 
Sec. 98-61. - Standing deposit. 
    Any person having occasion to make frequent excavations in or under the streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, highways, sidewalks or public easements in the city may, in lieu of the deposit required in section 98-59, keep a standing minimum deposit with the city in the sum of $1,000.00 to cover the restoration of any street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, highway, sidewalk or public easement where such excavation shall not exceed the width of the street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, highway, sidewalk or public easement in which such excavations are made, which deposit shall be subject to all the conditions of sections 98-59 and 98-60, except that such deposit shall at all times be maintained at $1,000.00. 
(Code 1980, § 24-39) 
Sec. 98-62. - Standing bond. 
    Any person having occasion to make frequent excavations may, and any person making excavations exceeding in length the width of the street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, highway, sidewalk or public easement in or under which such excavations are made shall, in lieu of the deposit required by sections 98-59 and 98-60, keep a standing bond, in the sum of $10,000.00 on file with the city clerk, to be approved by the mayor, conditioned to restore such streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, highways, sidewalks and public easements, as required in sections 98-59 through 98-61. 
(Code 1980, § 24-40) 
Sec. 98-63. - Obstruction of traffic. 
    Under this article, no public way shall be obstructed so as to inconvenience traffic, whether vehicular or pedestrian, without special permission of the city engineer. 
(Code 1980, § 24-42) 
Sec. 98-64. - Protection of public. 
    Every applicant for a permit under this article who shall make or cause to be made any excavation in or adjoining any street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, highway, sidewalk or public easement shall cause the excavation to be barricaded. Such barricade shall be so placed as to prevent persons, animals or vehicles from falling into the excavation. Every applicant making or causing to be made any such excavation shall cause two red lights to be securely and conspicuously posted on or near such excavation, provided such excavation does not exceed ten feet in length. If the excavation is more than ten feet and less than 50 feet, three red lights, one at each end and one in the center, shall be so placed and one additional light shall be placed for each additional 25 feet or part thereof. Such lights shall be kept burning during the entire night. 
(Code 1980, § 24-43) 
Sec. 98-65. - Repair of damage to pavement. 
    The applicant for a permit required under this article shall be required to repair all pavements, edges of pavements and shoulders damaged as a result of a diversion of traffic. 
(Code 1980, § 24-44) 
Sec. 98-66. - Maintenance after completion. 
    Every applicant for a permit under this article will be required to maintain the trench and such pavements as are disturbed through the installation of fixtures for a period of six months from the date of completion, during which period such applicant shall make all necessary repairs within ten days after being notified by the city engineer. 
(Code 1980, § 24-45) 
Sec. 98-67. - Unlawful work. 
    No applicant for a permit under this article shall do or cause to be done any work on or any use of public ways in violation of the law or conditions of his permit or shall fail to properly protect all existing fixtures and installation encountered. 
(Code 1980, § 24-46) 
Sec. 98-68. - Written acceptance of article. 
    Whenever the city engineer shall deem it necessary, written acceptance of any or all applicable conditions of this article may be required of applicants contemplating work under or upon any street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, sidewalk, public easement or highway. 
(Code 1980, § 24-47) 
Secs. 98-69-98-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 98-91. - Council authority for construction or repair. 
    The city council may, by ordinance, regulate the building, construction, reconstruction or repair of sidewalks and may adopt plans and specifications for sidewalks and parkways, which parkways shall include all of the space between curbstone and the building or property line or any space in the center of a street which may be set aside as a parkway, and prescribe and require certain materials to be used and the manner and form of doing such work, including the kind of shade trees to be planted and the manner of their care and preservation. 
(Code 1980, § 24-59) 
Sec. 98-92. - Condemnation. 
    The city council may, by ordinance, condemn any sidewalk which it may deem to be in a dangerous or defective condition or out of repair or any sidewalk which is not located upon the established grade and line of sidewalks, on the street on which it is located, as provided by the city, or any sidewalk which does not conform to the specifications and requirements for sidewalks in the city, as provided by the city, and to provide for the removal of any sidewalk so condemned. 
(Code 1980, § 24-60) 
Sec. 98-93. - Maintenance by owner. 
    The city council may, by ordinance, provide that the owner of any lot or tract shall build and construct or rebuild or reconstruct or repair a sidewalk lying along and adjacent to his property and may require the owner to grade, fill or plant with vegetation that portion of the street lying between the property line and the street curbline, may require the owner to build approaches and may provide for the serving of notice to do such work by delivering a written order to the property owner or his representatives or by publication and may provide, by ordinance, that any person who shall, after having been notified, fail, neglect or refuse to comply with such order, shall be guilty of an offense and shall be punished by a fine of not less than $5.00 nor more than $100.00 for each offense. 
(Code 1980, § 24-61) 
Sec. 98-94. - Grade. 
    The grades of all sidewalks constructed or reconstructed shall conform to the established grade of the street along which such sidewalk is made, unless otherwise ordered by ordinance or resolution. 
(Code 1980, § 24-62) 
Sec. 98-95. - Uniformity of surfaces. 
    The top surfaces of all sections of sidewalks made by adjoining lot owners must be joined on the same level or grade, without drops or rises, and any sections or portions of any sidewalk constructed so as to be higher or lower than the adjoining section on either side thereof shall be, by order or resolution of the council, reconstructed and made to conform to the established grade of the adjoining street. 
(Code 1980, § 24-63) 
Sec. 98-96. - Snow clearing and emergency winter event. 
    It shall be the duty of any lot owner or occupant of ground abutting on any sidewalk in the city to remove heavy accumulations of snow from such sidewalks as soon as possible after the falling of the snow. No snow or ice may be pushed onto a public street. 
    In the event of 12 inches or more of snow or any thickness of ice on roadways the mayor is authorized to declare an emergency winter event. Upon declaration of the emergency the city will enforce rules associated with the emergency snow route as set out in the snow policy adopted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1305-11, § 1, 10-25-11) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1305-11, § 1, adopted Oct. 25, 2011, repealed the former § 98-96, and enacted a new § 98-96 as set out herein. The former § 98-96 pertained to snow clearing and derived from the Code of 1980, § 24-64. 
Sec. 98-97. - Gates swinging over sidewalk. 
    No owner or occupant of any lot or piece of ground abutting on any sidewalk shall permit or suffer any gate, when open, to swing over, across or above any sidewalk. 
(Code 1980, § 24-65) 
Sec. 98-98. - Roller skating-Skating in tandem or pairs. 
    It shall be unlawful for persons to skate upon any public sidewalk in the city in tandem or pairs. 
(Code 1980, § 24-67) 
Sec. 98-99. - Same-Passing pedestrians. 
(a)  Any person roller skating upon any sidewalk paralleling a public street in the city shall, when approaching and passing pedestrians upon such sidewalk, pass on that side of the sidewalk nearest the street which the sidewalk parallels. 
(b)  It shall further be the duty of such person so skating, when approaching a pedestrian upon such sidewalk, to slow down sufficiently to avoid colliding with or injuring such pedestrian. 
(Code 1980, § 24-68) 
Sec. 98-100. - Same-Skating at fast or reckless speed. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person skating with roller skates upon any public sidewalk of the city to skate at a fast or reckless rate of speed. 
(Code 1980, § 24-69) 
Sec. 98-101. - Riding animals on sidewalks prohibited. 
    No person shall ride an animal upon any sidewalk. 
Chapter 102 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 46; fire prevention and protection, ch. 50; floods, ch. 54; historic preservation, ch. 62; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 74; parks and recreation, ch. 82; planning, ch. 86; signs, ch. 92; solid waste, ch. 94; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98; traffic and vehicles, ch. 110; utilities, ch. 114; zoning, app. A. 
State Law reference- Planning generally, RSMo 89.300 et seq.; plats, RSMo 445.010 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 102-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley means a minor way, dedicated to public use, when it is used primarily for vehicular service access to the back or side of properties otherwise abutting on a street. 
    Block means a piece or parcel of land surrounded by public highways, streets, streams, railroad rights-of-way or parks, etc., or a combination thereof. 
    Commission means the planning and zoning commission of the city. 
    Cul-de-sac means a street having one end open to traffic and being permanently terminated by a vehicle turnaround. 
    Easement means a grant by the property owner to the public, a corporation or persons of the use of a strip of land for specific purposes. 
    Improvements means street pavements with curbs, sanitary and storm sewers, permanent street monuments, water mains and other appropriate items. 
    Lot means a portion of a subdivision or other parcel of land intended as a unit for transfer of ownership or for development. 
    Plat, final, means a complete and exact subdivision plat, prepared for official recording as required by statute, to define property rights and proposed streets and other improvements. 
    Plat, preliminary, means a complete and exact subdivision plat, prepared for review by the city engineer and city council. 
    Right-of-way means the land opened, reserved or dedicated for a street, walk, drainage or other public purposes. 
    Street means a strip of land, including the entire right-of-way, intended primarily as a means of vehicular and pedestrian travel, which may also be used to provide space for sewers, public utilities, trees and sidewalks. 
    Street, arterial, means a street or road of considerable continuity which serves or is intended to serve as the principal trafficway between separated areas or districts and which is the main means of access to the primary street system or expressways. 
    Street, collector, means a street which, in addition to serving abutting properties, intercepts minor streets, connects with community facilities and carries neighborhood traffic to the major arterial street system. 
    Street, minor, means a street used primarily to provide access to abutting properties only and carries no through traffic. 
    Subdivider means the registered owner or the authorized agent of the owner of a subdivision. 
    Subdivision means a division of a lot, tract or parcel of land into two or more lots for the purpose of transfer of ownership or development, whether immediate or future, including all changes in street or lot lines; provided, however, that where no new streets or easement of access are involved, the following shall not be included within this definition: 
(1)  The combination or recombination of portions of previously platted lots where the total number of lots is not increased and the original lot areas are not decreased. 
(2)  The division of land into parcels of five acres or more. 
(3)  The subdivision or resubdivision of land where public sewers are available and the resultant lots comply with the requirements of the zoning ordinance in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1980, § 25-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 102-2. - Applicability of chapter. 
(a)  Any plat made for each subdivision or each part thereof lying within the city limits shall be prepared, presented for approval and recorded as prescribed in this chapter.
