Secs. 110-284-110-305. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 110-306. - Applicability of article. 
    The sections of this article prohibiting the stopping, standing or parking of a vehicle shall apply at all times or at those times specified in this article or as indicated on official signs, except when it is necessary to stop a vehicle to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device. 
(Code 1980, § 17-229) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.520. 
Sec. 110-307. - Article not exclusive. 
    The sections of this article imposing a time limit on parking shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe other and more restrictive sections prohibiting or limiting the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles in specified places or at specified times. 
(Code 1980, § 17-230) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.525. 
Sec. 110-308. - Parking signs required. 
    Whenever by this chapter or any other ordinance of the city any parking time limit is imposed or parking is prohibited on designated streets, the chief of police shall erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulations shall be effective unless such signs are erected and in place at the time of any alleged offense. 
(Code 1980, § 17-231) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.545. 
Sec. 110-309. - Parking tickets. 
(a)  Generally. Consecutively numbered parking tickets shall be in duplicate in the form prescribed by the chief of police and shall be ordered and issued by the police chief to such police officers and meter readers in such numbers as he shall direct. The police officers or meter readers shall place the original of the ticket, properly filled out, upon every vehicle violating any section of this chapter or other ordinance of the city relating to parking and shall appropriately fill out the duplicate and deliver it to the police department. The police chief shall cause records to be made of tickets issued which shall reflect the number of the ticket, the date of issuance, the state license number of the violator, the amount paid and the issuing officer's name. 
(b)  Courtesy tickets. The mayor is authorized to issue or have issued courtesy tickets to persons attending a convention or gathering within the city when the mayor determines that it will be to the best interest of the city as a whole to issue such courtesy tickets. The courtesy tickets shall specify the name, nature of convention or gathering, the date and hours that it is good for. The mayor shall determine the manner of distributing such courtesy tickets from time to time in the number he deems necessary. No summons or warrant shall be issued for overtime parking of a motor vehicle, but this shall not include zones marked in yellow or fire hydrant zones, to which the courtesy ticket is attached during the time for which the courtesy ticket is valid. 
(Code 1980, § 17-265) 
Sec. 110-310. - Evidence of illegal parking. 
    The establishment of the fact that a motor vehicle was parked in violation of any section of this chapter or other ordinances of the city and the establishment of the fact that the motor vehicle is licensed either by the city or by the state in the name of the defendant shall create the presumption that the defendant was the person who parked the motor vehicle in violation of such section and that the defendant is guilty of such violation. The presumption may be rebutted only by evidence establishing some other named person as the operator of the motor vehicle at the time and place of the alleged violation. 
(Code 1980, § 17-266) 
Sec. 110-311. - Liability for towing and storage charges. 
    The violator of any parking regulation of the city shall be responsible for the towing and storage fee when the illegally parked vehicle is towed in, pursuant to RSMo 300.595. 
(Code 1980, § 17-267) 
Sec. 110-312. - Penalties for violation. 
(a)  Violators of subsection 110-318(a)(2)b, pertaining to prohibited parking within 15 feet of a fire hydrant, shall appear before the traffic violations bureau and upon establishment of guilt shall be fined no less than $40.00 plus costs of no more than $100.00 or by imprisonment for no more than 90 days or by both such fines and imprisonment. 
(b)  The fine upon admission of guilt for double parking or parking in a no parking zone, but not including parking in a no parking zone adjacent to a fire hydrant, shall be $20.00. 
(c)  The fine for overtime parking shall be $20.00 if paid within 72 hours. For payments sent through the U.S. mail, the date of the official postmark shall be deemed the date paid. 
(d)  If after 72 hours the fine provided for by subsection (c) of this section has not been paid to the traffic violations bureau, the fine for overtime parking shall be $40.00. If after five days the fine provided by subsection (b) of this section has not been paid to the traffic violations bureau, the fine for double parking and parking in a no parking zone shall be $40.00. The traffic violations bureau clerk shall send a written notice to the violator at his last known address by ordinary mail, which notice shall specify the nature of the offense and give the violator five days in which to pay the increased fine. If the violator does not pay such increased fine or otherwise appear in answer to the charge within the time allowed, a warrant shall be issued for his arrest and upon conviction he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and liable as such as if the options granted by subsection (b) or (c) of this section had not been given. The form of the written notice required in this subsection shall contain at least the following information: 
(1)  The nature of the offense; 
(2)  The date of the offense; 
(3)  The fact that the violator has five days in which to either plead guilty and pay the prescribed penalty or plead guilty and appear before the judge; 
(4)  The amount of the fine if paid within the time prescribed; and 
(5)  The fact that, if the violator does not appear and pay the fine within the time allowed, a warrant may be issued for his arrest and he will be subject to prosecution as in any other case. 
(Code 1980, § 17-268; Ord. No. 1322-12, § 1, 6-26-12) 
State Law reference- Warning of arrest sent upon failure to answer ticket, RSMo 300.590. 
Sec. 110-313. - Prohibited parking zones. 
    When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle at any time upon any of the streets described by this chapter or other ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 17-232) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.530. 
Sec. 110-314. - Parking prohibited during certain hours on certain streets. 
    When signs are erected in each block giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle between the hours specified by ordinance of any day, except Sundays and public holidays, within the district or upon any of the streets described by ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 17-233) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.535. 
Sec. 110-315. - Restricted stopping, standing and parking zones. 
    When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle between the hours specified by ordinance of any day, except Sundays and public holidays, within the district or upon any of the streets described by this chapter or other city ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 17-234) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.540. 
Sec. 110-316. - Manner of parking. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article or when necessary in obedience to traffic regulations or traffic signs or signals, the operator of a vehicle shall not stop, stand or park such vehicle on a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway, headed in the direction of traffic and with the right-side wheels placed parallel to the right curb of the roadway and within 18 inches of the edge of the roadway. 
(Code 1980, § 17-235) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.415. 
Sec. 110-317. - Parking to obstruct traffic. 
    No person shall park any vehicle upon a street, other than an alley, in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1980, § 17-236) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.445. 
Sec. 110-318. - Prohibited stopping, standing and parking areas enumerated. 
(a)  Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device, no person shall: 
(1)  Stop, stand or park a vehicle: 
a.  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street. 
b.  On a sidewalk. 
c.  Within an intersection. 
d.  On a crosswalk. 
e.  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 30 feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless the traffic authority indicates a different length by signs or markings. 
f.  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic. 
g.  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or within a highway tunnel. 
h.  On any railroad tracks. 
i.  At any place where official signs prohibit stopping. 
(2)  Stand or park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except momentarily to pick up or discharge a passenger: 
a.  In front of a public or private driveway. 
b.  Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant. 
c.  Within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection. 
d.  Within 30 feet upon the approach to any flashing signal, stop sign or traffic control signal located at the side of a roadway. 
e.  Within 20 feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within 75 feet of the entrance, when properly signposted. 
f.  At any place where official signs prohibit standing. 
(3)  Park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or passengers: 
a.  Within 50 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing. 
b.  At any place where official signs prohibit parking. 
(b)  No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any such prohibited area or away from a curb such a distance as is unlawful. 
(Code 1980, § 17-237) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.440. 
Sec. 110-319. - Parking adjacent to schools. 
(a)  The chief of police is authorized to erect signs indicating no parking upon either or both sides of any street adjacent to any school property when such parking would, in his opinion, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous situation. 
(b)  When official signs are erected indicating no parking upon either side of a street adjacent to any school property, as authorized in this section, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Code 1980, § 17-238) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.460. 
Sec. 110-320. - Manner of parking within alleys. 
    No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such a position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(Code 1980, § 17-239) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.450. 
Sec. 110-321. - Standing, parking along divided highways. 
    If a highway includes two or more separate roadways and traffic is restricted to one direction upon any such roadway, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon the lefthand side of such one-way roadway, unless signs are erected to permit such standing or parking. The chief of police is authorized to determine when standing or parking may be permitted upon the lefthand side of any such one-way roadway and to erect signs giving notice thereof. 
(Code 1980, § 17-240) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.475. 
Sec. 110-322. - Standing or parking on one-way streets. 
    The chief of police is authorized to erect signs upon the lefthand side of any one-way street to prohibit the standing or parking of vehicles, and when such signs are in place no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon such lefthand side in violation of any such sign. 
(Code 1980, § 17-241) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.470. 
Sec. 110-323. - Parking on narrow streets. 
(a)  The chief of police is authorized to erect signs indicating no parking upon any street when the width of the roadway does not exceed 20 feet or upon one side of a street as indicated by such signs when the width of the roadway does not exceed 30 feet. 
(b)  When official signs prohibiting parking are erected upon narrow streets as authorized in this section, no person shall park a vehicle upon any such street in violation of any such sign. 
(Code 1980, § 17-242) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.465. 
Sec. 110-324. - Stopping, standing or parking near hazardous or congested places. 
(a)  The chief of police is authorized to determine and designate by proper signs places not exceeding 100 feet in length in which the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic. 
(b)  When official signs are erected at hazardous or congested places as authorized in this section, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Code 1980, § 17-243) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.480. 
Sec. 110-325. - Parking for commercial purposes. 
(a)  No person shall park or stand any vehicle upon any highway or street for the purpose of demonstrating, exhibiting or advertising any such vehicle or similar vehicle for sale or for the purpose of demonstrating, exhibiting or advertising any article for sale, and no vehicle shall be parked on the streets for the purpose of selling merchandise or farm produce therefrom. 
(b)  The chief of police may issue a permit designating the place and duration of standing or parking for advertising purposes. 
(Code 1980, § 17-244) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.455. 
Sec. 110-326. - Designation, marking of angle parking streets. 
    The chief of police shall determine upon what streets angle parking shall be permitted and shall mark or sign such streets. 
(Code 1980, § 17-245) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.420(1). 
Sec. 110-327. - Unsuitable places for angle parking. 
    Angle parking shall not be indicated or permitted at any place where passing traffic would be caused or required to drive upon the left side of the street. 
(Code 1980, § 17-246) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.420(2). 
Sec. 110-328. - Obedience to angle parking signs. 
    On those streets which have been signed or marked by the chief of police for angle parking, no person shall park or stand a vehicle other than at the angle to the curb or edge of the roadway indicated by such signs or markings. 
(Code 1980, § 17-247) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.425. 
Sec. 110-329. - Permits for loading or unloading vehicles with rear to curb. 
(a)  The chief of police is authorized to issue special permits to permit the backing of a vehicle to the curb for the purpose of loading or unloading merchandise or materials subject to the terms and conditions of such permit. Such permits may be issued either to the owner or lessee of real property or to the owner of the vehicle and shall grant to such person the privilege as therein stated and authorized in this section. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any permittee under this section or other person to violate any of the special terms or conditions of any permit issued pursuant to this section. 
(Code 1980, § 17-248) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.430. 
Sec. 110-330. - Designation of curb loading zones. 
    The chief of police is authorized to determine the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones and shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating the zones and stating the hours during which this section is applicable. 
(Code 1980, § 17-249) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.485. 
Sec. 110-331. - Permits for curb loading zones. 
    The chief of police shall not designate or sign any curb loading zone upon special request of any person, unless such person makes application for a permit for such zone and for two signs to indicate the ends of each such zone. The chief of police, upon granting a permit and issuing such signs, shall collect from the applicant and deposit in the city treasury a service fee per year or fraction thereof, as established by the city council from time to time and may by general regulations impose conditions upon the use of such signs and for reimbursement of the city for the value thereof if loss or damage occurs and for their return if misuse occurs or the permit expires. Every such permit shall expire at the end of one year. 
(Code 1980, § 17-250) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.490. 
Sec. 110-332. - Use of curb loading zones. 
(a)  Passenger. No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time, other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers and then only for a period not to exceed three minutes, in any place marked as a passenger curb loading zone during hours when the regulations applicable to such curb loading zone are effective. 
(b)  Freight. No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time, other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials and then only for a period not to exceed 15 minutes, in any place marked as a freight curb loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. 
(Code 1980, § 17-251) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.495, 300.500. 
Sec. 110-333. - Establishment, designation of bus stops or stands, taxicab stands or passenger carrier stands. 
    The chief of police is authorized and required to establish bus stops, bus stands, taxicab stands and stands for other passenger common carrier motor vehicles on such public streets in such places and in such number as he shall determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public, and every such bus stop, bus stand, taxicab stand or other stand shall be designated by appropriate signs. 
(Code 1980, § 17-252) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.505. 
Sec. 110-334. - Stopping, standing and parking of buses. 
(a)  The operator of a bus shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any street at any place other than a bus stand so designated as provided in this article. 
(b)  The operator of a bus shall not stop such vehicle upon any street at any place for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers or their baggage other than at a bus stop, bus stand or passenger loading zone so designated as provided in this article, except in an emergency. 
(c)  The operator of a bus shall enter a bus stop, bus stand or passenger loading zone on a public street in such a manner that the bus, when stopped to load or unload passengers or baggage, shall be in a position with the right front wheel of such vehicle not further than 18 inches from the curb and the bus approximately parallel to the curb so as not to unduly impede the movement of other vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1980, § 17-253) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.510(1)-(3). 
Sec. 110-335. - Stopping, standing and parking of taxicabs. 
    The operator of a taxicab shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any street at any place other than in a taxicab stand so designated as provided in this article. This section shall not prevent the operator of a taxicab from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers. 
(Code 1980, § 17-254) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.510(4). 
Sec. 110-336. - Use of bus stops and taxicab stands. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand when any such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Code 1980, § 17-255) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.515. 
Sec. 110-337. - Lamps on parked vehicles. 
(a)  Whenever a vehicle is lawfully parked upon a street or highway during the hours between one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise and if there is sufficient light to reveal any person or object within a distance of 500 feet upon such street or highway, no lights need be displayed upon such parked vehicle. 
(b)  Whenever a vehicle is parked or stopped upon a roadway or shoulder adjacent thereto, whether attended or unattended, during the hours between one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise and there is not sufficient light to reveal any person or object within a distance of 500 feet upon such highway, such vehicle so parked or stopped shall be equipped with one or more lamps meeting the following requirements: 
(1)  At least one lamp shall display a white or amber light visible from a distance of 500 feet to the front of the vehicle; 
(2)  The same lamp or at least one other lamp shall display a red light visible from a distance of 500 feet to the rear of the vehicle; and 
(3)  The location of such lamps shall always be such that at least one lamp or combination of lamps meeting the requirements of this section is installed as near as practicable to the side of the vehicle which is closer to passing traffic. 
This subsection shall not apply to a motor-driven cycle. 
(c)  Any lighted headlamps upon a parked vehicle shall be depressed or dimmed. 
(Code 1980, § 17-256) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.435. 
Sec. 110-338. - Working on motor vehicles on streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to work upon any motor vehicle or to repair the vehicle while on the street in the city, unless such work or repairing shall be necessary in order to remove such vehicle from the street. 
(Code 1980, § 17-257) 
Sec. 110-339. - Parking in spaces marked with yellow lines or posted with appropriate signs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park or stop or cause to be parked or stopped a motor vehicle or any other kind of vehicle within places marked with yellow lines or posted with appropriate signs at any time, unless otherwise indicated. 
(Ord. No. 1323-12, § 1, 6-26-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1323-12, § 1, adopted June 26, 2012, deleted § 110-339 which pertained to parking in lot F, Nichols Street Plaza Lot and derived from the Code of 1980, § 17-258. In addition, Ord. No. 1323-12 renumbered §§ 110-340-110-347 as §§ 110-339-110-346.

Sec. 110-341. - One hour parking zones. 
(a)  Parking shall be limited to a maximum of one hour on the following streets or indicated portions thereof during the hours from 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., except Sundays: 
State Street, on the west side from East Eighth Street to East Seventh Street. 
East Eighth Street, both sides, between Vine Street and State Street. 
(b)  Parking shall be limited to a maximum of one hour on the following streets or indicated portions thereof during the time between 9:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., except Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays: 
State Street, on the west side, between East Eighth Street and East Ninth Street. 
(Code 1980, § 17-261; Ord. No. 1323-12, § 1, 6-26-12) 
Note- See editor's note at § 110-339. 
Sec. 110-342. - School bus parking zone near intersection of Tenth Street and Grand Street. 
    No vehicles except public school buses shall be parked at the junction of Tenth Street and Grand Street as follows: On the north side of East Tenth Street from Grand Street east to Vine Street, 2:00 p.m. to 3:00 p.m. This section shall be effective on days when school is in session. Reference section 110-341, Parking on certain streets prohibited or limited. 
(Code 1980, § 17-262; Ord. No. 726-96, § 1, 9-24-96; Ord. No. 1323-12, § 1, 6-26-12) 
Note- See editor's note at § 110-339. 
Sec. 110-343. - Parking on municipal lot near city hall. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to park dual-wheeled or heavy duty trucks on the municipally owned parking lot which is located between Court Street and Market Street and south of city hall. Private passenger vehicles, pickups and vans may park on the municipal lot. 
(b)  Other vehicles may be parked on such lot at the direction of the police department when emergencies require such parking. 
(Code 1980, § 17-263; Ord. No. 1323-12, § 1, 6-26-12) 
Note- See editor's note at § 110-339. 
Sec. 110-344. - Angle parking streets. 
    All motor vehicles shall be parked parallel with the curb of the street, except on the following streets or portions thereof all vehicles must be parked at an angle of 45 degrees with the curb: 
Court Street, from Fourth Street to Fifth Street. 
East Fifth Street, on the south side, from Market Street to Court Street. 
(Code 1980, § 17-264; Ord. No. 1323-12, § 1, 6-26-12) 
Note- See editor's note at § 110-339. 
Sec. 110-345. - Parking in city parks. 
    Parking shall be prohibited in all parks of the city, except in areas designated as parking areas by signs on shoulders parallel to the roadways in the parks where such shoulders are provided. Parking on the grass or in recreational areas is strictly prohibited. 
(Code 1980, § 17-269; Ord. No. 1323-12, § 1, 6-26-12) 
Note- See editor's note at § 110-339. 
Sec. 110-346. - Parking of commercial vehicles and school buses in residential districts. 
    No operator of a commercial motor vehicle licensed for a gross weight in excess of 24,000 pounds or of any school, church or other bus, regardless of size, shall park such vehicle on any street or public right-of-way in a residential area of this city, zoned for single-family or multi-family residential use. 
(Ord. No. 684-95, § 1, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 1323-12, § 1, 6-26-12) 
Note- See editor's note at § 110-339. 
Secs. 110-347-110-355. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PARKING METERS 

Sec. 110-356. - Installation, maintenance and enforcement. 
    The police department shall install, maintain and enforce parking meters on certain streets and parking lots of the city, as designated by the city council by ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 17-280) 
Sec. 110-357. - Time of operation. 
    Parking zones and parking meters shall be enforced by the police department between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, and 8:00 a.m. until 12:00 noon on Saturday, except holidays. 
(Code 1980, § 17-281) 
Sec. 110-358. - Zones; fees. 
(a)  Parking in the following designated areas shall be for a period of time not to exceed three hours. Parking for successive periods of time within the same parking zone is prohibited. For the purpose of this subsection, a zone shall constitute both sides of the street of a city block: 
Court Street, east side, from Third Street to Fourth Street, except for driveways. 
Court Street, west side, 114 feet south of the south curb of Fourth Street, thence south 216 feet, except for driveways. 
Court Street, from Fourth Street to West Seventh Street. 
Jefferson Street, between West Fifth Street north to West Sixth Street, six spaces on the west side. 
Nichols Street, from West Fifth Street to West Sixth Street. 
Nichols Street, east side, from West Sixth Street to West Seventh Street. 
Ravine Street, west side, from East Fourth Street to East Fifth Street. 
Ravine Street, from East Fifth Street to East Sixth Street. 
St. Louis Avenue, south side, from Court Street to Market Street. 
East Fourth Street, from Market Street to Court Street. 
West Fourth Street, north side, from Court Street to Nichols Street. 
East Fifth Street, north side, from Market Street to 200 feet east of Ravine Street. 
East Fifth Street, from Ravine Street east 200 feet on the south side. 
East Fifth Street, from Market Street to Court Street. 
East Fifth Street, north side, between Ravine Street and Market Street. 
West Fifth Street, from Court Street to Jefferson Street. 
East Sixth Street, from Ravine Street to Market Street. 
East Sixth Street, from Market Street to Court Street. 
West Sixth Street, from Court Street to Nichols Street. 
West Sixth Street, north side, between Nichols Street and Jefferson Street. 
East Seventh Street, from Market Street to Court Street. 
(b)  A vehicle shall be unlawfully parked if it remains in the zone beyond the legal parking limit. Violators shall be subject to a fine as provided in section 110-312(c) and (e). 
(Code 1980, § 17-282; Ord. No. 789-98, § 1, 7-14-98; Ord. No. 1321-12, § 1, 6-26-12) 
Sec. 110-359. - Off street parking lots. 
(a)  The fees for parking in city parking lots shall be as follows: 
(1)  Lot A, city hall lot. Parking spaces in this lot shall be primarily for city employees, city vehicles and visitors to city hall. 
(2)  Lot B, Market Street lot. 
a.  Spaces 47-69 three hour free parking. This area shall be enforced as a parking zone prohibiting parking for successive periods of time. 
b.  Spaces 1-46 lease spaces at $20.00 per month, enforced from 7:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Monday through Friday with year ahead applied financing. 
(3)  Lot C, sky-go lot. Lease spaces at $20.00 per month. 
(4)  Lot D, Northeast Market Street lot. Free parking with no time limit. 
(5)  Lot E, South Nichols Street lot. Lease spaces at $20.00 per month. 
(6)  Lot F, Nichols Street Plaza lot. 
a.  Spaces 18-29 one-hour parking, $0.25 with a five-hour maximum. 
b.  Spaces 1-17 lease spaces at $20.00 per month, enforced from 7:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Monday through Friday with year ahead applied financing. 
(7)  Lot G-l and G-2, Jefferson Street lots. Lease spaces at $20.00 per month. 
(b)  In all lots designated for leased spaces, where such spaces are not leased or used by the city for official business, parking meters shall be installed which shall be metered at $0.25 per hour with a maximum of five-hour parking. 
(Code 1980, § 17-283; Ord. No. 630-92, § 1, 11-24-92; Ord. No. 637-93, § 1, 4-13-93; Ord. No. 652-93, § 3, 9-21-93; Ord. No. 789-98, § 2, 7-14-98; Ord. No. 838-00, § 1, 1-11-00; Ord. No. 1110-05, § 1, 10-11-05; Ord. No. 1131-06, § 1, 2-28-06; Ord. No. 1324-12, § 1, 6-26-12; Ord. No. 1349-13, § 1, 7-9-13) 
Sec. 110-360. - Deposit of coin when vehicle is parked. 
    The driver of every vehicle which shall be parked, during the time limit parking regulations are in effect, in a parking space alongside of, next to or in front of which a parking meter is installed shall immediately upon parking such vehicle deposit a coin in the meter according to the length of time desired to be parked in such space and shall set the signal on the meter indicating the time limit for parking in such space. 
(Code 1980, § 17-284) 
Sec. 110-361. - Overtime and unlawful parking. 
(a)  No person shall allow a vehicle under his control to remain parked in any parking space for which a parking meter is installed and maintained when such parking meter indicates by proper signal that the time limit for such a space has expired. 
(b)  No vehicle shall be parked in a parking space for which a parking meter is installed and maintained for a longer period of time than the time limit indicated by a signal on such meter upon the insertion of a coin therein. 
(c)  No vehicle shall be parked in designated areas as described in section 110-359(a), (b) or (c) for a period of time longer than allowed by such section. 
(Code 1980, § 17-285) 
Sec. 110-362. - Use of slugs. 
    No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter any slug, device or substitute for a coin of the United States. 
(Code 1980, § 17-286) 
Sec. 110-363. - Injuring or tampering with meters. 
    No person shall willfully mar, deface, injure, tamper with, destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter installed and maintained. 
(Code 1980, § 17-287) 
Sec. 110-364. - Use of funds. 
    The fee required to be deposited in parking meters as provided in this division is levied to cover the cost of inspection, installation, operation, control and use of the parking spaces and parking meters described in this division and to cover the cost of checking and regulating the parking of vehicles in parking spaces and for the purchase of materials, supplies and equipment to control traffic and for use in the alleviation of traffic conditions. 
(Code 1980, § 17-288) 
Secs. 110-365-110-375. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PARKING FOR HANDICAPPED PERSONS 

Sec. 110-376. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Parking space designated for use only by the physically disabled means any parking space that meets the requirements of the Federal Americans with Disabilities Act, as amended, and any rules or regulations established pursuant thereto including RSMo 301.143. 
    Physically disabled shall have the same meaning as RSMo 301.142. 
(Code 1980, § 17-290; Ord. No. 765-98, § 1, 2-10-98) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 110-377. - Reserved parking areas established. 
(a)  Authority of city engineer or owner of private property. The city engineer or any owner of private property who provides public parking spaces is authorized to designate and establish parking spaces for the exclusive use of vehicles which display a distinguishing license plate or card issued to physically disabled persons and shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating such spaces. 
(1)  Whenever the city engineer or owner of private property so designates a parking space, the space shall be indicated by a sign upon which shall be inscribed the international symbol of accessibility and shall also include any other appropriate wording or markings as required by the Americans with Disabilities Act, as amended, and any rules or regulations established pursuant thereto. 
(2)  Nonconforming signs or spaces otherwise required pursuant to this section which are in use prior to August 28, 1997, shall not be in violation of this section during the useful life of such signs or spaces. Under no circumstances shall the useful life of the nonconforming signs or spaces be extended by means other than those means used to maintain any sign or space on the owner's property which is not used for vehicles displaying a disabled license plate. 
(b)  Authorized vehicles. Vehicles authorized to be parked in disabled parking spaces shall have one of the following: 
(1)  A disabled license plate or card issued by this state or another state. 
(2)  Any motor vehicle designed and operated solely for the purpose of transporting physically disabled persons. 
(c)  Unauthorized vehicles parking in disabled parking spaces. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or stand a vehicle or to own a vehicle which is parked in any disabled parking space on private or public property, unless such person is a physically disabled person or is transporting a physically disabled person and such vehicle is one authorized to be parked in a disabled parking space by displaying the appropriate license plate or card. 
(d)  Police officers authority. Police officers may enter upon private property open to public use to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(e)  Penalty for violation. Any person who violates this section shall be deemed guilty of an infraction and shall, upon conviction, be fined $100.00 for the first offense, $200.00 for the second offense and $300.00 for the third and each subsequent offense. 
(Code 1980, § 17-289; Ord. No. 765-98, § 1, 2-10-98) 
Sec. 110-378. - State law adopted. 
    RSMo 301.142 and 301.143 are made a part of this division by reference. 
(Code 1980, § 17-291; Ord. No. 765-98, § 1, 2-10-98) 
Secs. 110-379-110-400. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - BICYCLES 

Sec. 110-401. - Obedience to traffic regulations. 
    Bicycles shall stop at all stop signs and obey all traffic regulations. 
(Code 1980, § 17-47) 
Sec. 110-402. - Number of passengers. 
    Bicycles shall not carry more than one person, except a bicycle which is constructed for more than one. 
(Code 1980, § 17-48) 
Sec. 110-403. - Riding on right side of street. 
    Every operator of a bicycle shall ride only on the right side of the street. 
(Code 1980, § 17-49) 
Sec. 110-404. - Lights. 
    No operator of a bicycle shall ride at night without a light on the front and a reflector or light on the rear of the bicycle. 
(Code 1980, § 17-50) 
Sec. 110-405. - Riding abreast. 
    No operator of a bicycle shall ride abreast of another bicycle. 
(Code 1980, § 17-51) 
Sec. 110-406. - Riding out of an alley or driveway or from behind parked car. 
    No operator of a bicycle shall ride out of an alley or driveway or from behind parked cars without first stopping and looking to see that the sidewalk and streets are clear of traffic. 
(Code 1980, § 17-52) 
Sec. 110-407. - Trick riding; reckless riding. 
(a)  No operator of a bicycle shall engage in any trick riding or weaving or without having at least one hand on the handle bars of the bicycle. 
(b)  No operator of a bicycle shall at any time ride a bicycle in a reckless manner. 
(Code 1980, § 17-53) 
Sec. 110-408. - Riding on sidewalk. 
(a)  No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within a business district. 
(b)  Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk, such person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give audible signal before overtaking and passing such pedestrian. 
(Code 1980, § 17-54) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.347. 
Secs. 110-409-110-430. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PEDESTRIANS 

Sec. 110-431. - Obedience to traffic control devices. 
    Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic control signals as prescribed in sections 110-126 and 110-127, but at all other places pedestrians shall be granted those rights and shall be subject to the restrictions stated in this article. 
(Code 1980, § 17-206) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.370. 
Sec. 110-432. - Right-of-way at crosswalks. 
(a)  When traffic control signals are not in place or not in operation, the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping if need be to so yield, to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within a crosswalk when the pedestrian is upon the half of the roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling or when the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite half of the roadway as to be in danger. 
(b)  Subsection (a) of this section shall not apply under the conditions stated in subsection 110-436(b). 
(Code 1980, § 17-207) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.375(1), (3). 
Sec. 110-433. - Leaving curb suddenly or entering path of vehicle. 
    No pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a vehicle which is so close that it is impossible for the driver to yield the right-of-way. 
(Code 1980, § 17-208) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.375(2). 
Sec. 110-434. - Use of right half of crosswalks. 
    Pedestrians shall move, whenever practicable, upon the right half of crosswalks. 
(Code 1980, § 17-209) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.380. 
Sec. 110-435. - Crossing at right angles. 
    No pedestrian shall cross a roadway at any place other than by a route at right angles to the curb or by the shortest route to the opposite curb, except in a crosswalk. 
(Code 1980, § 17-210) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.385. 
Sec. 110-436. - Yielding right-of-way. 
(a)  Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(b)  Any pedestrian crossing a roadway at a point where a pedestrian tunnel or overhead pedestrian crossing has been provided shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(c)  This section shall have no application under the conditions stated in section 10-437 when pedestrians are prohibited from crossing at certain designated places. 
(Code 1980, § 17-211) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.390. 
Sec. 110-437. - Prohibited crossing places. 
(a)  Between adjacent intersections at which traffic control signals are in operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a crosswalk. 
(b)  No pedestrian shall cross a roadway other than in a crosswalk in any business district. 
(c)  No pedestrian shall cross a roadway other than in a crosswalk upon any street designated by this chapter. 
(d)  No pedestrian shall cross a roadway intersection diagonally, unless authorized by official traffic control devices. When authorized to cross diagonally, pedestrians shall cross only in accordance with the official traffic control devices pertaining to such crossing movements. 
(Code 1980, § 17-212) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.395. 
Sec. 110-438. - Manner of walking along roadway. 
(a)  Where sidewalks are provided, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to walk along and upon any adjacent roadway. 
(b)  Where sidewalks are not provided, any pedestrian walking along and upon a highway shall, when practicable, walk only on the left side of the roadway or its shoulder facing traffic which may approach from the opposite direction. 
(Code 1980, § 17-213) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.405. 
Sec. 110-439. - Obedience to bridge signals. 
    No pedestrian shall enter or remain upon any bridge or approach thereto beyond the bridge signal, gate or barrier after a bridge operation signal indication has been given. 
(Code 1980, § 17-214) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.400(1). 
Sec. 110-440. - Duty of drivers. 
    Notwithstanding the sections of this article, every driver of a vehicle shall exercise the highest degree of care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any roadway and shall give warning by sounding the horn when necessary and shall exercise proper precaution upon observing any child or any confused or incapacitated person upon a roadway. 
(Code 1980, § 17-215) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.410. 
Sec. 110-441. - Persons carrying white canes. 
    For the purpose of guarding against accidents, it is declared unlawful for any person not wholly or partially blind to carry or use upon the streets, highways or public places of this city any cane or walking stick which is white in color or white tipped in red. The term "white in color" as used in this section means painted or enameled, and not an unpainted or natural wood color. Such white canes or walking sticks may be used on the streets or in other public places of the city by persons wholly or partially blind as a means of identifying them to drivers or operators of vehicles and for the purpose of protecting them from injury by such vehicles. 
(Code 1980, § 17-216) 
Sec. 110-442. - Duty of driver approaching handicapped with white cane or guide dog. 
    The driver of a vehicle approaching a blind or visually handicapped, deaf or partially deaf person or physically disabled person who is carrying a cane predominantly white or metallic in color, with or without a red tip, or using a guide dog, hearing dog or service dog shall yield to such person, and any driver who fails to take such precautions shall be liable in damages for any injury caused such pedestrian. A blind or visually handicapped, deaf or partially deaf person or physically disabled person not carrying such a cane or using a guide dog, hearing dog or service dog in any of the places, accommodations or conveyances listed in RSMo 209.150, shall have all of the rights and privileges conferred by law upon other persons. 
(Code 1980, § 17-217) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 304.080. 
Secs. 110-443-110-465. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - ACCIDENTS 

Sec. 110-466. - Notice to police. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to or death of any person or total property damage to an apparent extent of $500.00 or more to one person shall immediately by the quickest means of communication give notice of such accident to the police if such accident occurred within the city. 
(b)  Whenever the driver of a vehicle is physically incapable of giving immediate notice of an accident in accordance with subsection (a) of this section and there was another occupant in the vehicle at the time of the accident capable of doing so, such occupant shall give or cause to be given the notice not given by the driver. 
(Code 1980, § 17-322) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.110, 300.120(1). 
Sec. 110-467. - Report to police. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle which is in any manner involved in an accident resulting in bodily injury to or death of any person or total damage to all property to an apparent extent of $500.00 or more shall, within five days after such accident, forward a written report of such accident to the police. However, this subsection shall not be applicable when the accident has been investigated at the scene by a police officer while such driver was present thereat. 
(b)  Whenever the driver is physically incapable of making a written report of an accident as required in subsection (a) of this section and such driver is not the owner of the vehicle, the owner of the vehicle involved in such accident shall, within five days after the accident, make such report not made by the driver. 
(Code 1980, § 17-323) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.115, 300.120(2). 
Sec. 110-468. - Confidential nature of reports. 
(a)  All written reports made by persons involved in accidents or by garages shall be without prejudice to the person so reporting and shall be for the confidential use of the police or other governmental agencies having use for the records for accident prevention purposes, except that the police or other governmental agencies may disclose the identity of a person involved in an accident when such identity is not otherwise known or when such person denies his presence at such accident. 
(b)  No written reports forwarded under this section shall be used as evidence in any trial, civil or criminal, arising out of an accident, except that the police shall furnish upon demand of any party to such trial or upon demand of any court a certificate showing that a specified accident report has or has not been made to the police in compliance with law and, if such report has been made, the date, time and location of the accident and the names and addresses of the drivers, the owners of the vehicles involved, and the investigating officers. 
(Code 1980, § 17-324) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.125. 
Sec. 110-469. - Investigations. 
    All police officers shall investigate traffic accidents, arrest and assist in the prosecution of those persons charged with violations of law causing or contributing to such accidents. 
(Code 1980, § 17-325) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.030. 
Chapter 114 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; businesses, ch. 22; civil emergencies, ch. 34; environment, ch. 46; floods, ch. 54; historic preservation, ch. 62; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 74; parks and recreation, ch. 82; planning, ch. 86; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98; subdivisions, ch. 102. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 114-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Billing period means a utility service usage period. 
    Board means the board of public utilities as established by the Charter. 
    Commercial service means service for business use. 
    Customer or consumer means a purchaser of utility service. 
    Delinquent account means a utility bill unpaid after its due date. 
    Discontinuance of service means an intentional cessation of utility service by the city and not requested by a customer. 
    Economic hardship means an inability to make timely payment for utility service due to fiscal restraints. The level of economic hardship shall be determined by using the most current state guidelines for the utility assistance program. 
    Estimated billing means a billing for utility service which is not based on an actual meter reading. 
    Fuel adjustment clause means the adjustment procedure approved by the city council to recognize variations in the cost of fuel for the generation of electric power. 
    Good faith attempt to pay means the requirement whereby a customer makes some payment each month as agreed to by the city. 
    Industrial service means service for manufacturing purposes. 
    Mains means city-owned piping for the purpose of distributing gas or water to a customer or for the collection of sewage. 
    Rate means the amount charged for usage of a specified unit of electricity, gas, water or sewer service. 
    Registered elderly or handicapped customer means a person who is above the age of 62 or is handicapped and has registered with the city by submitting a statement attesting to the condition. 
    Residential service means service for household purposes. 
    Service means the same as utility service. 
    Service line means piping connecting a customer to a city main. 
    Sewer means piping designed for the collection and transportation of sewage. 
    Suspension of service means a temporary cessation of utility service initiated by the utility department. 
    Termination of service means a cessation of utility service requested by the customer. 
    Utility charges means the charges for utility service. 
    Utility service means the provision of electricity, gas, water or sewer and activities related to that provision. 
(Code 1980, § 28-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 114-2-114-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 114-26-114-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - UTILITY DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Board of public utilities, § 114-51 et seq. 

Sec. 114-36. - Established. 
    There is established, in accordance with article VI, section 6.1(c) of the city Charter, a utility department, the purpose of which is to operate and maintain all public utilities of the city. The department shall be organized and maintained as provided for by the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 28-2) 
Sec. 114-37. - Composition. 
    The utility department shall consist of four divisions: the gas division, the electric division, the water division and the sewer division. 
(Code 1980, § 28-3) 
Sec. 114-38. - Appointment of superintendent. 
    The director of administration, with the consent of the mayor, shall appoint a superintendent for the utility department. 
(Code 1980, § 28-4) 
Sec. 114-39. - Responsibilities of superintendent. 
    The superintendent of the utility department shall have supervisory responsibility for all activities and personnel of the utility department. Further, the superintendent shall have the responsibility to enforce all ordinances, rules and regulations applicable to the utility department. The superintendent may promulgate administrative rules and regulations consistent with the letter and intent of this chapter. 
(Code 1980, § 28-5; Ord. No. 622-92, § 1, 8-25-92) 
Sec. 114-40. - Division supervisors. 
    A supervisor for each division or combination thereof of the utility department shall be appointed by the superintendent of utilities with the consent of the director of administration. 
(Code 1980, § 28-6) 
Sec. 114-41. - Compensation. 
    The salary scale for personnel of the utility department shall be established by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 28-7) 
Secs. 114-42-114-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BOARD OF PUBLIC UTILITIES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation board, § 82-51 et seq.; utility department, § 114-36 et seq. 

Sec. 114-51. - Established; duties. 
(a)  There is established, in accordance with article VI section 6.1(i) of the Charter, a board of public utilities. 
(b)  The duties and responsibilities of the board shall be as follows: 
(1)  The board shall have authority as provided in RSMo 91.540 with regard to rate setting. Recommendations for utility rate structures, increases or decreases in rates shall be made by the board to the city council when the board shall deem it appropriate. Before the city council shall finally pass any change in any rate or rate structure, it shall receive a recommendation from the board. The board shall review the rates annually of each utility operated by the city as a part of the budget process. A rate-setting policy shall be established by the council after receiving a recommendation from the board. 
(2)  The utility board shall review capital improvement requests, preliminary budget and salary structures as they may pertain to the utility department prior to submission to the city council and shall make such recommendations to the city council as it deems appropriate. 
(3)  The board shall sit in advisement with the mayor and director of administration in the selection of the superintendent of utilities. The board shall participate in: 
a.  The development of the job description for the superintendent of utilities. 
b.  The interview of candidates for the position. 
c.  Such other decision making process as may be necessary in filling the position of superintendent of utilities. 
(4)  The board shall act to set all technical policy and review technical operational activity not inconsistent with the Charter or ordinances of the city. At a minimum it shall: 
a.  Develop long range plans for the utility departments. 
b.  Develop plans for system enhancement. 
c.  Participate in the development of policies unique to the utility department before they are adopted or implemented. 
d.  Provide recommendations for all utility system extension policies. 
(5)  The board shall also have such other duties and responsibilities as may be assigned by the mayor, city council or the director of administration. 
(Code 1980, § 28-8) 
Sec. 114-52. - Appointment of members, terms, removal from office. 
(a)  The board of public utilities shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of a majority of the city council and shall consist of five members selected from residents of the city. 
(b)  Members of the board shall hold office for four years from July 1 following their appointment. Annually, the mayor shall before July 1 of each year appoint one member who shall hold office for four years. 
(c)  Upon recommendation of the mayor, a member of the board may be removed by a vote of five members of the city council. A member may also be removed by six votes of the city council independently of the mayor. 
(d)  Any member who fails to attend three consecutive regular meetings of the board without being formally excused by the board shall forfeit membership. 
(Code 1980, § 28-9; Ord. No. 942-03, § 1, 10-28-03) 
Sec. 114-53. - Meetings, officers, quorum, compensation. 
(a)  Within 15 days after their appointment, the board of public utilities shall meet to establish a regular quarterly meeting date and thereafter shall meet at least quarterly. The board shall elect one of its members as chairman and one as vice-chairman. The chairman of the board shall preside at its meetings. Three members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. All members of the board shall serve without compensation but the actual and necessary expenses of their office shall be paid by the city. 
(b)  The city clerk or a person designated by the director of administration shall be the recording secretary for the board and shall keep a record of all actions taken at its meetings. 
(Code 1980, § 28-10) 
Secs. 114-54-114-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SERVICE REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 114-76. - Monthly payment in lieu of taxes. 
    In lieu of taxes, the finance department shall bill, collect and pay into the general fund of the city each month five percent of the revenue collections for electricity, gas and water supplied by the city's utility department. Each utility bill shall reflect the amount to be transferred to the general fund. 
(Code 1980, § 28-13) 
Sec. 114-77. - Extension policies established. 
    Certain policies regarding the extension of all public utilities, both within and beyond the city limits, shall be as determined by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 28-14) 
Sec. 114-78. - Sale of public utilities. 
    The public utilities shall not be sold, disposed of in any way, abandoned or cease to operate, except by a majority of the votes cast at any city election or a special election held for that purpose pursuant to ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 28-15) 
Sec. 114-79. - Written application for utility service; normal business hours. 
(a)  Any person desiring utility service or termination of utility service shall make written application on a form furnished by the city. Such application shall be made as far in advance of the effective date as possible. 
(b)  A customer may order utility service between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:30 p.m., Monday through Friday, except on regularly scheduled city holidays. Customers requesting normal utility connections during hours or days other than those established in this subsection shall be required to pay a service charge of $25.00. 
(c)  The city shall not be obligated to provide utility connections or disconnections until reasonable time has been allowed for proper planning. 
(Code 1980, § 28-16) 
Sec. 114-80. - Notice when terminating utility service. 
    A customer who intends to vacate any premises, discontinue the use of utility services or terminate in any manner his liability to pay for utility services delivered to such premises shall give at least 24 hours' written notice on a form furnished by the city. 
(Code 1980, § 28-17) 
Sec. 114-81. - Special utility services. 
    Customers requesting special utility services, such as meter relocation or special disconnections and connections, shall be charged on a labor-and-material basis. 
(Code 1980, § 28-18) 
Sec. 114-82. - Denial of utility service. 
    No customer having an unpaid bill for utility service may be permitted new or additional utility service without approval by the city's chief financial officer. 
(Code 1980, § 28-19) 
Sec. 114-83. - Access to premises, discontinuance of service for cause other than nonpayment. 
    The city shall have, at all reasonable hours, access to the premises of a customer of any utility for the purpose of reading, inspecting, adjusting, repairing or otherwise caring for its service, connections and meters. The city shall have the right to discontinue any utility service without notice to prevent fraud or theft or for the protection of its property or to prevent disaster. The city shall also have the right to discontinue any utility service if the city's planning and code enforcement officer determines that a structure or condition upon the premises is in violation of national, state or city building, structural or utility code and that the continuance of service presents a hazard to health, safety or property. 
(Code 1980, § 28-20; Ord. No. 622-92, § 1, 8-25-92) 
Sec. 114-84. - Injuring, misusing utility system. 
    No person shall connect with or use any city utility service without the knowledge or consent of the city or after the utility service has been discontinued by the city nor shall he in any manner defraud the city in the use of any utility service or tamper with any utility meter or shunt around any meter nor shall he willfully or maliciously injure or destroy any property whatsoever of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 28-21) 
Sec. 114-85. - Area of service. 
(a)  The area of utility service shall be within the corporate city limits and within the area outside such corporate city limits served by any city utility. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent the city from purchasing, leasing, erecting, installing or otherwise acquiring real and personal property necessary, useful or desirable in the conduct of its operations at any place, whether within or without the corporate limits of the city, subject to approval by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 28-22) 
Secs. 114-86-114-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CLASSIFICATIONS, RATES AND DEPOSITS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Taxation, ch. 106. 

Sec. 114-96. - Classifications. 
(a)  Generally. The amounts and procedures for computation of the various rates, charges, deposits and classifications referred to in this section shall be as recommended by the utility board and approved by the city council from time to time. 
(b)  Electricity. The classification of electric users shall be as follows: 
(1)  Residential. 
a.  Availability. This schedule is available to any residential customer at points on the city utilities existing secondary distribution lines within the area served by city utilities. 
b.  Character of service. Alternating current, 60 cycles, 120/240 volt single phase. 
c.  Application. To single-phase service for all domestic users in private residences and individual family apartments supplied through one meter, where the city utilities are the sole source of supply. Not applicable for service to recognized roominghouses or boardinghouses or establishments of a nonresidential nature, i.e., apartment buildings served by a master meter. Service is for the exclusive use of the customer and shall not be resold. 
(2)  Residential electric heating (single meter). 
a.  Availability. This schedule is available to any residential customer at points on the city utilities existing secondary distribution lines within the area served by city utilities, for the seven regular monthly meter readings taken after October 1 and until May 1. This schedule is made available to residential customers whose residences are heated wholly by permanently installed electric heaters. 
b.  Character of service. Alternating current, 60 cycles, 120/240 volt single phase. 
c.  Application. To single-phase service for all domestic users in private residences or in individual family apartments supplied through one meter, where city utilities are the sole source of supply. Not applicable for service to recognized roominghouses or boardinghouses or establishments of a nonresidential nature, i.e., apartment buildings served by a master meter. Service is for the exclusive use of the customer and shall not be resold. 
(3)  Residential electric heating (separate meter). 
a.  Availability. This schedule is available to any residential customer at points on the city utilities existing secondary distribution lines within the area served by city utilities. This schedule is made available to residential customers whose residences are heated wholly by permanently installed electric heat for the seven regular monthly meter readings taken after October 1 and until May 1. Lighting and other power uses, except air conditioning, will not be allowed on this schedule. 
b.  Character of service. Alternating current, 60 cycles, 120/240 volt single phase. 
c.  Application. For heating and air conditioning service only through a separate meter, provided all other service is rendered through the regular meter. Not applicable for service to recognized roominghouses or boardinghouses or establishments of a nonresidential nature, i.e., apartment buildings served by a master meter. Service is for the exclusive use of the customer and shall not be resold. 
(4)  General service. 
a.  Availability. This rate is available to any customer at points on city utilities existing secondary distribution lines within the area served by city utilities. 
b.  Character of service. Alternating current, 60 cycles, 120/240 volt single phase or, where available and at the option of city utilities, 120/240 volt three phase, four wire delta or 120/208 volt three phase, four wire wye. 
c.  Application. To single-phase or three-phase service, if available, for all establishments, including churches, hospitals and apartment buildings served by a master meter, where city utilities are the sole source of supply. Service is for the exclusive use of the customer and shall not be resold. 
(5)  General service electric heating. 
a.  Availability. This schedule is available to general service customers, at points on the city utilities existing secondary distribution lines within the area served by city utilities, for the seven regular monthly meter readings taken after October 1 and until May 1. This schedule is made available to general service customers whose heating is obtained through permanently installed electric heaters, for the seven regular monthly meter readings taken after October 1 and until May 1. Lighting and other power uses, except air conditioning, will not be allowed on this schedule. 
b.  Character of service. Alternating current, 60 cycles, 120/240 volt, single phase or, where available and at the option of city utilities, 120/240 volt three phase, four wire wye or 120/208 volt three phase, four wire wye. 
c.  Application. For heating service only through a separate meter, provided all other service is rendered through the regular meter. For space heating and air conditioning service only through a separate meter, provided all other service is rendered through the regular meter. Service is for the exclusive use of the customer and shall not be resold. 
(6)  Medium power service. 
a.  Availability. This schedule is available to any nonresidential customer using standard electric service for power or combined power, lighting, heating and special equipment at points on city utilities existing distribution lines within the area served by city utilities. Customers under this schedule must use an average of 30,000 kwh of electricity per billing period annually. 
b.  Character of service. Alternating current, 60 cycles, 240 volt, 480 volt or 2400 volt, three phase or power loads, and 120/240 volts, single phase for lighting and incidental loads, or 120/208 volt three phase, four wire wye. 
c.  Application. To single-phase or three-phase services for all nonresidential power uses in commercial or manufacturing and processing establishments where city utilities are the sole source of supply. Service is for the exclusive use of the customer and shall not be resold. 
d.  General. As far as practical, all energy should pass through one point of delivery and the city utilities, at its option, may meter at primary voltage. The overall power factor of the load must not drop below 85 percent. If it is determined that the power factor has dropped below 85 percent, service under this schedule may be discontinued until such time as the customer installs suitable devices to bring the power factor up to 85 percent or higher. 
(7)  Large power service. 
a.  Availability. This schedule is available to large power customers using standard electric service for power or combined power, lighting, heating and special equipment at points on city utilities existing distribution lines within the area served by city utilities. Customers under this schedule will be billed for a minimum demand of 500 kilowatts in each billing period. All nonresidential customers having 500 kw demand or more in one month must use this large power rate schedule. 
b.  Character of service. Alternating current, 60 cycles, 240 volt, 480 volt or 2400 volt, three phase or power loads, and 120/240 volts, single phase for lighting and incidental loads or 120/208 volt three phase, four wire wye. 
c.  Application. To single-phase or three-phase services for all nonresidential power uses in commercial or manufacturing and processing establishments where city utilities are the sole source of supply. Service is for the exclusive use of the customer and shall not be resold. 
d.  General. As far as practical, all energy should pass through one point of delivery and the city utilities, at its option, may meter at primary voltage. The city utilities will install a suitable demand meter for determining the monthly maximum indicated demand. The overall power factor of the load must not drop below 85 percent. If it is determined that the power factor has dropped below 85 percent, service under this schedule may be discontinued until such time as the customer installs suitable devices to bring the power factor up to 85 percent or higher. 
(8)  Economic development rider. 
a.  Purpose. The purpose of this economic development rider (EDR) is to encourage industrial development in the city. 
b.  Restrictions. Electric rates computed using the formula contained in this EDR are not permitted for service provided pursuant to any other special electric rate structure. Retail customers are not eligible for this EDR. 
c.  Applicability. This EDR may be applied to new customers or additional separately metered facilities of existing customers. Charges qualifying for a reduction under this EDR for separately metered service to existing customers will be calculated independently of any other service rendered. Electric rates computed using the formula contained in this EDR apply only in conjunction with local governmental economic development activities and when the customer meets any one of the following criteria: 
1.  Customers peak demand is a minimum of 50 kw. 
2.  Customers electric energy consumption is a minimum of 25,000 kwh per month. 
3.  A minimum of 25 new full-time equivalent (FTE) jobs are created by the customer. The EDR becomes effective when the 25 FTE positions are filled. (One FTE=2,080 hours/year) 
4.  Recommended by the director of administration with the approval of the mayor. 
Final approval of each customer to receive the EDR, meeting the criteria above, will be granted by the city council. The director of administration will give written approval to the chief financial officer prior to implementation of the EDR. 
d.  Incentive billing calculation. Pretax charges computed using the standard rate schedule shall be reduced as follows: 
1.  By 25 percent during the first contract year. 
2.  By 20 percent during the second contract year. 
3.  By 15 percent during the third and fourth contract years. 
4.  By ten percent during the fifth contract year. 
This incentive calculation schedule shall cease at the conclusion of the fifth contract year. All other billing, operational and related provisions of the standard rate schedule shall remain in effect. 
e.  Additional consideration. The city will not require customer payment for construction of standard service equipment if the projected revenue from the new load is determined to be sufficient to justify the required investment by the city. The request for rate computation as provided in this EDR shall be accompanied by sufficiently detailed information to enable the city to determine whether the request will meet the required criteria. New or expanded facilities, under construction or otherwise committed to operation prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this subsection (b)(8) derives, are not eligible for rate calculation under this EDR. Electric service provided under the conditions of this EDR shall be evidenced by a contract between the customer and the city. 
f.  Cessation or termination of EDR. The city may cease to offer the EDR with respect to new electric loads at any time following the first anniversary of the initial offering of the EDR. However, customers receiving service under this rider on the date it is withdrawn may continue to receive the benefits of this rider. Notwithstanding the above, this rider shall immediately become void and the city shall have no further obligations or liabilities hereunder if any provision of this rider is determined to be unlawful by a court of competent jurisdiction. If the customer receiving the EDR fails to meet the qualifying criteria for any six consecutive months, the EDR for that customer will be terminated. 
(Code 1980, § 28-23; Ord. No. 761-97, § 1, 12-16-97) 
Sec. 114-97. - Rates. 
(a)  Various rates for utility service shall be as established by ordinance. 
(b)  Established rates shall be reviewed annually by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 28-11) 
Sec. 114-98. - Special rates for retired employees. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term "retirement" refers to those full-time employees who retire using the guidelines for retirement as outlined in the personnel manual. 
(b)  All employees of the city who were working for the city as full-time employees on January 5, 1976, and who have maintained continuous city employment to retirement eligibility shall be charged for electric, gas, water and sewer services one-half of the regular rates charged by the city for such services. 
(c)  The intent of this section is to restore to those persons employed by the city on January 5, 1976, the benefits which were eliminated by the repeal of Code 1961, section 2-90.1. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to any individuals employed after January 5, 1976. 
(e)  To receive utility rates at one-half of the regular rates charged, the employee must be receiving utility services from the city. This would entitle the retired employee to receive the benefits even though the retired employee was not entitled to the benefits at the time of initial retirement because of not using municipal utilities. This policy shall apply only to the personal residence of the retired employee while he resides in that residence as a member of the household. 
(Code 1980, § 28-12) 
Sec. 114-99. - Utility deposits. 
(a)  Deposits shall be required of all utility customers prior to connection to city utilities, except as provided in sections 114-100 and 114-101. 
(b)  Utility deposits shall be placed in the deposit fund of the utility for which the deposit was collected. 
(c)  Following the final readout of a customer's utility meter, the customer's deposit shall be applied to the unpaid bill, and the balance of the deposit, if any, shall be returned to the customer. 
(Code 1980, § 28-24; Ord. No. 1185-07, § 1, 6-26-07) 
Sec. 114-100. - Deposit schedule established. 
(a)  The schedule for residential utility deposits shall be as established by the city council. 
(b)  New commercial/industrial customers. The city will require security equal to one month's average bill for all new commercial customers. The average bill would be based on past consumption history at the service address. If this is unavailable or inappropriate due to a change in the type of business to be located at that address, then the city will look at similar types of businesses either among its own customers or in other cities. In any case, the security will be required before utility service is activated. 
(c)  Existing commercial/industrial customers whose accounts are not secured as of the date this policy is adopted will not be required to furnish security for their accounts as long as they maintain a good payment history. If an existing customer's account is delinquent two or more times during the last 12 months, the city retains the right to require security equal to as much as three month's average bills. The customer is to provide this security within 30 days of notification. Service may be terminated if the required security is not in place within 30 days of notification. 
(Code 1980, § 28-25; Ord. No. 1185-07, § 1, 6-26-07) 
Sec. 114-101. - Deposits refunded for timely payment. 
(a)  Residential customers. Any person having been a city residential utility customer for a period of time exceeding two years and who at that time has consistently paid all utility bills by their due date shall be deemed to have established a payment record entitling him to have all his utility deposits refunded or credited to an appropriate utility bill upon request. 
(b)  Commercial and industrial customers. Deposits on commercial and/or industrial customers are nonrefundable as long as the account is active. 
(Code 1980, § 28-26; Ord. No. 1185-07, § 1, 6-26-07) 
Sec. 114-102. - Exceptions to payment of deposits. 
(a)  Residential customers. Any person requesting residential utility service who furnishes a letter from an immediate past utility supplier, indicating a satisfactory payment record for a period of 12 continuous months within the past two years, shall not be required to make utility deposits. However, if consistent payment by the due date is not maintained, utility deposits may be required. 
(b)  Any person having made deposits for residential utility service who subsequently furnishes a letter as provided in subsection (a) of this section may obtain a refund of or credit for such deposits. 
(c)  Commercial and industrial customers. If an existing customer with a good payment history: 
(1)  Relocates within the city or expands an existing location - additional security will not be required unless there will be a significant increase in consumption; 
(2)  Opens a second or new location (either directly related to the existing business or a new business) - security will be required in the amount of one month's average bill for that location. 
(d)  If the city is holding security on an existing account due to poor payment history, security will also be required for any new accounts the customer may wish to open due to relocation, expansion or opening of new business. 
(Code 1980, § 28-27; Ord. No. 1185-07, § 1, 6-26-07) 
Sec. 114-103. - Additional deposit. 
(a)  Residential customers. If a residential customer is delinquent two or more times in any 12-month period for non-payment of any utility bill, the city may require an increase in deposit up to three months average bill. 
(b)  Commercial and industrial customers: 
(1)  Adjustment for poor payment history. Accounts will be reviewed monthly for adequacy of security based on payment history. If an account has a poor payment history, the city may require an increase in security up to three months average bill;
